translated: But an action that has another as its substratum cannot be the object [of the injunction], so the self is not modified by that.

original: nanu dehāśrayayā snānācamanayajñopavītādikayā kriyayā dehī saṃskriyamāṇo dṛṣṭaḥ / na /
analyzed: nanu deha āśrayayā snāna ācamana yajñopavīta ādikayā kriyayā dehī saṃskriyamāṇaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ na
translated: But is not the embodied self seen to be purified by the rites based on the body, such as bathing, sipping water, wearing the sacred thread, etc.? No.

analyzed: deha ādi saṃhatasya eva avidyā gṛhītasya ātmānaḥ saṃskriyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because only that which is united with the body, etc., and grasped by ignorance, is seen to be purified as the self.

analyzed: pratyakṣam hi snāna ācamana ādeḥ deha samavāyi tvam
translated: For bathing, sipping water, etc. are directly perceived to be inherent in the body.

original: tayā dehāśrayayā tatsaṃhata eva kaścidavidyayātmatvena parigṛhītaḥ saṃskriyata iti yuktam /
analyzed: tayā deha āśrayayā tad saṃhataḥ eva kaścid avidyayā ātma tvena parigṛhītaḥ saṃskriyate iti yuktam
translated: It is reasonable that someone who is united with that [body] is purified by that [rite] based on the body, being grasped as the self by ignorance.

original: yathā dehāśrayacikitsānimittena dhātusāmyena tatsaṃhatasya tadabhimānina ārogyaphalaṃ /
analyzed: yathā deha āśraya cikitsā nimittena dhātu sāmyena tad saṃhatasya tad abhimāninaḥ ārogya phalam
translated: Just as the result of health is for one who is united with that [body] and has the notion of self, by the balance of the elements caused by medical treatment based on the body.

analyzed: aham arogaḥ iti yatra buddhiḥ utpadyate
translated: Where the notion arises, I am healthy.

original: evaṃ snānācamanayajñopavītādinā ahaṃ śuddhaḥ saṃskṛta iti yatra buddhirutpadyate sa saṃskriyate /
analyzed: evam snāna ācamana yajñopavīta ādinā aham śuddhaḥ saṃskṛtaḥ iti yatra buddhiḥ utpadyate sa saṃskriyate
translated: In the same way, one is purified by bathing, sipping water, wearing the sacred thread, etc., where the notion arises, I am pure, purified.

analyzed: sa ca dehena saṃhataḥ eva
translated: And that [person] is united with the body itself.

original: tenaiva hyahaṅkartrāhaṃpratyayaviṣayeṇa pratyayinā sarvāḥ kriyā nirvartyante /
analyzed: tena eva hi ahaṅkartrā ahaṃpratyaya viṣayeṇa pratyayinā sarvāḥ kriyāḥ nirvartyante
translated: For all actions are performed by that very object of the notion of I and the notion of I am, which is the experiencer.

analyzed: tad phalam ca saḥ eva aśnāti
translated: And that [person] alone enjoys its result.

analyzed: tayoḥ anyaḥ pippalam svādvatti an aśnan anyaḥ abhicākāśīti muṇḍa  iti mantra varṇāt
translated: And from the text of the mantra, 'One of them eats the sweet fruit, the other looks on without eating' (Mu. Up. 3.1.1).

analyzed: ātma indriya manaḥ yuktam bhoktā iti āhuḥ manīṣiṇaḥ kāṭhaḥ iti ca
translated: And also, 'The wise call him the enjoyer, united with the self, the senses, and the mind' (Ka. Up. 2.3.1).

analyzed: tathā ca ekaḥ devaḥ sarva bhūteṣu gūḍhaḥ sarva vyāpī sarva bhūta antarātmā
translated: And so also, 'The one God, hidden in all beings, all-pervading, the inner self of all beings,

original: karmādhyakṣaḥ sarvabhūtādhivāsaḥ sākṣī cetā kevalo nirguṇaśca' śvetā / / iti /🔽sa paryagācchukramakāyamantraṇamastrāviraṃśuddhamapāpaviddham /
analyzed: karma adhyakṣaḥ sarva bhūta adhivāsaḥ sākṣī cetā kevalaḥ nirguṇaḥ ca śvetāḥ iti  sa paryagāt śukram akāya mantraṇam astra āvis aṃśuddham apāpa viddham
translated: the overseer of actions, the abode of all beings, the witness, the knower, the sole, qualityless one' (Sv. Up. 6.10).

analyzed: ī iti ca
translated: And also, 'He has gone to the pure, bodiless, imperishable, stainless, sinless one' (Sv. Up. 3.19).

original: etau mantrāvanādheyātiśayatāṃ nityaśuddhatāṃ ca brahmaṇo darśayataḥ /
analyzed: etau mantrau anādheya atiśaya tām nitya śuddha tām ca brahmaṇaḥ darśayataḥ
translated: These two mantras show that Brahman has no property that can be added to it and is eternally pure.

analyzed: brahma bhāvaḥ ca mokṣaḥ
translated: And liberation is the state of Brahman.

analyzed: tasmāt na saṃskāryaḥ mokṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, liberation is not to be purified.

original: ato 'nyanmokṣaṃ prati kriyānupraveśadvāraṃ na śakyaṃ kenaciddarśayitum /
analyzed: atas prati kriyā anupraveśa dvāram na śakyam kenacid darśayitum
translated: Apart from this, no one can show any other door for the entrance of action towards liberation.

original: tasmāt jñānamekaṃ muktvā kriyāyā gandhamātrasyāpyanupraveśa iha nopapadyate /
analyzed: tasmāt jñānam ekam muktvā kriyāyāḥ gandha mātrasya api anupraveśaḥ iha na upapadyate
translated: Therefore, apart from knowledge alone, the entrance here of even the mere smell of action is not possible.

original: nanu jñānaṃ nāma mānasī kriyā / na /
analyzed: nanu jñānam nāma mānasī kriyā
translated: But is not knowledge a mental action? No.

analyzed: vailakṣaṇyāt
translated: Because of its difference.

original: kriyā hi nāma sā yatra vastusvarūpanirapekṣaiva codyate /
analyzed: kriyā hi nāma sā yatra vastu svarūpa nirapekṣā eva codyate
translated: For an action is that which is enjoined independently of the nature of the thing.

original: puruṣacittavyāpārādhīnā ca /🔽yathā yasyai devatāyai havirgṛhītaṃ syāttāṃ manasā dhyāyedvṣaṭkariṣyan iti /
analyzed: puruṣa citta vyāpāra adhīnā ca  yathā yasyai devatāyai haviḥ gṛhītam syāt tām manasā dhyāyet vṣaṭkariṣyan iti
translated: And it is dependent on the mental activity of the person.🔽As in the case of the injunction, One who is about to offer oblations to a deity should meditate on that deity in his mind.

analyzed: saṃdhyām manasā dyāyet aibrā
translated: And in such statements as One should meditate on the evening twilight in one's mind.

analyzed: iti ca evamādiṣu
translated: And so on.

original: dhyānaṃ cintanaṃ yadyapi mānasaṃ tathāpi puruṣeṇa kartumakartumanyathā vā kartuṃ śakyaṃ /
analyzed: dhyānam cintanam yadi api mānasam tathā api puruṣeṇa kartum a kartum anyathā vā kartum śakyam
translated: Although meditation is mental, still it can be done, not done, or done differently by a person.

analyzed: puruṣa tantra tvāt
translated: Because it is dependent on the person.

analyzed: jñānam tu pramāṇa janyam
translated: But knowledge is produced by a means of valid cognition.

original: pramāṇaṃ ca yathābhūtavastuviṣayamato jñānaṃ kartumakartumanyathā vā kartumaśakyaṃ /
analyzed: pramāṇam ca yathā bhūta vastu viṣayam atas jñānam kartum akartum anyathā vā kartum aśakyam
translated: And a means of valid cognition has as its object a real thing as it is. Therefore, knowledge cannot be made, not made, or made differently.

analyzed: kevalam vastu tantram eva tat
translated: It is solely dependent on the thing itself.

analyzed: na codanā tantram
translated: And it is not dependent on an injunction.

analyzed: na api puruṣa tantram
translated: Nor is it dependent on a person.

analyzed: tasmāt mānasa tve pi jñānasya mahat vailakṣaṇyam
translated: Therefore, even though knowledge is mental, it is very different.

analyzed: yathā ca puruṣaḥ vāva gautama agniḥ
translated: And just as in the case of The person, O Gautama, is the fire,

analyzed: yoṣā vāva gautama agniḥ chāndaḥ
translated: The woman, O Gautama, is the fire (Chandogya Upanishad 5.1.1),

analyzed: iti atra yoṣit puruṣayoḥ agni buddhiḥ mānasī bhavati
translated: here the mental cognition of a woman and a man as fire occurs.

analyzed: keva codanā janya tvāt kriyā eva sā puruṣa tantrā ca
translated: It is an action, because it is produced by the mere injunction, and it depends on the human agent.

analyzed: yā tu prasiddhe gnau agni buddhiḥ na sā codanā tantrā
translated: But the cognition of fire in a well-known fire is not dependent on an injunction.

analyzed: na api puruṣa tantrā
translated: Nor does it depend on a human agent.

analyzed: kim tarhi pratyakṣa vastu tantrā eva iti jñānam eva etat na kriyā
translated: What then? It depends only on the directly perceived object. Thus it is knowledge, not an action.

analyzed: evam sarva pramāṇa viṣaya vastuṣu veditavyam
translated: This should be understood in the case of all objects that are the content of valid cognition.

original: tatraivaṃ sati yathābhūtabrahmātmaviṣayamapi jñānaṃ na codanātantram /
analyzed: tatra evam sati yathā bhūta brahma ātma viṣayam api jñānam na codanā tantram
translated: In that case, the knowledge of Brahman, the true Self, is also not dependent on an injunction.

analyzed: tad viṣaye liṅ āga ādayaḥ śrūyamāṇāḥ api aniyojya viṣaya tvāt kuṇṭhībhavanti upala ādiṣu prayukta kṣura taikṣṇya ādi vat
translated: The optative endings, etc., even when heard, become crippled in regard to that object, like the sharpness of a razor used on stone, etc., because they have no enjoined object.

analyzed: aheya anupādeya vastu viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because it has as its object a thing that is neither to be accepted nor rejected.

original: kimarthāni tarhi 'ātmā vāre draṣyavyaḥ śrotavyaḥ' ityādīni vidhicchāyāni vacanāni /
analyzed: kimarthāni tarhi ātmā vāre draṣyavyaḥ śrotavyaḥ ityādīni vidhi chāyāni vacanāni
translated: Then what is the purpose of such statements as The Self is to be seen, to be heard which resemble injunctions?

analyzed: svābhāvika pravṛtti viṣaya vimukhīkaraṇa arthāni iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say they are for the purpose of turning one away from the objects of natural engagement.

original: yo hi bahirmukhaḥ pravartate puruṣaḥ iṣṭaṃ me bhūyādadaniṣṭaṃ mābhūditi /
analyzed: yaḥ hi bahirmukhaḥ pravartate puruṣaḥ iṣṭam me bhūyāt adaniṣṭam mā abhūt iti
translated: For a person who engages externally, thinking May what is desirable happen to me, may what is undesirable not happen,

analyzed: na ca tatra ātyantikam puruṣa irtham labhate
translated: does not attain the ultimate human goal in that.

original: tamātyantikapuruṣārthavāñchinaṃ svābhāvikakāryakaraṇasaṃghātapravṛttigocarādvimukhīkṛtya pratyagātmasrotastayā pravartayanti 'ātmā vā are draṣṭavyaḥ'🔽ityādīni /
analyzed: tam ātyantika puruṣa artha vāñchinam svābhāvika kārya karaṇa saṃghāta pravṛtti gocarāt vimukhīkṛtya pratyagātma srotaḥ tayā pravartayanti ātmā vai are draṣṭavyaḥ  ityādīni
translated: They turn him away from the sphere of activity of the natural operation of the aggregate of body and organs, which is directed to the external world, and make him proceed by the current of the inward Self, with such passages as, ‘The Self is to be seen, to be heard, to be thought’ (Br. 3, 4, 1).

analyzed: tasya ātma anveṣaṇāya pravṛttasya aheyam anupādeyam ca ātma tattvam upadiśyate
translated: For him who has set out to seek the Self, the truth about the Self, which is neither to be rejected nor to be accepted, is taught.

analyzed: idam sarvam yat ayam ātmā bṛha
translated: ‘All this, whatever there is, is that Self’ (Ch. 7, 25, 2).

original: 'yatra tvasya sarvamātmaivābhūttatkena kaṃ paśyet kena kaṃ vijānīyāt vījñātāramare kena vijānīyāt' bṛha / / /
analyzed: yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśyet kena kam vijānīyāt vījñātāram are kena vijānīyāt
translated: ‘When the Self only is all this, how should he see another? By what and whom should he see? By what and whom should he know the knower? (Br. 4, 5, 15).

analyzed: ayam ātmā brahma bṛha
translated: ‘This Self is Brahman’ (Br. 1, 4, 10).

analyzed: ityādibhiḥ
translated: With such passages.

analyzed: yat api akartavya pradhānam ātma jñānam hānāya upādānāya vā na bhavati iti
translated: And as for the argument that the knowledge of the Self, which has for its principal content what is not to be done, does not lead to the rejection or acceptance of anything,

analyzed: tat tathā eva iti abhyupagamyate
translated: that is accepted just as it is.

original: alaṅkāro hyayamasmākaṃ yadbrahmātmāvagatau satyāṃ sarvakartavyatāhāniḥ kṛtakṛtyatā ceti /
analyzed: alaṅkāraḥ hi ayam asmākam yat brahma ātma avagatau satyām sarva kartavya tā hāniḥ kṛtakṛtya tā ca iti
translated: For it is an ornament to us that when the Brahman-Self is known, all that is to be done ceases, and one becomes one whose purpose is fulfilled.

analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ ātmānam ced vijānīyāt ayam asti iti pūruṣaḥ
translated: And thus the Śruti: ‘If a man knows the Self as “He is”,

analyzed: kim icchan kasya kāmāya śarīram anusaṃjvaret
translated: desiring what, for the sake of what desire, should he grieve for the body?’ (Bṛ. 4, 4, 22).

analyzed: bṛhaḥ iti
translated: Brih. .. thus.

analyzed: etat buddhvā buddhimān syāt kṛtakṛtyaḥ ca bhārata
translated: 'Having understood this, one becomes wise and has accomplished one's purpose, O descendant of Bharata.'

analyzed: bhagī iti smṛtiḥ
translated: This is the Smriti.

analyzed: tasmāt na pratipatti vidhi viṣaya tayā brahmaṇaḥ samarpaṇam
translated: Therefore, Brahman is not presented as the subject of the injunction to practice.

original: yadapi kecidāhuḥ 'pravṛttinivṛttividhitaccheṣavyatirekeṇa kevalavastuvādī vedabhāgo nāsti' iti tanna /
analyzed: yat api kecid āhuḥ pravṛtti nivṛtti vidhi tad śeṣa vyatirekeṇa kevala vastu vādī veda bhāgaḥ na asti iti tat na
translated: As for what some say: 'Apart from injunctions to engage and disengage, and their remnants, there is no part of the Veda that speaks only of real things,' that is not so.

analyzed: aupaniṣadasya puruṣasya puruṣasya an anya śeṣa tvāt
translated: Because the person taught in the Upanishads is not a mere remnant of something else.

original: yo 'sāvupaniṣatsvevādhigataḥ puruṣo 'saṃsārī brahma utpādyādicaturvidhadravyavilakṣaṇaḥ svaprakaraṇastho 'nanyośeṣaḥ /🔽nāsau nāsti nādhigamyata iti vā śakyaṃ vaditum /
analyzed: saṃsārī brahma utpādi ādi caturvidha dravya vilakṣaṇaḥ sva prakaraṇa sthaḥ  na asau na asti na adhigamyate iti vā śakyam vaditum
translated: That person who is known only in the Upanishads, who is not subject to transmigration, who is different from the four kinds of substances beginning with the produced, who is mentioned in his own context, and who is not a mere remnant of something else,🔽it cannot be said that he does not exist or is not known.

analyzed: saḥ eṣa na iti na iti ātmā bṛha
translated: 'He is the Self who is to be described as neither this nor that.' Brih. ..

analyzed: iti āma śabdāt
translated: Thus it is stated in the Upanishads.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ ca pratyākhyātum aśakya tvāt
translated: And because the Self cannot be denied.

analyzed: yaḥ eva nirākartā tasya eva ātma tvāt
translated: Because the very one who denies is the Self.

analyzed: nanu ātmā ahaṃpratyaya viṣaya tvāt upaniṣatsu eva vijñāyate iti anupapannam na
translated: But it is not possible that the Self is known only in the Upanishads because it is the object of the notion of 'I.' No.

analyzed: tad sākṣi tvena pratyukta tvāt
translated: Because this has been answered by his being the witness of that.

original: nahyahaṃpratyayaviṣayakartṛvyatirekeṇa tatsākṣī sarvabhūtasthaḥ sama ekaḥ kūṭasthanityaḥ puruṣo vidhikāṇḍe tarkasamaye vā kenacidadhigataḥ🔽ataḥ sa na kenacitpratyākhyātuṃ śakyo vidhiśeṣatvaṃ vā netum /
analyzed: na hi aham pratyaya viṣaya kartṛ vyatirekeṇa tad sākṣī sarva bhūta sthaḥ samaḥ ekaḥ kūṭastha nityaḥ puruṣaḥ vidhi kāṇḍe tarka samaye vā kenacid adhigataḥ  atas sa na kenacid pratyākhyātum śakyaḥ vidhi śeṣa tvam vā netum
translated: For, apart from the object of the notion of I, the agent, no one has perceived, either in the injunctions or in the time of reasoning, any other witness of that, abiding in all beings, one, uniform, immutable, eternal, puruṣa.🔽Therefore, he cannot be denied by anyone or led to be the remainder of an injunction.

original: asmatvādeva ca sarveṣāṃ na heyo nāpyupādeyaḥ /
analyzed: asmatvāt eva ca sarveṣām na heyaḥ na api upādeyaḥ
translated: And because of his existence, he is neither to be rejected nor accepted by anyone.

analyzed: sarvam hi vinaśyat vikāra jātam puruṣa antam vinaśyati
translated: For, indeed, the entire perishable manifold perishes with the puruṣa.

analyzed: puruṣaḥ vināśa hetu ābhāvāt avināśī
translated: The puruṣa is imperishable, because there is no cause for destruction.

analyzed: vikriyā hetu abhāvāt ca  kūṭastha nityaḥ
translated: And because there is no cause for modification.🔽He is immutable and eternal.

analyzed: atas eva nitya aśuddha buddha mukta svabhāvaḥ
translated: For this very reason, he is of the nature of eternal purity, knowledge, and freedom.

original: tasmāt 'puruṣānna paraṃ kiñcitsā kāṣṭā sā parā gatiḥ' kāṭha / / /
analyzed: tasmāt puruṣāt na param kiñcid sā kāṣṭā sā parā gatiḥ
translated: Therefore, 'There is nothing higher than the puruṣa; that is the highest end, that is the highest goal' (Kaṭha Upaniṣad).

analyzed: tam tvā aupaniṣadam puruṣam pṛcchāmi bṛha
translated: 'I ask about that puruṣa who is taught in the Upaniṣads' (Brhadāranyaka Upaniṣad).

original: iti caupaniṣadatvaviśeṣaṇaṃ puruṣasyopaniṣatsu prādhānyena prakāśyamānatva upapadyate /
analyzed: iti ca aupaniṣada tva viśeṣaṇam puruṣasya upaniṣatsu prādhānyena prakāśyamāna tve upapadyate
translated: And the qualification of the puruṣa as being taught in the Upaniṣads is justified by his being taught as the principal subject in the Upaniṣads.

original: ato bhūtavastuparo vedabhāgo nāstīti vacanaṃ sāhasamātram /
analyzed: atas bhūta vastu paraḥ veda bhāgaḥ na asti iti vacanam sāhasa mātram
translated: Therefore, the statement that there is no part of the Veda that refers to real entities is mere audacity.

original: yadapi śāstratātparyavidāmanukramaṇam 'dṛṣṭo hi tasyārthaḥ karmāvabodhanam' ityevamādi /
analyzed: yat api śāstra tātparya vidām anukramaṇam dṛṣṭaḥ hi tasya arthaḥ karma avabodhanam iti evamādi
translated: And the statement of those who know the purport of the scriptures, such as The purpose of that (Veda) is seen to be the teaching of duties,

analyzed: tad dharma jijñāsā viṣaya tvāt vidhi pratiṣedha a śāstra abhiprāyam draṣṭavyam  apica āmnāyasya kriyā artha tvāt ānarthakyam atarthānām iti etat ekāntena abhyupagacchatām bhūta upadeśa ānārthakya prasaṅgaḥ
translated: That should be seen as referring to the scriptures of injunctions and prohibitions, because it is the object of the inquiry into dharma.🔽Moreover, for those who accept this as an absolute truth, Since the Veda is for the sake of action, the teaching of what is not for the sake of action is useless, there would be the undesirable consequence of the uselessness of the teaching of what exists.

analyzed: pravṛtti nivṛtti vidhi tad śeṣa vyatirekeṇa bhūtam ced vastu upadiśati bhavya artha tvena
translated: If the Veda teaches an existent thing as a means to what is to be accomplished, apart from the injunctions of engagement and disengagement and their remnants,

analyzed: kūṭastha nityam bhūtam na upadiśati iti kaḥ hetuḥ
translated: what is the reason that it does not teach the immutable and eternal existent as for the sake of what is to be accomplished?

analyzed: nahi bhūtam upadiśyamānam kriyā bhavati
translated: For when an existent is taught, it does not become an action.

original: akriyātve 'pi bhūtasya kriyāsādhanatvātkriyārthaṃ eva bhūtopadeśa iti cet /
analyzed: akriyā tve pi bhūtasya kriyā sādhana tvāt kriyā artham eva bhūta upadeśaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the teaching of the existent is for the sake of action, because even though it is not an action, it is a means of action,

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ  kriyā artha tve pi kriyā ativartana śaktimat vastu upadiṣṭam eva
translated: that is not a fault.🔽Even if it is for the sake of action, the existent thing that has the power to transcend action is indeed taught.

analyzed: kriyā artha tvam tu prayojanam tasya
translated: But being for the sake of action is its purpose.

analyzed: na ca etāvatā vastu anupadiṣṭam bhavati
translated: And by that much, the existent thing is not untaught.

original: yadi nāmopadiṣṭaṃ kiṃ tava tena syāditi /
analyzed: yadi nāma upadiṣṭam kim tava tena syāt iti
translated: If it be said that, even if it is taught, what is the use of it to you?

analyzed: ucyate anavagata ātma vastu upadeśaḥ ca tathā eva bhavitum arhati
translated: We reply: The teaching of the truth of the self, which was not known before, can be only of that kind.

original: tadavagatyā mithyājñānasya saṃsārahetornivṛttiḥ prayojanaṃ kriyata ityavāśiṣṭamarthavattvaṃ kriyāsādhanavastūpadeśena /
analyzed: tad avagatyā mithyājñānasya saṃsāra hetoḥ nivṛttiḥ prayojanam kriyate iti ava śiṣṭam arthavattvam kriyā sādhana vastu upadeśena
translated: By the knowledge of that, the purpose is accomplished, which is the cessation of false knowledge, the cause of the world. Thus the usefulness of the teaching of the means of action remains intact.

original: apica 'brāhmaṇo na hantavyaḥ' iti caivamādyā nivṛttirupadiśyate /
analyzed: apica brāhmaṇaḥ na hantavyaḥ iti ca evamādyā nivṛttiḥ upadiśyate
translated: Moreover, prohibitions like 'A Brahmin should not be killed' are taught.

analyzed: na ca sā kriyā
translated: And that is not an action.

analyzed: na api kriyā sādhanam
translated: Nor is it a means of action.

analyzed: akriyā arthānām upadeśaḥ narthakaḥ ced brāhmaṇaḥ na hantavyaḥ ityādi nivṛtti upadeśānām ānarthakyam prāptam
translated: If the teaching of things that are not actions is useless, then the teaching of prohibitions like 'A Brahmin should not be killed' would become useless.

analyzed: tat ca aniṣṭam
translated: And that is undesirable.

analyzed: na ca sva abhāva prāpta hanti artha anurāgeṇa nañaḥ śakyam aprāpta kriyā artha tvam kalpayitum
translated: And it is not possible to assume that the negative has the meaning of an action not enjoined by the Veda, by taking the meaning of 'kills' as obtained by the nature of things.

analyzed: hanana kriyā nivṛtti audāsīnya vyatirekeṇa
translated: Except for indifference to the cessation of the action of killing.

analyzed: nañaḥ ca eṣa svabhāvaḥ yat sva saṃbandhinaḥ bhāvam bodhayati iti
translated: And this is the nature of the negative that it conveys the non-existence of what is connected with itself.

analyzed: abhāva buddhiḥ ca audāsīnya kāraṇam
translated: And the cognition of non-existence is the cause of indifference.

analyzed: sā ca dagdha indhana agni vat svayam eva upāśāmyati
translated: And that, like a fire whose fuel is consumed, ceases by itself.

original: tasmātprasaktakriyānivṛttyaudāsīnyameva 'brāhmaṇo na hantavyaḥ' ityādiṣu pratiṣedhārthaṃ manyāmahe /
analyzed: tasmāt prasakta kriyā nivṛtti audāsīnyam eva brāhmaṇaḥ na hantavyaḥ ityādiṣu pratiṣedha artham manyāmahe
translated: Therefore, we consider that the meaning of the prohibitions such as 'a Brahmin should not be killed' is merely the indifference consisting in the cessation of the activity that is engaged in.

analyzed: anyatra prajāpati trāta ādibhyaḥ
translated: Except in the case of Prajapati, Traata, and others.

analyzed: tasmāt puruṣa artha anupayogi upākhyāna ādi bhūta arthavāda viṣayam ānarthakya abhidhānam draṣṭavyam
translated: Therefore, the statement of meaninglessness should be seen as referring to the stories and other things that are not useful for human goals.

original: yadapyuktaṃ kartavyavidhyanupraveśamantareṇa vastumātramucyamānamānarthakaṃ syāt 'saptadvīpā vasumatī' tyādivaditi /
analyzed: yat api uktam kartavya vidhi anupraveśam antareṇa vastu mātram ucyamānam ānarthakam syāt saptadvīpā vasumatī tyādi vat iti
translated: As for what was said - that if something is stated as merely an object without being connected to an injunction to perform, it would be meaningless like 'the earth with seven islands' and so on -

analyzed: tat parihṛtam
translated: that has been refuted.

original: rajuriyaṃ nāyaṃ sarpa iti vastumātrakathane 'pi prayojanasya dṛṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: rajuḥ iyam na ayam sarpaḥ iti vastu mātra kathane pi prayojanasya dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because even in the mere statement of an object, like 'this is a rope, not a snake', a purpose is seen.

analyzed: nanu yathāpūrvam saṃsāri tvar dānāt na raju sva rūpa kathana vat arthavat tvam iti uktam
translated: But it was said that even for one who has heard about Brahman, since he continues to be a transmigrator as before, it is not meaningful like the statement about the nature of the rope.

original: atrocyate nāvagatabrahmātmabhāvasya yathāpūrvaṃ saṃsāritvaṃ śakyaṃ darśayituṃ va vedapramāṇajanitabrahmātmabhāvavirodhāt /
analyzed: atrā ucyate na avagata brahma ātma bhāvasya yathāpūrvam saṃsāri tvam śakyam darśayitum veda pramāṇa janita brahma ātma bhāva virodhāt
translated: To this it is said: The state of being a transmigrator as before cannot be shown for one who has not understood the nature of Brahman as the self, because it is contradicted by the state of being Brahman-self produced by the valid knowledge of the Vedas.

original: nahi śarīrādyātmābhimānino duḥkhabhayādimattvaṃ dṛṣṭamiti tasyaiva vedapramāṇajanitabrahmātmāvagame
analyzed: nahi śarīra ādi ātma abhimāninaḥ duḥkha bhaya ādimat tvam dṛṣṭam iti tasya eva veda pramāṇa janita brahma ātma avagame
translated: For it is not seen that one who is attached to the body, etc., as the self has sorrow, fear, etc.; and it is not possible to imagine that for him alone, when the knowledge of Brahman as the self is produced by the Veda as a means of knowledge,

original: tadabhimānanivṛttau tadeva mithyājñānanimittaṃ duḥkhabhayādimattvaṃ bhavatīti śakyaṃ kalpayitum /
analyzed: tad abhimāna nivṛttau tat eva mithyājñāna nimittam duḥkha bhaya ādimattvam bhavati iti śakyam kalpayitum
translated: when the attachment to that [body, etc.] ceases, that very sorrow, fear, etc., which have false knowledge as their cause, continue to exist.

original: nahi dhanino gṛhasthasya dhanābhimānino dhanāpahāranimittaṃ duḥkhaṃ dṛṣṭamiti tasyaiva pravrajitasya dhanābhimānarahitasya tadeva dhanāpahranimittaṃ
analyzed: nahi dhaninaḥ gṛhasthasya dhana abhimāninaḥ dhana apahāra nimittam duḥkham dṛṣṭam iti tasya eva pravrajitasya dhana abhimāna rahitasya tat eva dhana apahra nimittam
translated: For it is not seen that a householder who is rich and attached to his wealth has sorrow caused by the loss of his wealth, and that for him alone who has gone forth as a renunciant, being devoid of attachment to wealth, that very sorrow caused by the loss of wealth

analyzed: duḥkham bhavati
translated: continues to exist.

original: naca kuṇḍalinaḥ kuṇḍalitvābhimānanimittaṃ sukhaṃ dṛṣṭamiti tasyaiva kuṇḍalaviyuktasya kuṇḍalitvābhimānanimittaṃ sukhaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: na ca kuṇḍalinaḥ kuṇḍali tva abhimāna nimittam sukham dṛṣṭam iti tasya eva kuṇḍala viyuktasya kuṇḍali tva abhimāna nimittam sukham bhavati
translated: And it is not seen that one who has earrings has happiness caused by the conceit of having earrings, and that for him alone who is separated from the earrings, the happiness caused by the conceit of having earrings🔽continues to exist.

original: taduktaṃ śrutyā 'ārīraṃ vāva santaṃ na priyāpriye spṛśataḥ' chāndo / / / iti /
analyzed: tat uktam śrutyā ārīram vāva santam na priya apriye spṛśataḥ chāndaḥ iti
translated: This is stated in the scripture: Verily, when one is bodiless, neither pleasure nor pain touches him. (ChU 8.15.1)

analyzed: śarīre patite śarīra tvam syāt
translated: It might be argued that bodilessness occurs only after the body has fallen,

analyzed: na jīvate iti ced na
translated: not while one is alive. But that is not so.

analyzed: sa śarīra tvasya mithyā jñāna nimitta tvāt
translated: Because having a body is caused by false knowledge.

original: na hyātmanaḥ śarīrātmābhimānalakṣaṇaṃ mithyājñānaṃ muktvānyataḥ saśarīratvaṃ śakyaṃ kalpayitum /
analyzed: na hi ātmanaḥ śarīra ātma abhimāna lakṣaṇam mithyājñānam muktvā anyatas sa śarīra tvam śakyam kalpayitum
translated: For, apart from the false knowledge consisting in the notion of the Self being identical with the body, it is impossible to imagine that the Self is embodied.

analyzed: nityam aśarīra tvam akarma nimitta tvāt iti avocāma
translated: We have already said that the Self is eternally unembodied, because it is not the effect of any action.

analyzed: tad kṛta dharma adharma nimittam sa śarīra tvam iti ced na  śarīra saṃbandhasya asiddha tvāt dharma adharmayoḥ ātma kṛta tva asiddheḥ
translated: If it be said that embodiment is due to merit and demerit produced by the Self, we reply: No.🔽Because the connection with the body is not established, and because the merit and demerit are not established as produced by the Self.

analyzed: śarīra saṃbandhasya dharma adharmayoḥ tad kṛta tvasya ca itaretara āśraya tva prasaṅgāt andha paramparā eṣā anādi tva kalpanā
translated: And because the connection with the body and the production of merit and demerit by the Self would involve a mutual dependence, this hypothesis of beginninglessness is like the series of the blind.

analyzed: kriyā samavāya abhāvāt ca āmtanaḥ kartṛ tva anupapatteḥ
translated: And because the Self cannot be the agent, because there is no inherence of action in it.

analyzed: saṃnidhāna mātreṇa rāja prabhṛtīnām dṛṣṭam kartavyam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the agency of the king and others is seen to be due to mere presence, we reply: No.

analyzed: dhana dāna ādi upārjita bhṛtya saṃbandha tvāt teṣām kartṛ tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because their agency is possible on the ground of their connection with servants acquired by the bestowal of wealth, etc.

original: na tvātmano dhanadānādivaccharīrādibhiḥ svasvāmisaṃbandhanimittaṃ kiñcicchakyaṃ kalpayitum /
analyzed: na tu ātmanaḥ dhana dāna ādi vat śarīra ādibhiḥ sva svāmi saṃbandha nimittam kiñcid śakyam kalpayitum
translated: But in the case of the Self, it is not possible to imagine anything like the bestowal of wealth, etc., as the cause of the relation of master and servant with the body, etc.

analyzed: mithyā abhimānaḥ tu pratyakṣaḥ saṃbandha hetuḥ
translated: But the false notion is a directly perceived cause of the relation.

analyzed: etena yajamāna tvam ātmanaḥ vyākhyātam
translated: By this (verse) the fact of the Self being the sacrificer is explained.

original: atrāhuḥ dehādivyatiriktasyātmana ātmīye dehādāvabhimāno gauṇo na mithyeti cenna /
analyzed: atra āhuḥ deha ādi vyatiriktasya ātmanaḥ ātmīye deha ādau abhimānaḥ gauṇaḥ na mithyā iti ced na
translated: Here they say: If it is said that the figurative identification of the Self, which is distinct from the body etc., with what belongs to the Self, the body etc., is not false, but secondary, it is not so.

analyzed: prasiddha vastu bhedasya gauṇa tva mukhya tva prasiddheḥ
translated: Because secondary and primary usage are well-known only in the case of the difference of well-known objects.

analyzed: yasya hi prasiddhaḥ vastu bhedaḥ
translated: For one whose difference of objects is well-known,

original: yathā kesarādimānākṛtiviśeṣo 'nvayavyatirekābhyāṃ siṃhaśabdapratyayabhāṅmukhyo 'nyaḥ prasiddhaḥ tataścānyaḥ puruṣaḥ prāyikaiḥ krauryaśauryādibhiḥ
analyzed: yathā kesara ādi māna ākṛti viśeṣaḥ nvaya vyatirekābhyām siṃha śabda pratyaya bhāj mukhyaḥ prasiddhaḥ tatas ca anyaḥ puruṣaḥ prāyikaiḥ kraurya śaurya ādibhiḥ
translated: just as the particular form possessing manes etc., which is the primary basis of the word and concept 'lion' through positive and negative concomitance, is well-known to be different from that, and then another person is well-known to be endowed with the lion's qualities such as fierceness and courage,

analyzed: siṃha guṇaiḥ saṃpannaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: which are common to both.

original: tasya puruṣe siṃhaśabdapratyayau gauṇau bhavato nāprasiddhavastubhedasya /
analyzed: tasya puruṣe siṃha śabda pratyayau gauṇau bhavataḥ na aprasiddha vastu bhedasya
translated: The word and concept 'lion' with regard to that person are secondary, not in the case of one whose difference of objects is not well-known.

original: tasya tvanyatrānyaśabdapratyayau bhrāntinimittāveva bhavato na gauṇau /
analyzed: tasya tu anyatra anya śabda pratyayau bhrānti nimittau eva bhavataḥ na gauṇau
translated: But in the case of the application of the word and concept of one thing to another, they are only due to the cause of error, not secondary.🔽Just as in dim light, when the distinction is not apprehended, the word and concept 'man' refer to a post.

original: yathā mandāndhakāre sthāṇurayamityagṛhyamāṇaviśeṣe puruṣaśabdapratyayau sthāṇuviṣayau /🔽yathāvā śuktikāyāmakasmādrajatamiti niścitau śabdapratyayau /
analyzed: yathā manda andhakāre sthāṇuḥ ayam iti agṛhyamāṇa viśeṣe puruṣa śabda pratyayau sthāṇu viṣayau 🔽yathā vā śuktikāyām akasmāt rajatam iti niścitau śabda pratyayau
translated: Or just as the word and concept 'silver' are ascertained with regard to a shell.

original: tadvaddehādisaṃghāte 'hamiti nirupacāreṇa śabdapratyayāvātmānātmāvivekenotpadyamānau kathaṃ gauṇau śakyau vaditum /
analyzed: tadvat deha ādi saṃghāte ham iti nirupacāreṇa śabda pratyayau ātma anātma avivekena utpadyamānau katham gauṇau śakyau vaditum
translated: In the same way, when the notions of ‘I’ and ‘mine’ arise in regard to the aggregate of body, etc., in an unqualified manner, without any discrimination of the self and the not-self, how can they be said to be secondary?

original: ātmānātmavivekināmapi paṇḍitānāmajāvipālānāmivāviviktau śabdapratyayau bhavataḥ /🔽tasmāddehādivyatiriktātmāstitvavādināṃ dehādāvahaṃpratyayo mithyaiva na gauṇaḥ /
analyzed: ātma anātma vivekinām api paṇḍitānām aja avi pālānām iva a viviktau śabda pratyayau bhavataḥ  tasmāt deha ādi vyatirikta ātma astitva vādinām deha ādau ahaṃpratyayaḥ mithyā eva na gauṇaḥ
translated: Even for the wise who discriminate the self from the not-self, the verbal and mental notions do not arise without discrimination, like those of the ignorant.🔽Therefore, for those who assert the existence of the self separate from the body, etc., the notion of ‘I’ in regard to the body, etc. is false, not secondary.

analyzed: tasmāt mithyā pratyaya nimitta tvāt sa śarīra tvasya
translated: Therefore, because being embodied is the cause of false notions,

analyzed: siddham jīvataḥ pi viduṣaḥ śarīra tvam
translated: it is established that even a living person who knows Brahman is disembodied.

original: tathāca brahmavidviṣayā śrutiḥ ' tadyathāhinirlvayanī valmīke mṛtā pratyastā śayītaivamevedaṃ śarīraṃ śete /
analyzed: tathā ca brahma vid viṣayā śrutiḥ tat yathā ahi nirlvayanī valmīke mṛtā pratyastā śayīta evam eva idam śarīram śete
translated: And in this way, there is a Vedic text about one who knows Brahman: ‘Just as a snake’s slough, cast off from the head, lies in the anthill, so does this body lie.

original: athāyamaśarīro 'mṛtaḥ prāṇo brahmaiva teja eva' bṛha / / / iti /
analyzed: atha ayam aśarīraḥ mṛtaḥ prāṇaḥ brahma eva tejaḥ eva bṛhaḥ iti
translated: But this immortal breath, bodiless, is Brahman itself, pure light.’ (Br. U. 4.4.22)

original: 'sacakṣuracakṣuriva sakarṇo 'karṇa iva savāgavāgiva samanā amanā iva saprāṇo 'prāṇa iva' iti ca /
analyzed: sa cakṣuḥ a cakṣuḥ iva sa karṇo karṇaḥ iva sa vāc avāc iva sa manāḥ amanāḥ iva sa prāṇo prāṇaḥ iva iti ca
translated: ‘He has eyes, yet is as if eyeless; he has ears, yet is as if earless; he has speech, yet is as if speechless; he has mind, yet is as if mindless; he has breath, yet is as if breath-less.’ (Mu. U. 3.1.1)

analyzed: smṛtiḥ api ca sthita prajñasya akā bhāṣā bhagī
translated: And there is also a Smṛti text: ‘What is the speech of one whose wisdom is steady?’ (Bh. Gītā 2.54)

analyzed: ityādyā sthitaprajña lakṣaṇāni ācakṣāṇā viduṣaḥ sarva pravṛtti asaṃbandham darśayati
translated: Thus, in describing the characteristics of one whose mind is fixed in Brahman, the text shows that the wise man is not connected with any activity.

analyzed: tasmāt na avagata brahma ātma bhāvasya yathāpūrvam saṃsāri tvam
translated: Therefore, one who has realized Brahman as the Self does not continue to transmigrate as before.

original: yasya tu yathāpūrvaṃ saṃsāritvaṃ nāsāvavagatabrahmātmabhāva ityanavadyam /
analyzed: yasya tu yathāpūrvam saṃsāri tvam na asau avagata brahma ātma bhāvaḥ iti anavadyam
translated: But one who continues to transmigrate as before has not realized Brahman as the Self. This is faultless.

analyzed: yat punar uktam śravaṇāt parācīnayoḥ manana nididhyāsanayoḥ darśanāt vadhi śeṣa tvam brahmaṇaḥ na svarūpa paryavasāyi tvam iti na
translated: Again, it is said that Brahman is subsidiary to injunctions, not self-sufficient, because reflection and contemplation are seen to follow hearing. This is not so.

analyzed: avagati artha tvāt manana nididhyāsanayoḥ
translated: Because reflection and contemplation are for the purpose of understanding.

original: yadi hyavagataṃ brahmānyatra viniyujyeta bhavettadā vidhiśeṣitvam /
analyzed: yadi hi avagatam brahma anyatra viniyujyeta bhavet tadā vidhi śeṣi tvam
translated: If what is understood through Brahman were employed elsewhere, then it would be subsidiary to injunctions.

analyzed: na tu tat asti
translated: But that is not so.

analyzed: manana nididhyāsanayoḥ api śravaṇa vat avagati artha tvāt
translated: Because reflection and contemplation, like hearing, are for the purpose of understanding.

original: tasmānna pratapattividhiviṣayatayā śāstrapramāṇakatvaṃ brahmaṇaḥ saṃbhavatītyataḥ svatantrameva brahma śāstrapramāṇakaṃ vedāntavākyasamanvayāditi 🔽siddham /
analyzed: tasmāt na śāstra pramāṇaka tvam brahmaṇaḥ saṃbhavati iti atas svatantram eva brahma śāstra pramāṇakam vedānta vākya samanvayāt iti 🔽siddham
translated: Therefore, Brahman cannot be the subject of injunctions in the scriptures by being the content of injunctions. Hence it is established that Brahman, which is independent, is the subject of the scriptures through the harmony of the Vedanta texts.

original: evañca sati 'athāto brahmajijñāsā' iti tadviṣayaḥ pṛthakśāstramārambha upapadyate /
analyzed: evam ca sati atha atas brahma jijñāsā iti tad viṣayaḥ pṛthak śāstram ārambhaḥ upapadyate
translated: And this being so, the undertaking of a separate treatise on that subject is proper, beginning with the words, ‘Now, therefore, the desire to know Brahman.’

analyzed: pratipatti vidhi para tve hi atha atas dharma jijñāsā iti eva ārabdha tvāt na pṛthak śāstram ārabhyeta
translated: For if it were devoted to the injunction of practice, since it would have been begun already with the words, ‘Now, therefore, the desire to know religious duty,’ a separate treatise would not be begun.

original: ārabhyamāṇaṃ caivamārabhyeta 'athātaḥ pariśiṣṭadharmajijñāseti' ' athātaḥ kratvarthapuruṣārthayorjijñāsā' jai / / / itivat /
analyzed: ārabhyamāṇam ca evam ārabhyeta atha atas pariśiṣṭa dharma jijñāsā iti atha atas kratu artha puruṣa arthayoḥ jijñāsā itivat
translated: And if it were begun, it would be begun in this way: ‘Now, therefore, the desire to know the remaining religious duty.’ ‘Now, therefore, the desire to know what is for the purpose of the sacrifice and what is for the purpose of man.’ Jaimini

original: brahmātmaikyāvagatistvapratijñāteti tadartho yuktaḥ śāstrārambhaḥ 'athāto brahmajijñāsā' iti /
analyzed: brahma ātma aikya avagatiḥ tu apratijñātā iti tad arthaḥ yuktaḥ śāstra ārambhaḥ atha atas brahma jijñāsā iti
translated: But the knowledge of the identity of Brahman and the self is not a matter of promise, so it is proper to begin the treatise with the words, ‘Now, therefore, the desire to know Brahman,’ for that purpose.

original: tasmādahaṃ brahmāsmītyetadavasānā eva sarve viṣayaḥ sarvāṇi cetarāṇi pramāṇāni /
analyzed: tasmāt aham brahma asmi iti etad avasānāḥ eva sarve viṣayaḥ sarvāṇi ca itarāṇi pramāṇāni
translated: Therefore, all subjects and all other means of knowledge end with the conclusion ‘I am Brahman.’

analyzed: na hi aheya anupādeya advaita ātma avagatau nirviṣayāṇi apramātṛkāṇi ca pramāṇāni bhavitum arhanti iti
translated: For means of knowledge that have no object and no knower cannot be proper when the non-dual self, which is not to be rejected or accepted, is known.

analyzed: api ca āhuḥ gauṇa mithyā ātmanoḥ sattve putra deha ādi bādhanāt
translated: Moreover, they say: ‘If the secondary false self does not exist, because of the contradiction of son, body, etc.,

analyzed: sat brahma ātmā aham iti evam bodhe kāryam katham bhavet
translated: how can there be an effect of the knowledge “I am the real Brahman, the self” in that way?

analyzed: anveṣṭavya ātma vijñānāt prāk pramātṛ tvam ātmanaḥ
translated: Before the knowledge of the self, the self is the knower.

original: anviṣṭaḥ syātpramātaiva pāpmadoṣādivarjitaḥ //🔽dehātmapratyayo yadvatpramāṇatvena kalpitaḥ /🔽laukikaṃ tadvadevedaṃ pramāṇaṃ tvā'tmaniścayāt'
analyzed: anviṣṭaḥ syāt pramātā eva pāpma doṣa ādi varjitaḥ  deha ātma pratyayaḥ yadvat pramāṇa tvena kalpitaḥ  laukikam tadvat evā idam pramāṇam tu ātma niścayāt
translated: When the self is known, it becomes the knower, free from sin, faults, etc.🔽Just as the notion of the body being the self is accepted as valid,

analyzed: iti
translated: in the same way, this (scripture) is valid, due to the ascertainment of the self.

analyzed: iti catur sūtrī samāptā
translated: Thus ends the four-versed (text).

original: FN / pūrvapakṣiṇā kriyāśeṣatayā brahma pratipādyata ityuktaṃ tadvyāvṛttyarthamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: pūrvapakṣin kriyā śeṣa tā brahman pratipādyate iti uktam tad vyāvṛtti artha iti bhāva
translated: The opponent has said that Brahman is taught as a part of ritual. To exclude that, is the idea.

original: pūrṇatayā juhūdvārā kratuśeṣatāvādātmano 'pi jñānadvārā karmaśeṣatvāttadarthā vedāntāstadvidhiśeṣā bhaviṣyantītyāśaṅkyāha tatkeneti /
analyzed: pūrṇa tayā juhū dvārā kratu śeṣa tā vāda ātmanaḥ api jñāna dvārā karma śeṣa tvāt tad arthāḥ vedāntāḥ tad vidhi śeṣāḥ bhaviṣyanti iti āśaṅkya āha tat kena iti
translated: Because the self is taught as a part of the sacrifice through the Juhu, which is complete, it is a part of ritual through knowledge. Therefore, the Vedanta texts, which are for that purpose, will be parts of the injunctions about it. Fearing this, he says: By what?

original: pratipattikarma pradhānakarmaśeṣāṅgaṃ /🔽yatha pradhānacaruhomottaraṃ tenaiva dravyeṇa sviṣṭakṛdbalidānādi /
analyzed: pratipatti karma pradhāna karma śeṣa aṅgam  pradhāna caru homa uttaram tena eva dravyeṇa sviṣṭakṛt bali dāna ādi
translated: The ritual of understanding is a subsidiary part of the main ritual.🔽Just as after the main ritual of offering oblations of cooked rice, by that same substance, the offering of oblations to Svistakrit, etc.

original: yathāvā śrāddhe piṇḍapradānapūjottaraṃ piṇḍānāṃ gaṅgādipravāhe prakṣepaḥ /
analyzed: yathā vā śrāddhe piṇḍa pradāna pūjā uttaram piṇḍānām gaṅgā ādi pravāhe prakṣepaḥ
translated: Or just as after the offering of balls of rice and worship in a funeral ceremony, the balls of rice are thrown into the current of the Ganges, etc.

analyzed: saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The non-connection is the non-entry.

analyzed: pratipatteḥ vidhiḥ niyogaḥ tasya viṣaya bhūtām pratipatti pratyavacchedaka tvema viṣayatayā iti arthaḥ
translated: The injunction is the rule of practice. Its object is the exclusion of the understanding of the object, which is the object of the injunction.

analyzed: agni ādi devatā uddeśena puroḍāśa ādi dravya utsargaḥ yāgaḥ
translated: Sacrifice is the offering of substances like the sacrificial cake with the deity Agni as the recipient.

analyzed: aśarīram videham
translated: Without a body, bodiless.

analyzed: priya apriye sukha duḥkhe  kṛta a kṛtāt iti
translated: Pleasure and pain are happiness and sorrow.🔽From the done and the undone.

analyzed: kṛtāt kāryāt
translated: From the done, the effect.

analyzed: akṛtāt kāraṇāt
translated: From the undone, the cause.

analyzed: tat brahma avet viditavat
translated: That Brahman knew, it knew.

original: valkalādivaccittarañjako rāgādikaṣāyo mṛditaḥ kṣālitaḥ vināśito yasya jñānavairāgyābhyāsakṣārajalena tasmai /
analyzed: valkala ādi vat citta rañjakaḥ rāga ādi kaṣāyaḥ mṛditaḥ kṣālitaḥ vināśitaḥ yasya jñāna vairāgya abhyāsa kṣāra jalena tasmai
translated: To him who has washed away, destroyed, the dye of passion etc. which colors the mind like the bark of a tree, with the alkaline water of the practice of knowledge and detachment.

analyzed: adhyāsaḥ tasmin tad dhīḥ

analyzed: ādeśaḥ upadeśaḥ  pralaya kāle vāyuḥ agni ādīn saṃvṛṇoti saṃharati iti saṃvargaḥ
translated: Ādeśa is instruction.🔽At the time of dissolution, Vāyu (air) covers, i.e., withdraws, Agni (fire) and others. Thus, it is Saṃvarga.

analyzed: svāpa kāle prāṇaḥ vāc ādīn saṃharati iti saṃhāra kriyā yogāt saṃvargaḥ
translated: At the time of sleep, Prāṇa (vital air) withdraws Vāg (speech) and others. Thus, it is Saṃvarga due to the association with the act of withdrawal.

analyzed: tat viditāt jñāna viṣayāt anyat bhinnam
translated: That is different from the known, the object of knowledge.

analyzed: atha u api aviditāt ajñāna viṣayāt api adhi anyat
translated: Moreover, there is something else beyond the unknown, the object of ignorance.

analyzed: yat vācā śabdena an abhyuditam a prakāśitam
translated: Or, that which is not manifested, not illuminated, by speech, by sound.

analyzed: yena bhmaṇā sā vāc abhyadyate prakāśyate
translated: By which power that speech is illuminated, is manifested.

analyzed: nivṛtti viṣaya tvāt bhāpā
translated: Because it has non-cessation as its object.

original: svātmano dharmānāśrayatve 'pi nityo dharmo mokṣākhyo bhaviṣyatītyabhiprāyeṇa dharmaśabdaḥ /
analyzed: svātmanaḥ dharma anāśraya tve pi nityaḥ dharmaḥ mokṣa ākhyaḥ bhaviṣyati iti abhiprāyeṇa dharma śabdaḥ
translated: Even though the Self is not the substratum of its own attributes, the attribute called Liberation will be eternal. With this intention, the word 'dharma' is used.

analyzed: sva rūpa paraḥ vā

analyzed: anyaḥ jīva ātmā

analyzed: pippalam karma phalam
translated: The fruit of action is the morsel.

analyzed: abhicākaśīti prakāśate

The overseer of action is the bestower of the fruits of action.

analyzed: śukram iti bāhya aśuddhi virahaḥ uktaḥ
translated: The word 'pure' indicates the absence of external impurity.

analyzed: avraṇam asnāviram iti eva kāya niṣedhe siddhe punar tad niṣedhaḥ līlā dhṛta viṣaṇu ādi vigrahasya api anṛta tā pratipādana arthaḥ
translated: When the negation of the body is established by the negation of 'without wound' and 'without fat', the repetition of that negation is for the purpose of showing that even the unreal incarnations like Visnu are not true.

original: tathāca 'māyā hyeṣā mayā sṛṣṭā yanmāṃ paśyasi nārada /
analyzed: tathā ca  māyā hi eṣā mayā sṛṣṭā yat mām paśyasi nārada
translated: And thus: 'This illusion, O Narada, is created by me, by which you see me.

analyzed: sarva bhūta guṇaiḥ yuktam mā evam mām draṣṭum arhasi ti

analyzed: śarīra upādāna bhūta avidyā rāhityāya śuddham iti

analyzed: tad nimitta rāhityāya a pāpa viddham iti

analyzed: atra anupraveśaḥ saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Here, 'anu-pra-vis' means connection.

analyzed: mayā idam kāryam iti avagatimān hi niyojyaḥ bhavati
translated: For one who understands 'this work is to be done by me' becomes one who is enjoined.

analyzed: kṛti sādhyaḥ ca vidhi viṣayaḥ bhavati

analyzed: jñānasya ca kṛtya sādhya tvāt na ubhayam ātma jñānam bhavati iti bhāvaḥ

analyzed: vidhi chāyāni prasiddha yāga ādi vidhi tulyāni

analyzed: kṛtam kṛtyam prāpaṇīyam prāptam iti eva tuṣyati pañca
translated: But he is satisfied with the thought, What was to be done has been done, what was to be attained has been attained, - thus he is contented. (Panchasikha)

analyzed: anusaṃjvaret śarīram paritapyamānam anutapyeta
translated: He should burn with the body that is burning.

original: pramāpramārūpadhīmātraviṣayaḥ pratipattiśabdaḥ / ā / /🔽'yaccāpnoti yadādatte yaccātti viṣayāniha /
analyzed: yat ca āpnoti yat ādatte yat ca atti viṣayān iha
translated: The word 'pratipatti' (realization) refers to the mere cognition of valid and invalid knowledge. (Acharya)🔽What one obtains, what one takes up, what one enjoys here as objects,

translated: and what is his continuous existence, for that reason he is called the self. (Chandogya Upanishad 8.7.1)🔽 The person taught in the Upanishads is the object of the notion of 'I'.

analyzed: ahaṃpratyaya viṣayaḥ yaḥ kartā kārya karaṇa saṃghāta upahitaḥ jīvātmā tad vyatirekeṇa

analyzed: vidhi anupraveśaḥ vidhi saṃbandhaḥ

analyzed: kūṭasthasya kṛtya yogāt na kartṛ tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the immutable one does not have agency due to the absence of connection with action.

analyzed: śabdaḥ śābda vodhaḥ ca iti arthaḥ
