analyzed: yat ca gati sāmānyāt iti acetana kāraṇa nirākaraṇam uktam tat api vākya antarāṇi brahma viṣayāṇi vyācakṣāṇena brahma viparīta kāraṇa niṣedhena prapañcyate
translated: And the refutation of an unconscious cause stated in the passage, because of the similarity of the course, is also elaborated by the author, while commenting on other passages referring to Brahman, by the denial of a cause which is the opposite of Brahman.

analyzed: ānanda mayaḥ bhyāsāt
translated: The Self consisting of bliss is Brahman on account of the repetition.

analyzed: taittirīyake nna mayam
translated: In the Taittiriya Upanishad, after having enumerated the Self consisting of food,

analyzed: prāṇa mayam
translated: the Self consisting of breath,

analyzed: manaḥ mayam
translated: the Self consisting of mind,

analyzed: vijñāna mayam  ca anukramya āmnāyate tasmāt vai etasmāt vijñāna mayāt
translated: and the Self consisting of knowledge,

analyzed: anyaḥ ntaraḥ ātmā ānanda mayaḥ te iti
translated: it is declared, Therefore, different from this Self consisting of knowledge, there is another inner Self consisting of bliss.

original: tatra saṃśayaḥ kimihānandamayaśabdena parameva brahmocyate yatprakṛtam 'satyaṃ jñānamanantaṃ brahma' tai / /
analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ kim iha ānanda maya śabdena param eva brahma ucyate yat prakṛtam satyam jñānam anantam brahma
translated: Here there is a doubt whether in this passage the word consisting of bliss denotes Brahman itself, which is the subject of the chapter, That Brahman is Truth, Knowledge, and Infinite,

analyzed: iti kiṃvā anna maya ādi brahmaṇā ūrtha antaram iti
translated: or whether it denotes something different from Brahman, consisting of food, etc.

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam brahmaṇā ūrtha antaram amukhyaḥ ātmā ānanda mayaḥ syāt
translated: What is the prima facie view? The Self consisting of bliss, which is different from Brahman, is not the principal Self.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: anna maya ādya mukhya ātma pravāha patita tvāt
translated: because it falls within the series of the not-so-important Selfs beginning with the one consisting of food.

analyzed: atha api syāt sarva antara tvāt ānanda mayaḥ mukhyaḥ eva ātmā iti
translated: Now, it may be argued that the Self consisting of bliss is the principal one, because it is the innermost of all.

analyzed: na syāt priya ādi avayava yogāt śarīra tva śravaṇāt ca
translated: This is not so, because of the connection with the parts such as the dear one, and because of the declaration of its being the body.

analyzed: mukhyaḥ ced ātmā ānanda mayaḥ syāt na priya ādi saṃsparśaḥ syāt
translated: If the Self consisting of bliss were the principal Self, there would be no contact with the dear one, etc.

original: iha tu 'tasya priyameva śiraḥ' ityādi śrūyate /🔽śārīratvaṃ ca śrūyate 'tasyaiṣa eva śārīra ātmā /
analyzed: iha tu tasya priyam eva śiraḥ ityādi śrūyate  śārīra tvam ca śrūyate tasya eṣaḥ eva śārīraḥ ātmā
translated: But here it is heard: ‘Its head is the dear one,’ etc.

analyzed: yaḥ pūrvasya iti
translated: And its being the body is heard: ‘This very Self consisting of food is the body of the former one.’

original: tasya pūrvasya vijñānamayasyaiṣa eva śārīra ātmā ya eṣa ānandamaya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tasya pūrvasya vijñāna mayasya eṣaḥ eva śārīraḥ ātmā yaḥ eṣaḥ ānanda mayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: this very Self consisting of food is the body of the former one consisting of knowledge, who is the same as the one consisting of bliss.

original: naca saśarīrasya sataḥ priyāpriyasaṃspārśo vārayituṃ śakyaḥ /
analyzed: na ca sa śarīrasya sataḥ priya apriya saṃspārśaḥ vārayitum śakyaḥ
translated: And for one who has a body, contact with the dear and the not-dear cannot be prevented.

analyzed: tasmāt saṃsārī eva ānanda mayaḥ ātmā iti avam prāptaḥ idam ucyate ānanda mayaḥ bhyāsāt
translated: Therefore, it is concluded that the Self consisting of bliss is the transmigrating one. To this, it is said: ‘The Self consisting of bliss, by repetition.’

analyzed: paraḥ eva ātmā ānanda mayaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: The Supreme Self alone should be the one consisting of bliss.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: abhyāsāt
translated: By repetition.

analyzed: parasmin eva hi ātmani ānanda śabdaḥ bahu kṛtvas bhyasyate
translated: For the word ‘bliss’ is repeated many times only in reference to the Supreme Self.

original: ānandamayaṃ prastutya 'raso vai saḥ' iti tasyaiva rasatvamuktvocyate 'rasaṃhyevāyaṃ labdhvā'nandī bhavati' iti /
analyzed: ānanda mayam prastutya rasaḥ vai saḥ iti tasya eva rasa tvam uktvā ucyate rasam hi eva ayam labdhvā ānandī bhavati iti
translated: Having introduced the topic of the Self consisting of bliss, after declaring that it is the essence of bliss, it is said: 'For, having obtained that essence, one becomes blissful.'

analyzed: kaḥ hi eva anyāt kaḥ prāṇyāt
translated: 'Who would breathe after another? Who would breathe before another?

analyzed: yat eṣaḥ ākāśaḥ ānandaḥ na syāt
translated: If this space were not bliss,

analyzed: eṣa hi eva ānandayāti  taiḥ sā eṣā ānandasya mīmāṃsā bhavati
translated: for it is he who makes one blissful.'🔽'This is the investigation of bliss.'

analyzed: etam ānanda mayam ātmānam upasaṃkrāmati
translated: 'He approaches this Self consisting of bliss.'

original: 'ānandaṃ brahmaṇo vidvān na bibheti kutaścana' tai / / / iti /
analyzed: ānandam brahmaṇaḥ vidvān na bibheti kutaścana taiḥ iti
translated: 'Knowing bliss to be Brahman, one is not afraid of anything.'

analyzed: ānandaḥ brahma iti vyajānāt tai iti ca
translated: 'He knew that bliss is Brahman.'

analyzed: śruti antare ca vijñānam ānandam brahma
translated: And in another Upanishad, 'Brahman is knowledge and bliss.'

analyzed: iti brahmaṇi eva ānanda śabdaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: Thus, the word 'bliss' is seen to refer to Brahman.

original: evamānandaśabdasya bahukṛtvo brahmaṇyabhyāsādānandamaya ātmā brahmeti gamyate /
analyzed: evam ānanda śabdasya bahu kṛtvas brahmaṇi abhyāsāt ānanda mayaḥ ātmā brahma iti gamyate
translated: In this way, it is understood that the Self consisting of bliss is Brahman, because the word 'bliss' is repeatedly used in reference to Brahman.

analyzed: yat tu uktam anna maya ādi amukhya ātma pravāha patita tvāt ānanda mayasya api amukhya tvam iti
translated: As for what was said - that the Self consisting of bliss is not primary because it falls within the sequence of the not primary Selfs beginning with the one consisting of food,

analyzed: na asau doṣaḥ
translated: that is not a fault.

analyzed: ānanda mayasya sarva antara tvāt
translated: Because the Self consisting of bliss is the innermost.

analyzed: mukhyam eva hi ātmānam upadidikṣu śāstram loka buddhim anusarat
translated: For the scriptures, when they wish to teach the principal Self, follow the understanding of the world.

analyzed: anna mayam śarīram anātmānam atyanta mūḍhānām ātma tvena prasiddham anūdya mūṣā niṣikta druta tāmra ādi pratimā vat tatas
translated: Having mentioned the food-made body, which is not the Self but is well-known to the most ignorant as the Self, like an image cast from molten bronze, etc.,

analyzed: nantaram tatas ntaram iti evam pūrveṇa pūrveṇa samānam uttaram uttaram anātmānam ātmā iti grāhayat
translated: and then the next one, and the next one after that, in the same way as the preceding one, it makes one understand that each subsequent one is not the Self but the Self.

analyzed: pratipatti saukarya apekṣayā sarva antaram mukhyam ānanda mayam ātmānam upadideśa iti śliṣṭataram
translated: With regard to the ease of understanding, it is more appropriate that it teaches the principal Self, which is the innermost, consisting of bliss.

original: yathārundhatīnidarśane barhvīṣvapi tārāsvamukhyāsvarundhatīṣu darśitāsu yāntyā pradarśyate sā mukhyaivārundhatī bhavati /
analyzed: yathā arundhatīnidarśane barhvīṣu api tārāsu amukhyāsu arundhatīṣu darśitāsu yāntyā pradarśyate sā mukhyā eva arundhatī bhavati
translated: Just as in the teaching of Arundhati, even though many other stars are shown, which are not the principal Arundhati, the one that is shown as the last is the principal Arundhati.

analyzed: evam iha api ānanda mayasya sarva antara tvāt mukhyam ātma tvam
translated: In the same way, here also, because the one consisting of bliss is the innermost, it is the principal Self.

analyzed: yat tu brūṣe  priya ādīnām śiraḥ tva ādi kalpanā anupapannā mukhyasya ātmanaḥ iti
translated: But what you say,🔽that the postulating of the head, etc. of the principal Self is not possible,

analyzed: ātīta anantara upādhi janitā sā na svābhāvikī iti adoṣaḥ
translated: that is not due to its own nature, but is produced by the immediately preceding limiting adjunct, so it is not a fault.

analyzed: śārīra tvam api ānanda mayasya anna maya ādi śarīra paramparayā pradarśyamāna tvāt
translated: The state of being embodied also belongs to the Self consisting of bliss, because it is shown as a series of bodies beginning with the one consisting of food.

analyzed: na punar sākṣāt eva śārīra tvam saṃsāri vat
translated: But it is not direct embodiment like the transmigrating individual soul.

analyzed: tasmāt āndamayaḥ paraḥ eva ātmā
translated: Therefore, the Self consisting of bliss is the Supreme Self itself.

analyzed: tasya niṣkala tva śrutyā niraṃśa tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is partless because of the scriptural statement of its being without parts.

analyzed: kovānyāt calet
translated: Who else would move away?

analyzed: kaḥ vā viśiṣya prāṇyāt jīvet
translated: Or who would live, excelling others?

analyzed: ānandayāti ānandayati iti arthaḥ
translated: Ānandayati means it delights.

analyzed: upasaṃkramaṇam prāptiḥ brahmaṇaḥ svarūpam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Upasampraṇa is attainment. The nature of Brahman is the remainder.

analyzed: loka buddheḥ sthūla grāhitām anusarat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it follows the gross grasping of worldly understanding.

analyzed: iha api amukhya pravāhe patitasya api
translated: Even one who has fallen into the secondary current here.

analyzed: vṛtta anuvādena uttara sūtra saṃdarbham ākṣipati janmāt iti
translated: By stating the topic, he raises the context of the subsequent aphorisms - janmādyasya yataḥ (1.1).

analyzed: prathama sūtrasya śāstra upodghāta tvāt janma ādi sūtram ārabhya iti uktam
translated: Since the first aphorism is the introduction to the scripture, it is said starting from the aphorism on birth, etc. (1.1).

original: sarvavedāntānāṃ kārye pradhānādyacetane ca samanvayanirāsena brahmaparatvaṃ vyākhyātam /
analyzed: sarva vedāntānām kārye pradhāna ādi acetane ca samanvaya nirāsena brahma paratvam vyākhyātam
translated: The supremacy of Brahman has been explained by negating the agreement of all Vedāntas with non-intelligent pradhāna etc. in the effect.

analyzed: atas prathama adhyāya arthasya asamāpta tvāt uttara grantha ārambhe kim kāraṇam iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, since the meaning of the first chapter is complete, the meaning is what is the reason for beginning the subsequent text.

analyzed: vedānteṣu sa guṇa nirguṇa brahma vākyānām bahulam upalabdheḥ
translated: Because in the Vedanta texts, statements about Brahman with and without qualities are frequently found.

original: tatra kasya vākyasya saguṇopāsanāvidhidvārā niguṇe samanvayaḥ kasya vā guṇavivakṣāṃ vinā sākṣādeva brahmaṇi samanvaya ityākāṅkṣaiva kāraṇamityāhaucyata
analyzed: tatra kasya vākyasya saguṇa upāsanā vidhi dvārā samanvayaḥ kasya vā guṇa vivakṣām vinā sākṣāt eva brahmaṇi samanvayaḥ iti ākāṅkṣā eva kāraṇam iti āha ucyata
translated: There, the question arises: By what statement is there a connection with the qualityless through the injunction of meditation with qualities, and by what statement is there a direct connection with Brahman without the mention of qualities? The reason is just this question, he says it is said.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: saṃkṣipya sa guṇa nirguṇa vākya artham āha dvirūpam hi iti
translated: Having summarized the meaning of the statements with and without qualities, he says Indeed, of two forms.

analyzed: nāma rūpa ātmakaḥ vikāraḥ sarvam jagat
translated: The entire world is modification consisting of name and form.

analyzed: tad bhedaḥ hiraṇya śmaśru tva ādi viśeṣaḥ iti vākya arthaḥ
translated: The difference in that is the particularity of Hiranyagarbha, Ashvin etc. This is the meaning of the statement.

analyzed: vākyān udāharati yatra hi ityādinā
translated: He cites the statement beginning with where.

original: yasyāṃ khalvajñānāvasthāyāṃ dvaitamiva kalpitaṃ bhavati tattadetaraḥ sannitaraṃ paśyatīti dṛśyopādhikaṃ vastu bhāti /
analyzed: yasyām khalu ajñāna avasthāyām dvaitam iva kalpitam bhavati tat tadā itaraḥ san itaram paśyati iti dṛśya upādhikam vastu bhāti
translated: In that state of ignorance, indeed, duality appears as if imagined. He, being different, sees another. Thus, the object with the superimposition of the seen appears.

original: yatra jñānakāle viduṣaḥ sarvaṃ jagadātmamātramabhūttattadā tu kena kaṃ paśyedityākṣepānnirupādhikaṃ tattvaṃ bhāti /
analyzed: yatra jñāna kāle viduṣaḥ sarvam jagat ātma mātram abhūt tat tadā tu kena kam paśyet iti ākṣepāt nirupādhikam tattvam bhāti
translated: When, at the time of knowledge, for the knower, the entire world becomes only the Self, then by the objection By whom and whom does one see?, the reality without superimposition appears.

original: yatra bhumni niścito vidvān dvitīyaṃ kimapi na vetti so 'dvitīyo bhūmā paramātmā nirguṇaḥ /
analyzed: yatra bhumni niścitaḥ vidvān dvitīyam kim api na vetti saḥ dvitīyaḥ bhūmā paramātmā nirguṇaḥ
translated: Where the wise one, being certain on that ground, does not know a second thing, that is the non-dual ground, the supreme self, the attributeless one.

analyzed: atha nirguṇa ukti anantaram saguṇam ucyate
translated: Now, after the mention of the attributeless, the one with attributes is mentioned.

original: yatra saguṇe sthito dvitīyaṃ vetti tadalpaṃ paricchinnaṃ /
analyzed: yatra saguṇe sthitaḥ dvitīyam vetti tat alpam paricchinnam
translated: Where, being situated in the one with attributes, one knows a second, that is small, limited.

analyzed: yaḥ tu bhūmā tat amṛtam nityam
translated: But that which is the ground is immortal, eternal.

analyzed: atha iti
translated: Now, then.

analyzed: pūrvavat vyākhyeyam
translated: It should be explained as before.

original: dhīraḥ paramātmaiva sarvāṇi rūpāṇi vicitya sṛṣṭvā nāmāni ca kṛtvā buddhyādau praviśya jīvasaṃjño vyavaharanyo vartate sa saguṇastaṃ nirguṇatvena
analyzed: dhīraḥ paramātmā eva sarvāṇi rūpāṇi vicitya sṛṣṭvā nāmāni ca kṛtvā buddhi ādau praviśya jīva saṃjñaḥ vyavaharan yaḥ vartate sa sa guṇaḥ tam nirguṇa tvena
translated: The wise one, the supreme self itself, having created all forms and made names, having entered into intellect etc., existing as the one called jiva, engaged in worldly activities, is the one with attributes. The knower of that as attributeless

analyzed: vidvān api amṛtaḥ bhavati
translated: becomes immortal.

analyzed: nirgatāḥ kalāḥ aṃśāḥ yasmāt tat niṣkalam
translated: That from which the parts, the portions, have gone out is the partless.

analyzed: atas niraṃśa tvāt niṣkriyam
translated: Therefore, being partless, it is actionless.

analyzed: atas śāntam apariṇāmi
translated: Therefore, it is peaceful, unchanging.

analyzed: niravadyam rāga ādi doṣa śūnyam
translated: It is faultless, devoid of faults like attachment.

original: añjanaṃ mūlatamaḥsaṃbandho dharmādikaṃ vā tacchūnyaṃ nirañjanam /
analyzed: añjanam mūla tamaḥ saṃbandhaḥ dharma ādikam vā tat śūnyam nirañjanam
translated: It is free from defilement, devoid of defilement, which is the connection with the root darkness or with dharma etc.

original: kiñcāmṛtasya mokṣasya svayameva vākyotthavṛttisthatvena paramutkṛṣṭaṃ setuṃ laukikasetuvatprāpakam /

translated: Moreover, it is the supreme bridge, the best means of attaining, like a worldly bridge, to immortality, to liberation, by being itself present in the commentary arising from the text.

original: yathā dagdhendhano 'nalaḥ śāmyati tamivāvidyāṃ tajjaṃ ca dagdhvā praśāntaṃ nirguṇamātmānaṃ vidyādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā dagdha indhanaḥ nalaḥ śāmyati tam iva avidyām tad jam ca dagdhvā praśāntam nirguṇam ātmānam vidyāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that one should know the Self, which is tranquil, free from qualities, after burning ignorance and what is produced by it, like a fire goes out after burning the fuel.

analyzed: na iti na iti iti
translated: Not so, not so.

analyzed: vyākhyātam
translated: This has been explained.

analyzed: sthūla ādi dvaita śūnyam  rūpa dvaye śrutim āha nyūnam iti
translated: It is devoid of the duality of grossness etc.🔽The text is quoted in the two forms, the inferior one.

analyzed: dvaita sthānam nyūnam alpam sa guṇa rūpam nirguṇāt anyat
translated: The inferior, lesser, qualified form is different from the unqualified.

analyzed: tathā saṃpūrṇam nirguṇam sa guṇāt anyat iti arthaḥ
translated: Similarly, the complete, unqualified is different from the qualified. This is the meaning.

analyzed: ekasya dvi rūpa tvam viruddham iti atas āha vidyā iti
translated: Since it is contradictory for one to have two forms, it is said: by knowledge etc.

original: vidyāviṣayo jñeyaṃ nirguṇatvaṃ satyaṃ avidyāviṣaya upāsyaṃ saguṇatvaṃ kalpitamityavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: vidyā viṣayaḥ jñeyam nirguṇa tvam satyam avidyā viṣayaḥ upāsyam sa guṇa tvam kalpitam iti avirodhaḥ
translated: The object of knowledge, the truth of the unqualified nature, is real. The object of meditation, the qualified nature, is imagined. Thus there is no contradiction.

analyzed: tatra avidyā viṣayam vivṛṇoti tatra iti
translated: There, in that, he explains the object of ignorance.

analyzed: nirguṇa jñāna artham āropita prapañcam āśritya bādhāt prāc kāle guḍajihvikā nyāyena tad tad phala arthāni upāsanāni vidhīyante
translated: For the sake of knowledge of the unqualified, depending on the superimposed world, the meditations are enjoined at the time before refutation, like the molasses-licking method, for the sake of each fruit.

original: teṣāṃ cittaikāgryadvārā jñānaṃ mukhyaṃ phalamiti tadvākyānāmapi mahātātparyaṃ brahmaṇīti mantavyam /
analyzed: teṣām citta aikāgrya dvārā jñānam mukhyam phalam iti tad vākyānām api mahā tātparyam brahmaṇi iti mantavyam
translated: And their primary fruit is knowledge through one-pointedness of mind. Thus, the great purport of those statements should be understood to be Brahman.

analyzed: nāma brahma etyādi upāstīnām kāma ācāra ādiḥ abhyudayaḥ phalam
translated: The results of the meditations beginning with 'Name is Brahman' are prosperity etc. consisting of the fulfillment of desires.

analyzed: dahara ādi upāstīnām kāma ācāra ādiḥ abhyudayaḥ phalam
translated: The results of the meditations beginning with the small ether are gradual liberation.

analyzed: udbhītha ādi dhyānasya karma samṛddhiḥ phalam iti bhedaḥ
translated: The result of the meditation on Udbhid etc. is the prosperity of actions. Thus there is a difference.

analyzed: dhyānānām mānasa tvāt
translated: Because the meditations are mental.

analyzed: jñāna antaraṅga tvāt ca
translated: And because they are more internal to knowledge.

analyzed: jñāna kāṇḍe vidhānam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the injunction is in the section on knowledge.

analyzed: nanu upāsya brahmaṇaḥ eka tvāt katham upāsanānām bhedaḥ
translated: But how can there be a difference in the meditations if the Brahman to be meditated upon is one?

analyzed: tatra āha teṣām iti
translated: To that he says 'among them'.

analyzed: guṇa viśeṣāḥ satya kāma tva ādayaḥ
translated: The special qualities are having true desires etc.

analyzed: hṛdaya ādiḥ upādhiḥ
translated: The heart etc. are the limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: atra svayam eva āśaṅkya pariharati ekaḥ iti
translated: Here he himself raises the doubt and answers it with 'one'.

original: paramātmasvarūpābhede 'pyupādhibhedenopahitopāsyarūpabhedādupāsananāṃ bhede sati phalabheda iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: paramātma svarūpa abhede pi upādhi bhedena upahita upāsya rūpa bhedāt upāsananām bhede sati phala bhedaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that even when there is no difference in the nature of the supreme self, there is a difference in the results of the meditations when there is a difference in the nature of the meditated upon, which is limited by the difference in the limiting adjuncts.

original: taṃ paramātmānaṃ yadyadguṇatvena lokā rājānamivopāsate tattadguṇavatvameva teṣāṃ phalaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tam paramātmānam yad yad guṇa tvena lokāḥ rājānam iva upāsate tat tad guṇavat tvam eva teṣām phalam bhavati
translated: Whatever qualities they meditate upon the supreme self as having, like a king, that very quality becomes their result.

analyzed: kratuḥ saṃkalpaḥ dhyānam
translated: Kratu is resolve, meditation.

original: iha yādṛśadhyānavān bhavati mṛtvā tādṛśopāsyarūpo bhavati /
analyzed: iha yādṛśa dhyānavān bhavati mṛtvā tādṛśa upāsya rūpaḥ bhavati
translated: Here, one becomes like the object of meditation after death.

original: anirukte nikṛṣyocyanta iti niruktāni bhūtasūkṣmāṇi taiścābhedavarjite /
analyzed: anirukte nikṛṣya ucyante iti niruktāni bhūta sūkṣmāṇi taiḥ ca abheda varjite
translated: The subtle elements are called 'nirukta' because they are spoken of after being extracted from the unmanifest. And it is devoid of identity with them.

analyzed: niḥśeṣa laya sthānam nilayanam māyā tad śūnye
translated: The abode is the place of complete dissolution, which is empty of that Maya.

original: udaramiti ut api aramalpam antaraṃ bhedam /
analyzed: udaram iti u t api aram alpam antaram bhedam
translated: The belly is that which has no internal difference, even though it is above the belly.

analyzed: ānanda mayāt tu iti brahmaṇya antara tvam aśrutam puccha tvam tu śrutam iti arthaḥ
translated: But from the one consisting of bliss, the state of being within Brahman is not heard, but the state of being the tail is heard. This is the meaning.

analyzed: puccham iti ādhāra tva mātram pratiṣṭhā iti
translated: The tail is merely the support, and the abode is the foundation.

analyzed: eka nīḍam adhiṣṭhānam sa upādānasya jagataḥ
translated: The single nest is the basis of the world with its cause.

original: yato yasmāt vācaḥ śaktivṛttyā tamaprakāśyaiva nivartante /
analyzed: yatas yasmāt vācaḥ śakti vṛttyā tam a prakāśya eva nivartante
translated: From which, or from whom, the words turn back even without revealing him by the functioning of their power.

analyzed: pratiyogī virodhī tasya ātmatvam apekṣate
translated: The opposite, the contradictory, requires the state of being the self of that.

analyzed: yathā vipra mayaḥ grāmaḥ iti atra śūdra alpa tvam
translated: Just as in the sentence the village is full of Brahmins, there is the state of being few Shudras.

analyzed: upakramaṇam bādhaḥ
translated: The beginning is contradicted.

analyzed: upasaṃkrati mitavyānām vivekena tyājyānām  prāya āpattiḥ avayava kramasya buddhau prāptiḥ
translated: Of those to be approached, which are to be abandoned separately.🔽The conclusion is the attainment in the mind of the sequence of parts.

original: asminniti viṣayasaptamī ānandamayaviṣayakaprabodhavato jīvasya tadyogaṃ yasmācchāsti tasmānna pradhānamiti yojanā /
analyzed: asmin iti viṣaya saptamī ānanda maya viṣayaka prabodhavataḥ jīvasya tad yogam yasmāt śāsti tasmāt na pradhānam iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: because it teaches the connection of the living being who has the knowledge of the one consisting of bliss with that, therefore the primordial matter is not so.

analyzed: jīvasya pradhāna yogaḥ u pi asti iti atas āha tad ātmanā iti
translated: The individual soul also has a connection with the primordial matter, so it is said for the Self of that.

analyzed: jīvasya jīva abhedaḥ sti iti atas āha muktiḥ iti
translated: The individual soul is not different from the individual soul, so it is said liberation.

analyzed: adṛśye sthūla prapañca śūnye
translated: In the invisible, devoid of the gross manifold.

analyzed: ātma saṃbandham ātmātmyam liṅga śarīram tad rahite
translated: The state of being the Self, the subtle body, devoid of that.

analyzed: niruktam śabda śakyam tad bhinne
translated: Different from the denotable, the possible object of words.

analyzed: niḥśeṣa laya sthānam nilayanam māyā tat śūnye brahmaṇi
translated: The abode of complete dissolution, the abode, Maya, devoid of that in Brahman.

original: abhayaṃ yathā syattathā yadaiva pratiṣṭhāṃ manasaḥ prakṛṣṭāṃ vṛttimeṣa vidvāṃllabhate atha tadaivābhayaṃ brahma prāpnotītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: abhayam yathā syat tathā yadā eva pratiṣṭhām manasaḥ prakṛṣṭām vṛttim eṣa vidvān labhate atha tadā eva abhayam brahma prāpnoti iti arthaḥ
translated: As to how there may be fearlessness, when this learned one attains the excellent state of the mind, then at that very time he attains the fearless Brahman. This is the meaning.

original: ut api aramalpamapyantaraṃ bhedaṃ yadaivaiṣa naraḥ paśyati atha tadā tasya bhayamiti yojanā iti /
analyzed: api aram alpam api antaram bhedam yadā eva eṣa naraḥ paśyati atha tadā tasya bhayam iti yojanā iti
translated: When this man sees even the slightest difference, then at that time he has fear. This is the construction.

analyzed: vṛtti kāra matam dūṣayati idam tu iti
translated: He refutes the opinion of the commentator: But this.

original: iha paravyākhyāyāṃ vikārārthake mayaṭibuddhisthe satyakasmātkāraṇaṃ vinā ekaprakaraṇasthasya mayaṭaḥ pūrvaṃ vikārārthakatvaṃ /
analyzed: iha para vyākhyāyām vikāra arthake mayaṭ i buddhi sthe sati akasmāt kāraṇam vinā eka prakaraṇa sthasya mayaṭaḥ pūrvam vikāra arthaka tvam
translated: Here, in the explanation of others, when the suffix maya, which means modification, is well-known, suddenly, without reason, the suffix maya, occurring in the same context, has the meaning of modification first.

original: ante prācuryārthakatvamityardhajaratīyaṃ kathamiva kena dṛṣṭāntenāśrīyata itīdaṃ vaktavyamityanvayaḥ /
analyzed: ante prācurya arthaka tvam iti ardhajaratīyam katham iva kena dṛṣṭāntena āśrīyate iti idam vaktavyam iti anvayaḥ
translated: It remains to be said by what example this is to be accepted, that the meaning of the suffix maya is secondary, and that of the suffix tva is primary.

analyzed: praśnam matvā āśaṅkyate imā antra iti
translated: Considering this to be a question, it is suspected in the mantra.

analyzed: spuṭam uttaram
translated: The answer is clear.

analyzed: kimāntare iti na śrūyate
translated: It is not heard that it is internal.

original: kiṃvā vastuto 'pyāntaraṃ brahma na śrūyata iti vikalpya ādyamaṅgīkarotiatrocyateyadyapīti /
analyzed: kiṃvā vastutas pya antaram brahma na śrūyate iti vikalpya ādyam aṅgīkaroti atra ucyate yadi api iti
translated: Or is it that even in reality, Brahman is not heard to be internal? Having considered the alternatives, he accepts the first in This is said.

analyzed: vikāra prāya pāṭha anugrahīta mayaṭ śruteḥ sāvayavatva liṅgāt ca iti āha tathā api iti
translated: The suffix maya is supported by the frequent mention of modifications, and the indication of having parts. He says Nevertheless.

analyzed: iṣṭa arthasya dṛṣṭyā jātam sukham priyam
translated: Delight is the pleasure born of the vision of the desired object.

analyzed: smṛtyāḥ modaḥ
translated: Joy is by memory.

analyzed: sa ca ābhāyāsāt prakṛṣṭaḥ pramodaḥ
translated: And that is the highest joy, which is free from fear.

analyzed: ānandaḥ tu kāraṇam
translated: But bliss is the cause.

analyzed: bimba caitanyam ātmā
translated: The image consciousness is the self.

analyzed: śiraḥ pucchayoḥ madhya kāryaḥ brahma śuddham iti śruti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Upanishad is that Brahman is pure in the middle of the head and tail.

analyzed: dvitīyam pratyāha tatra yat iti
translated: In reply to the second, he says There, that.

analyzed: yat mantre prakṛtam guhā nihita tvena sarva antaram brahma
translated: That Brahman which is the subject of the mantra, as being the innermost, hidden in the cave,

analyzed: tat iha puccha vākye brahma śabdāt pratyabhijñāyate
translated: is recognized here in the passage about the tail by the word Brahman.

analyzed: tasya eva vijñāpana icchayā pañca kośa rūpā guhā prapañcitā
translated: In order to convey that very [meaning], the cave in the form of the five sheaths is elaborated.

original: tatra tātparyaṃ nāstīti vaktuṃ kalpyanta ityuktam /
analyzed: tatra tātparyam na asti iti vaktum kalpyante iti uktam
translated: There, it is said that they are imagined to state that there is no intention [to convey that].

original: evaṃ pucchavākye prakṛtasvapradhānabrahmapare sati na prakṛtahānyādidoṣa ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: evam puccha vākye prakṛta svapradhāna brahma pare sati na prakṛta hāni ādi doṣaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, when the tail sentence is about Brahman, which is the primary subject, there is no fault of abandoning the primary subject, and so on. This is the meaning.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ pradhāna tvam puccha śruti viruddham iti śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: He doubts that Brahman's being primary contradicts the statement about the tail.

analyzed: atra brahma śabdāt prakṛta sva pradhāna brahma pratyabhijñāne sati puccha śabda virodha prāptau
translated: Here, when there is recognition of the primary Brahman, which is the subject, upon hearing the word Brahman, and the contradiction with the word tail is reached,

analyzed: ekasmin vākye prathama carama śruta śabdayoḥ ādyasya an upasaṃjāta virodhinaḥ balīyaḥ tavāt
translated: because in one sentence, the first word heard, which has not yet encountered a contradiction, is stronger than the last word heard.

analyzed: puccha śabdena prāpta guṇa tvasya bādhaḥ iti matvā āha prakṛta tvāt iti
translated: Thinking that the quality obtained by the word tail is contradicted, he says because of being the primary subject.

analyzed: prakaram asya anyathā asiddhim āha nanu iti  ekasya eva guma tvam pradhāna tvam ca viruddham iti āha atra ucyate iti
translated: He rejects the possibility of the primary subject being established in another way with But how?🔽He says that being a quality and being primary are contradictory with Here it is said...

original: tatra virodhanirāsāyānyatarasmanvākye brahmasvīkāre pucchavākye brahma svīkāryamityāhaanyatareti /
analyzed: tatra virodha nirāsāya anyatarasman vākye brahma svīkāre puccha vākye brahma svīkāryam iti āha anyatara iti
translated: In order to remove the contradiction there, if Brahman is accepted in one sentence, Brahman must be accepted in the sentence about the tail. He says In one of the two...

analyzed: vākya śeṣāt ca evam iti āha api ca iti
translated: And from the supplementary passage also it is so; thus he says: And moreover.

analyzed: tad tatrabrahmaṇi ślokaḥ pi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even in that Brahman there is a verse.

analyzed: puccha śabdasya gatim pṛcchati katham punar iti
translated: He asks the meaning of the word tail in the tail is Brahman: How then?

analyzed: tvayā api puccha śabdasya mukhya arthaḥ vaktum aśakyaḥ
translated: Even for you, the primary meaning of the word tail cannot be stated.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ ānanda maya lāṅgūla tva abhāvāt
translated: Because Brahman is not the tail of the Blissful One.

analyzed: puccha dṛṣṭi lakṣaṇāyām ca ādhāra lakṣaṇā yuktā
translated: And in the case of indication by the word tail, indication of the substratum is appropriate.

analyzed: pratiṣṭhā pada yogāt
translated: Because of the connection with the word foundation.

analyzed: brahma śabdasya mukhya artha lābhāt ca
translated: And because the word Brahman can have its primary meaning.

analyzed: tvad pakṣe brahma padasya api avayava lakṣaka tvāt iti āha na eṣa doṣaḥ iti
translated: In your view, because the word Brahman also indicates its parts, he says: This is not a fault.

analyzed: puccham iti ādhāra tva mātram uktam
translated: Tail has been said to mean mere substratum.

analyzed: pratiṣṭhatu eka nīḍa tvam
translated: Foundation means being the sole abode.

original: ekaṃ mukhyaṃ nīḍamadhiṣṭhānaṃ sopādānasya jagata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: ekam mukhyam nīḍam adhiṣṭhānam sa upādānasya jagataḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: the sole primary abode is the world with its cause.

analyzed: nanu vṛtti kāraiḥ api taittirīya vākyam brahmaṇi samanvitam iṣṭam
translated: But even by the commentators, the Taittiriya passage is accepted as referring to Brahman.

analyzed: tatra kim udāharam abhedena iti āśaṅkya āha api ca iti
translated: There, what is the purpose of citing it as non-different? Anticipating this doubt, he says: And moreover.

original: yatra saviśeṣatvaṃ tatra vāṅmanasagocaratvamiti vyāpteratra vyāpakābhāvoktyā nirviśeṣamucyata ityāhanirviśeṣamiti /
analyzed: yatra sa viśeṣa tvam tatra vāc manasa gocara tvam iti vyāpteḥ atra vyāpaka abhāva uktyā nirviśeṣam ucyate iti āha nirviśeṣam iti
translated: Where there is the quality of having distinctions, there is the state of being the object of speech and mind. By stating the absence of the pervader here, it is said to be without distinctions.

analyzed: nivartante aśaktāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: They turn away, meaning they are incapable.

analyzed: sa viśeṣasya mṛṣātvāt abhayam ca ayuktam
translated: Because that which has distinctions is false, fear is also unreasonable.

analyzed: atas nirviśeṣa jñāna artham puccha vākyam eva udāharaṇam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that the concluding statement itself is an example for the purpose of knowing what is without distinctions.

analyzed: prācurya arthaka mayaṭā sa viśeṣa uktau nirviśeṣa śruti bādhaḥ uktaḥ
translated: The suffix maya, which has the meaning of abundance, is said to contradict the statement about what is without distinctions.

analyzed: doṣa antaram āha api ca iti
translated: He states another fault, saying Moreover...

analyzed: pratyaya artha tvena pradhānasya prācuryasya prakṛti arthaḥ viśeṣaṇam
translated: The meaning of the primary suffix is abundance, and the meaning of the base word is the qualifier.

analyzed: viśeṣasya yaḥ pratiyogī virodhi iti tasya alpatvam apekṣate
translated: It requires the smallness of its opposite, which is the contradictory.

analyzed: yathā vipra mayaḥ grāmaḥ iti śūdra alpa tvam
translated: For example, in the statement the village is full of Brahmins, it means there are few Shudras.

analyzed: astu kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: Let it be so, what is the fault?

analyzed: tatra āha tathā ca iti
translated: There he says and in that case...

analyzed: prakṛti artha prādhānye tu ayam doṣaḥ na asti
translated: But when the meaning of the base word is primary, this fault does not exist.

analyzed: pracura prakāśaḥ savitā iti atra tamasaḥ lpasya api ābhānāt
translated: Because even a little darkness is absent in the statement the sun is full of light.

analyzed: parantu ānanda maya padasya pracura ānanda lakṣaṇā doṣaḥ syāt iti mantavyam
translated: However, it should be understood that there would be a fault in the word full of bliss due to the definition of abundant bliss.

analyzed: kiñca bhinna tvāt ghaṭa vat na brahma tā iti āha pratiśarīram iti
translated: Moreover, because it is different, like a pot, it is not Brahman. He says this in 'In each body'.

analyzed: nanu abhyasyamāna ānanda padam lakṣaṇayā ānanda maya param iti abhyāsa siddhiḥ iti atas āha yadi ca iti
translated: But if the word 'ānanda' is taken as referring to ānandamaya by lakṣaṇā, then the establishment of the repetition is accomplished. To this he says 'If, etc.'.

analyzed: ānanda mayasya brahma tve nirṇīte satya ānanda padasya tad para tva jñānāt abhyasa siddhiḥ
translated: When ānandamaya is ascertained to be Brahman, then the establishment of the repetition is by knowing that the word 'ānanda' refers to that.

original: tatsiddhau tannirṇaya iti parasparāśraya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tad siddhau tad nirṇayaḥ iti paraspara āśrayaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: When that is established, then its ascertainment. Thus there is mutual dependence, this is the idea.

analyzed: ayam abhyāsaḥ pucchabrahmaṇaḥ iti āha tasmāt iti
translated: This repetition is of the tail-Brahman. He says this in 'Therefore'.

analyzed: upasaṃkramaṇam bādhaḥ
translated: Approaching is contradiction.

original: nanu 'sa ya evaṃvit'iti brahmavidaṃ prakramyopasaṃkramaṇavākyena phalaṃ nirdiśyate tattasyābrahmatve na sidhyatīti śaṅkatenanviti /
analyzed: nanu sa yaḥ evaṃvid iti brahma vidam prakramya upasaṃkramaṇa vākyena phalam nirdiśyate tat tasya abrahmatve na sidhyati iti śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: But if a person who knows Brahman is begun with in 'He who knows thus', and the result is indicated by the sentence on approaching, then that is not accomplished if he is not Brahman. He doubts this in 'But, etc.'.

analyzed: upasaṃkramaṇam prāptiḥ iti aṅgīkṛtya viśiṣṭa prāpti uktyā viśeṣaṇa prāpti phalam uktam iti āha na eṣaḥ iti
translated: Accepting that approaching is attainment, the result of the attainment of the qualification is stated by the statement of the attainment of the qualified. He says 'This is not so'.

original: jñānena kośānāṃ bādhastaditi siddhānte bādhāvadhipratyagānandalābhor'thādukta uttaraślokena sphuṭīkṛta ityāhatadapīti /
analyzed: jñānena kośānām bādhaḥ tat iti siddhānte bādha avadhi pratyagānanda lābha ūrthāt uktaḥ uttara ślokena sphuṭīkṛtaḥ iti āha tat api iti
translated: The contradiction of the sheaths by knowledge, and the attainment of the inward bliss up to the contradiction, which is the result stated in the Siddhānta, is made clear by the next verse. He says 'That, etc.'.

analyzed: tad apekṣa tvāt iti
translated: Because it depends on that.

analyzed: kāmayitṛ puccha brahma viṣayatvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because it is about the Brahman with a tail that desires.

analyzed: yat uktam pañcama sthāna stha tvāt ānanda maye brahmavallī samāptā
translated: What was said - that in the fifth place, the Brahman-vally ends with the bliss-filled one,

analyzed: bhṛguvallī vat iti
translated: like the Bhrigu-vally.

analyzed: tatra āha yat tu iti
translated: There he says: Because of that.

analyzed: yā tu iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: what is said.

original: mayaṭśrutyā sāvayavatvādiliṅgena ca sthānaṃ bādhyamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: mayaṭ śrutyā sāvayava tva ādi liṅgena ca sthānam bādhyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the place is to be contradicted by the mention of the suffix maya and by the indicative mark of having parts, etc.

analyzed: gocara ati kramaḥ gocara tva abhāvaḥ
translated: The absence of being an object is not being an object.

analyzed: veda sūtrayoḥ virodhe guṇe tu anyāyya kalpanā iti sūtrāṇi anyathā netavyāni iti āha sūtrāṇi iti
translated: When there is a contradiction between the Veda and the aphorism, the aphorisms should be interpreted differently, he says: The aphorisms.

original: pūrvamīkṣateḥ saṃśayābhāvāditi yuktyā prāyapāṭho na niścāyaka ityuktam /
analyzed: pūrvam īkṣateḥ saṃśaya abhāvāt iti yuktyā prāya pāṭhaḥ na niścāyakaḥ iti uktam
translated: Earlier, it was said that because there is no doubt due to the word 'īkṣate' (sees), the general statement is not conclusive.

analyzed: tarhi atra puccha padasya ādhāra avayavayoḥ lakṣaṇa asāmyāt saṃśayaḥ sti iti avayava prāya pāṭhaḥ niścāyakaḥ iti pūrva adhikaraṇa siddhānta yukti abhāvena pūrvapakṣayati puccha śabdāt iti
translated: Then, here, because of the similarity of definition of the substratum and the part due to the word 'puccha' (tail), there is doubt. Therefore, the general statement about the part is conclusive. Thus, he takes the prima facie view that there is no reasoning for the conclusion of the previous section, with the words 'from the word puccha'.

analyzed: tathā ca pratyudāharaṇa saṃgatiḥ
translated: And thus there is relevance through a counter-example.

analyzed: pūrvapakṣe sa guṇa upāstiḥ
translated: In the prima facie view, there is meditation with attributes.
In the conclusion, the result is the cognition of the attributeless Brahman.
The connections with the scriptures etc. are clear from the statement of the identity of the Vedanta passages.

analyzed: sūtra stha ānanda maya padena tad vākya stham brahma padam lakṣyate
translated: The word Brahman in that passage is indicated by the word ananda-maya in the aphorism.

analyzed: vikriyate nena iti vikāraḥ vayavaḥ
translated: Vikara means an avayava (part) which is modified by this.

analyzed: prāya āpattiḥ iti
translated: Prayapatti means

analyzed: avayava kramasya buddhau prāptiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: the attainment of the order of parts in the intellect.

original: atra hi prakṛtasya brahmaṇo jñānārthaṃ kośāḥ pakṣitvena kalpyante /
analyzed: atra hi prakṛtasya brahmaṇaḥ jñāna artham kośāḥ pakṣi tvena kalpyante
translated: Here, the sheaths are imagined as the object of sacrifice for the purpose of knowing the Brahman which is the subject.

analyzed: na atra tātparyam asti
translated: There is no intention here.

original: tatrānandamayasyāpi avayavāntaroktyanantaraṃ kasmiṃścitpucche vaktavye prakṛtaṃ brahma pucchapadenoktam /
analyzed: tatra ānanda mayasya api avayava antara ukti anantaram kasmiṃścid pucche vaktavye prakṛtam brahma puccha padena uktam
translated: There, after the mention of another part of the ananda-maya, when it should be mentioned in some puccha (tail), the original Brahman is mentioned by the word puccha.

analyzed: tasya ānanda maya ādhāra tvena avaśyam vaktavya tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it must be mentioned as the support of the ananda-maya, because it is necessary.

analyzed: tad hetu vyapadeśāt ca
translated: And because it is declared to be the cause of that (ananda-maya).

analyzed: tasya brahmaṇaḥ sarva kārya hetu tva vyapadeśāt
translated: Because it is declared to be the cause of all effects.

original: priyādiviśiṣṭatvākāreṇānandamayasya jīvasya kāryatvāttaṃ prati śeṣatvaṃ brahmaṇo na yuktamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: priya ādi viśiṣṭa tva ākāreṇa ānanda mayasya jīvasya kārya tvāt tam prati śeṣa tvam brahmaṇaḥ na yuktam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not proper for Brahman to be subordinate to the individual soul, which is the effect of the ananda-maya in the form of being qualified by priya (love) etc.

analyzed: māntravarṇikam eva ca gīyate
translated: And it is sung as described in the Mantras.

analyzed: brahma vidā āpnoti param iti yasya jñānāt muktiḥ uktā
translated: The Self consisting of bliss is Brahman, because of the mention of the cause in the passage, He who knows Brahman attains the highest.

analyzed: yat satyam jñānam iti mantra uktam brahma
translated: The Brahman spoken of in the mantra Truth, knowledge, infinite.

analyzed: udgātṛ pratihartṛbhyām udgīthe pratihāre ca kā devatā iti pṛṣṭena cākrāyaṇena ādityaḥ annam ca nirdiśyate
translated: When asked by the Udgātṛ and Pratihāṛṛ priests about the deities in the Udgītha and Pratihāra, Ākāśāyaṇa points out the sun and food.

analyzed: ādityaḥ iti ha uvāca annam iti ha uvāca eti śrutau iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the Vedic text it is said, He said, 'The sun,'  and He said, 'Food.'

analyzed: sāmānyam sannidhānam
translated: Sameness is proximity.

analyzed: saṃnidhi anugrahīta prathama śruta prāṇa śrutyā mukhya prāṇa nirṇaye tad dṛṣṭyā prastāva upāstiḥ iti pūrvapakṣa phalam
translated: The result of the prima facie view is that in the determination of the primary vital breath by the first-heard vital breath qualified by proximity, the worship of the Prastāva is by that view.
In the conclusion, the worship is in the form of seeing Brahman.

analyzed: tasya adhikaraṇasya atideśa tvam eva pūrveṇa saṃgatiḥ iti vibhāgaḥ
translated: The division is that the connection with the previous one is only the extension of that topic.

original: bhavantīti bhūtānīti vyutpatyā yatkiñcidbhavanadharmakaṃ kāryamātraṃ tasya layodayau
analyzed: bhavanti iti bhūtāni iti vyutpatyā yat kiñcid bhavana dharmakam kārya mātram tasya laya udayau
translated: By the derivation of bhūta as that which becomes, any product that has the quality of becoming has dissolution and origination.

original: vāyuvikāre prāṇe na yuktāvityuktvā bhūtaśabdasya rūḍhārthagrahe 'pi layāderbrahmanirṇāyakatvamityāhayadāpīti /
analyzed: vāyu vikāre prāṇe na yuktau iti uktvā bhūta śabdasya rūḍha artha grahe pi laya ādeḥ brahma nirṇāyaka tvam iti āha yadā api iti
translated: Having said that the word 'bhūta' is not appropriate for prāṇa, which is a modification of air, he says that even if the conventional meaning of the word is accepted, dissolution etc. determine Brahman.

analyzed: bhaitika prāṇasya bhūta yoni tva ayogāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not proper for the physical prāṇa to have bhūta as its source.

analyzed: tasya tad yoni tvam śrutyā āśaṅkate nanu iti
translated: He raises the doubt that it may be the source of that by scripture with 'But is it not so?'

original: atha yadā suṣupto jīvaḥ prāṇe brahamaṇyekībhavati tadā enaṃ prāṇaṃ saviṣayavāgadayo 'piyantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: atha yadā suṣuptaḥ jīvaḥ prāṇe brahamaṇi ekībhavati tadā enam prāṇam sa viṣaya vāc ādayaḥ piyanti iti arthaḥ
translated: When the individual self is in deep sleep, it becomes one with prāṇa in Brahman. Then speech etc. with objects go into that prāṇa. This is the meaning.

original: atra jīvābhannatve sarvalayādhāratvaliṅgānna mukhyaḥ prāṇa ityāhatatrāpīti /
analyzed: atra jīva abhanna tve sarva laya ādhāra tva liṅgāt na mukhyaḥ prāṇaḥ iti āha tatra api iti
translated: Here, since the individual self is different, and since the indication is that it is the basis of the dissolution of all, the primary prāṇa is not the meaning. He says 'Even there' etc.

analyzed: vākya antara saṃnidhi apekṣayā sva vākya gatam liṅgam balīyaḥ iti āha tat ayuktam iti
translated: He says that the indication present in one's own sentence is stronger than the dependence on the proximity of another sentence. He says 'That is improper' etc.

original: ekavākyatvaṃ vākyaśeṣaḥ tasya balaṃ tadgataṃ liṅgaṃ tenetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: eka vākya tvam vākyaśeṣaḥ tasya balam tad gatam liṅgam tena iti arthaḥ
translated: The completion of a sentence is the strength of that. The indication present in that is by that. This is the meaning.

original: prāṇamevetyavadhāraṇena sarvabhūtaprakṛtitvaliṅgana ca prāṇapadena tatkāraṇaṃ brahma lakṣyamityāhatadākāśaśabdasyeveti /
analyzed: prāṇam eva iti avadhāraṇena sarva bhūta prakṛti tva liṅgana ca prāṇa padena tat kāraṇam brahma lakṣyam iti āha tad ākāśa śabdasya iva iti
translated: By the determination 'prāṇa alone', and by the indication that it is the source of all beings, the word 'prāṇa' indicates Brahman, which is its cause. He says 'Then, like the word 'ākāśa' etc.'

analyzed: vṛtti kṛtām udāharaṇam saṃśaya abhāvena ayuktam iti āha atra ityādinā
translated: The example given by the commentator is improper due to the absence of doubt. He says 'Here' etc.

analyzed: śabda bhedam uktvā prakaraṇam prapañcayati yasya ca iti

analyzed: e ns  start  jyotiścaraṇa adhikaraṇam sū
translated: Start.🔽The section on the feet of light. Sutra.

analyzed: jyotiḥ caraṇa abhidhānāt

original: idamāmananti 'atha yadataḥ paro jyotirdīpyate viśvataḥpṛṣṭeṣu sarvataḥpṛṣṭeṣvanuttameṣūttameṣu lokeṣvidaṃ vāva tadyadidamasminnantaḥpuruṣe 🔽jyotiḥ' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: idam āmananti atha yat atas paras jyotiḥ dīpyate viśvatas pṛṣṭeṣu sarvatas pṛṣṭeṣu anuttameṣu uttameṣu lokeṣu idam vāva tat yat idam asmin antaḥpuruṣe  / jyotiḥ chā iti
translated: They recite this: Now that light which shines beyond here, on all sides, on the unsurpassed and excellent worlds, this indeed is that which is this light within this man here.

analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ kim iha jyotiḥ śabdena āditya ādi jyotiḥ abhidhīyate kiṃvā paramātmā iti

analyzed: artha antara viṣayasya api śabdasya tad liṅgāt abrahma viṣaya tvam uktam
translated: It has been said that even a word referring to something else can be about Brahman because of that indication.

analyzed: iha tu tat liṅgam eva asti na asti iti vicāryate

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

analyzed: āditya ādikam eva jyotiḥ śabdena parigṛhyate iti
translated: The light of the sun etc. is taken up by the word light.

analyzed: kutas prasiddheḥ
translated: Why? Because of common usage.

original: tamo jyotiriti hīmau śabdau parasparapratidvandvī vīṣayau prasiddhau /
analyzed: tamaḥ jyotiḥ iti hi imau śabdau paraspara pratidvandvī vīṣayau prasiddhau

analyzed: cakṣuḥ vṛtteḥ nirodhakam śārvara ādikam tamaḥ ucyate

analyzed: tasyāḥ eva anugrāhakam āditya ādikam jyotiḥ

analyzed: tathā dīpyate iti iyam api śrutiḥ āditya ādi viṣayā prasiddhā
translated: And the passage, It shines, &c, is well known to refer to the sun, etc

analyzed: dyu maryāda tva śruteḥ ca

analyzed: kāryasya tu jyotiṣaḥ paricchinnasya dyauḥ maryādā syāt

translated: And the Brahmana passage also, There is a light higher than this light, Bṛ Up , , 0, shows that the light spoken of is the sun🔽But as the light which is an effect is perceived everywhere, it is not proper to make heaven its limit! Let us then assume that the light which is the firstborn is that light which is produced by the threefold combination of the three constituent elements of light! Not so, we reply

analyzed: a trivṛt kṛtasya tejasaḥ prayojana abhāvāt iti

analyzed: idam eva prayojanam yat upāsya tvam iti ced na

analyzed: prayojana antara prayuktasya eva āditya ādeḥ upāsya tva darśanāt

analyzed: tāsām trivṛtam trivṛtam ekaikām karavāṇi chā
translated: And the passage, Of these three each I will make three, Bṛ Up , , 0, shows that the three constituent elements of light are to be combined in the same way as the three Vedas

analyzed: iti ca a viśeṣa śruteḥ

analyzed: na ca a trivṛt kṛtasya api tejasaḥ dyu maryāda tvam prasiddham

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ

analyzed: te vai ete pañca anye ādhidaivikāḥ

analyzed: catuṣpada tva ādikam pūrvam eva vyākhyātam

analyzed: yaḥ etām evam iti

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ pi katham sarva ātmaka tvam

analyzed: tatra āha kāryam ca iti

translated: The passage beginning with the words, Know me alone, as the Self, and ending with the words, Worship me as the lifebreath, the intelligent Self, as immortality, as life, shows that the beginning and the end of the passage are of the same purport, the beginning having the words, I am the lifebreath, the intelligent Self, and the end having the words, He is the lifebreath alone, the intelligent Self, the immortal, the undecaying, the blissful🔽In this case, it is proper to assume that the meaning of the passage is one and the same.🔽And the mark of Brahman cannot be interpreted as referring to something else.🔽For it is not possible to refer the ten material and the ten cognitive elements to anything other than Brahman.🔽And because it is dependent on Brahman, the word prāṇa, even when used elsewhere, refers to Brahman, on account of the marks of Brahman.

analyzed: iha api ca hitatama upanyāsa ādi brahma liṅga yogāt brahma upadeśaḥ eva ayam iti gamyate
translated: The passage beginning with the words, Know me alone, as the Self, and ending with the words, Worship me as the lifebreath, the intelligent Self, as the immortal life, contains the same subjectmatter in the beginning and the end, the intelligent Self, the immortal, the undecaying, is the lifebreath; and this subjectmatter is Brahman, because the passage is seen to be connected with the word Brahman in the beginning and in the end, and because the word Brahman is not capable of being construed as referring to anything else, and because the ten material and the five cognitive organs cannot be referred to anything else but Brahman, and because the word prāṇa is used in the sense of Brahman elsewhere also, on account of the presence of the word Brahman and of other indications of Brahman, such as the statement of what is most beneficial, we conclude that the passage teaches Brahman, not the chief vital air, as the object of meditation

original: athavā nopāsātraividhyādāśritatvādiha tadyogāt ityasyāyamanyor'thaḥ na brahmavākyo 'pi jīvamukhyaprāṇaliṅgaṃ virudhyate /
analyzed: athavā na upāsā traividhyāt āśrita tvāt iha tad yogāt iti asya ayam anyaḥ arthaḥ na jīva mukhya prāṇa liṅgam virudhyate
translated: Or else, the passage may be interpreted in another way, as follows The indication of the individual soul and the chief vital air in the passage about Brahman is not contradicted.

analyzed: katham upāsā traividhyāt
translated: How so? Because of the threefoldness of the meditation.

original: trividhamiha brahmopāsane vivakṣitaṃ prāṇadharmeṇa prajñādharmeṇa svadharmeṇa ca /
analyzed: trividham iha brahma upāsane vivakṣitam prāṇa dharmeṇa prajñā dharmeṇa svadharmeṇa ca
translated: For three kinds of meditation on Brahman are intended here, one in terms of the attributes of the prāṇa, one in terms of the attributes of the prājña self, and one in terms of the attributes of Brahman itself.

analyzed: tatra āyuḥ amṛtam upāḥsva āyuḥ prāṇaḥ iti
translated: Of these, the meditation in terms of the attributes of the prāṇa is taught in the passage, Worship thou life as the immortal; life is the prāṇa.

analyzed: idam śarīram parigṛhya utthāpayati iti
translated: It raises this body and makes it rise up, and so on.

analyzed: tasmāt etat eva uktham upāsīta iti ca prāṇa dharmaḥ
translated: And the meditation in terms of the attributes of the prājña self is taught in the passage, Therefore one should meditate on this hymn.

original: 'atha yathāsyai prajñāyai sarvāṇi bhūtānyekībhavanti tadvyākhyāsyāmaḥ' ityupakramya🔽'vāgevāsyā ekamaṅgamadūduhattasyai nāma parastātprativihitā bhūtamātrā prajñayā vācaṃ
analyzed: atha yathā asyai prajñāyai sarvāṇi bhūtāni ekībhavanti tat vyākhyāsyāmaḥ iti upakramya  vāc eva asyai ekam aṅgam adūduhat tasyai nāma parastāt prativihitā bhūta mātrā prajñayā vācam
translated: Having begun with the words, 'Now we shall explain how in this wisdom all beings become one,'🔽and having stated the doctrine of wisdom, beginning with the words, 'Speech is indeed one part of it. It milked it. Beyond its name, the mere elements are arranged in order. Having mounted speech on wisdom,

original: samāruhya vācā sarvāṇi nāmānyāpnoti' ityādiḥ prajñādharmaḥ /
analyzed: samāruhya vācā sarvāṇi nāmāni āpnoti ityādiḥ prajñā dharmaḥ
translated: by speech one obtains all names,'🔽and so on,

original: tā vā etā daśaiva bhūtamātrā adhiprajñaṃ daśa prajñāmātrā adhibhūtam /🔽yaddhi bhūtamātrā na syurna prajñāmātrāḥ syuḥ /
analyzed: tāḥ vai etāḥ daśa eva bhūtamātrāḥ adhiprajñam daśa prajñāmātrāḥ adhibhūtam  yat hi bhūtamātrāḥ na syuḥ na prajñāmātrāḥ syuḥ
translated: those ten mere elements are indeed in wisdom, and the ten mere wisdoms are in the elements.🔽For if there were no mere elements, there would be no mere wisdoms.

original: yaddhi prajñāmātrā na syurna bhūtamātrāḥ syuḥ /
analyzed: yat hi prajñāmātrāḥ na syuḥ na bhūtamātrāḥ syuḥ
translated: And if there were no mere wisdoms, there would be no mere elements.

analyzed: na hi antarataḥ rūpam kiñcana siddhyet
translated: For nothing could be established internally as form.

analyzed: na u etat nānā
translated: No, they are not different.

original: 'tadyathā rathasyāreṣu nemirarpitā nābhāvarā arpitā evamevaitā bhūtamātrāḥ prajñāmātrāsvarpitāḥ prajñāmātrāḥ prāṇe 'rpitāḥ sa eṣa prāṇa eva
analyzed: tat yathā rathasya areṣu nemiḥ arpitā nābhau arāḥ arpitāḥ evam eva etāḥ bhūtamātrāḥ prajñāmātrāsu arpitāḥ prajñāmātrāḥ prāṇe rpitāḥ saḥ eṣa prāṇaḥ eva
translated: Just as the nave is fixed in the spokes of a chariot, and the felly is fixed in the nave, so are these mere elements fixed in the mere wisdoms, and the mere wisdoms are fixed in the vital breath. That vital breath itself

analyzed: prajñā ātmā ityādiḥ brahma dharmaḥ
translated: is the self consisting of wisdom,' and so on, is the doctrine of Brahman.

original: tasmādbrahma evaitadupādhidvayadharmeṇa svadharmeṇa caikamupāsanaṃ trividhaṃ vivakṣitam /
analyzed: tasmāt brahma eva etat upādhi dvaya dharmeṇa svadharmeṇa ca ekam upāsanam trividham vivakṣitam
translated: Therefore, Brahman alone is meant to be meditated upon in three ways, by its own attribute and by the attributes of the two limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: anyatra api manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ chā
translated: Elsewhere also, in passages like 'consisting of mind, having life as its body' (Tai. 2.1),

analyzed: ityādau upādhi dharmeṇa brahmaṇaḥ upāsanam āśritam
translated: meditation on Brahman by the attributes of the limiting adjuncts is resorted to.

analyzed: iha api tat yujyate vākyasya upakrama upasaṃhārābhyām eka artha tva avagamāt prāṇa prajñā brahma liṅga avagamāt ca
translated: Here also, that is appropriate, because the beginning and end of the sentence are understood to have the same meaning, and because the characteristics of life, wisdom, and Brahman are understood.

analyzed: tasmāt brahma vākyam etat iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is established that this is a passage about Brahman.

original: iti śrīmacchārīrakamīmāṃsābhāṣye śrīśaṅkarabhagavatpādakṛtau prathamādhyāyasya prathamaḥ pādaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrīmat śārīraka mīmāṃsā bhāṣye śrī śaṅkara bhagavat pāda kṛtau prathama adhyāyasya prathamaḥ pādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the first chapter of the first section in the commentary of Shri Shankara Bhagavatpada on the Vedanta-Sutras.

original: FN / yathāyogaṃ kiñcidatra jīvavākyaṃ kiñcinmukhyaprāṇavākyaṃ kiñcidbrahmavākyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathāyogam kiṃcid atra jīva vākyam kiṃcid mukhya prāṇa vākyam kiṃcid brahman vākya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that some passages here are about the individual soul, some are about the primary life force, and some are about Brahman.

original: prāṇasaṃvāde vāgādayaḥ sarve pratyekamātmanaḥ śraiṣṭhyaṃ manyamānāstannirdidhārayiṣayā prajāpatimupajagmuḥ /
analyzed: prāṇa saṃvāde vāc ādayaḥ sarve pratyekam ātmanaḥ śraiṣṭhyam manyamānāḥ tad nirdidhārayiṣayā prajāpatim upajagmuḥ
translated: In the dialogue about life force, speech and others, considering each one to be the best, approached Prajapati with the desire to determine that.

original: sa tānuvāca yasminnutkrānte śarīraṃ pāpiṣṭhataramiva bhavati sa vaḥ śreṣṭha iti /
analyzed: sa tān uvāca yasmin utkrānte śarīram pāpiṣṭhataram iva bhavati sa vaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ iti
translated: He said to them, He who, when departed, makes the body seem most wretched, he is the best among you.

analyzed: tatas krameṇa vāc ādiṣu utkrānteṣu api śarīram svastham asthat
translated: Then, even when speech and the rest had departed in order, the body remained well.

analyzed: mukhyaprāṇasya uccikramiṣāyām sarveṣām vyākula tve
translated: When the chief life-breath was about to depart, and all were agitated,

original: variṣṭhaḥ prāṇo 'bravīdahameva pañcadhā prāṇāpānādibhāvenātmānaṃ vibhajya etadbhāti gacchatīti vānaṃ tadeva bāṇamasthiraṃ śarīramavaṣṭabhyāśrityeti
analyzed: variṣṭhaḥ prāṇaḥ bravīt aham eva pañcadhā prāṇa apāna ādi bhāvena ātmānam vibhajya etat bhāti gacchati iti vānam tat eva bāṇam asthiram śarīram avaṣṭabhya āśritya iti
translated: the best life-breath said: I alone, dividing myself into five forms as inhalation, exhalation, etc., support this unstable arrow, the body, and abide.

original: pañca śabdādayaḥ pañca pṛthivyādaya iti daśa bhūtamātrāḥ /
analyzed: pañca śabda ādayaḥ pañca pṛthivī ādayaḥ iti daśa bhūtamātrāḥ
translated: The five objects of sense such as sound, and the five elements such as earth, these are the ten mere elements.

original: pañca buddhīndriyāṇi pañca buddhaya iti daśa prajñāmātrāḥ /
analyzed: pañca buddhīndriyāṇi pañca buddhayaḥ iti daśa prajñāmātrāḥ
translated: The five sense organs and the five cognitions, these are the ten mere cognitions.

analyzed: anyatra atas eva prāṇa ityādau
translated: Elsewhere, in Therefore, the life-breath, etc.

original: yena caitanyena vāgabhyudyate preryate vadanasāmarthyamāpadyate tadeva vāgāderagamyaṃ brahma /
analyzed: yena caitanyena vāc abhyudyate preryate vadana sāmarthyam āpadyate tat eva vāc ādeḥ agamyam brahma
translated: By that consciousness with which speech is impelled, urged, and attains the ability to speak, that alone is Brahman, which is not accessible to speech, etc.

analyzed: upāsā iti svatantrāṇām trayāṇām upāstau vākya bhedaḥ
translated: If the three independent ones worship, there is split of the sentence in the worship.

analyzed: na tu ekasya eva brahmaṇaḥ tad dharmeṇa iti arthaḥ  tasya āyuḥ tvam jīvanasya tad adhīna tvāt
translated: The meaning is not that of one Brahman alone with that attribute.🔽Its being life is because life depends on it.

analyzed: utthāpayati iti uktham iti prāṇa dharmaḥ
translated: It raises up, therefore it is uktha, an attribute of the life-breath.

analyzed: atha iti jīva dharmaḥ
translated: Then, is an attribute of the individual soul.

analyzed: deha utthāpanam jīva liṅgam kim na syāt
translated: Why should not the support of the body be the living Self?

analyzed: tatra āha śarīra dhāraṇam ca iti
translated: To this he says: If it be said that the support of the body is the function of the principal lifebreath, no;🔽because of the declaration of difference, and because of the scriptural passage about the living Self.

original: sarve vāgādayaḥ prāṇā ahamahaṃ śreṣṭha iti vivadamānāḥ prajāpatimupajagmuḥ /
analyzed: sarve vāc ādayaḥ prāṇāḥ aham aham śreṣṭhaḥ iti vivadamānāḥ prajāpatim upajagmuḥ
translated: All the vital breaths, speech and so on, disputed among themselves, saying, I am the best. They went to Prajāpati.

analyzed: sa ca tān uvāca
translated: And he said to them:

original: yasminnutkrānte śarīraṃ pāpiṣṭhataraṃ patiṣyati sa vaḥ śreṣṭha iti tathākrameṇa vāgādipūtkrānteṣvapi mūkādibhāvena śarīraṃ svasthamasthāt /
analyzed: yasmin utkrānte śarīram pāpiṣṭhataram patiṣyati sa vaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ iti tathākrameṇa vāc ādipu utkrānteṣu api mūka ādi bhāvena śarīram svastham asthāt
translated: He among you, by whose departure the body would fall most helplessly, he is the best of you. So in due order, when speech and so on had departed, the body remained sound, in the state of dumbness and so on.

original: mukhyaprāṇasya tu uccikramiṣāyāṃ sarveṣāṃ vyākulatvāptau tānvāgādīnvariṣṭhaḥ prāṇa uvāca /
analyzed: mukhya prāṇasya tu uccikramiṣāyām sarveṣām vyākula tva āptau tān vāc ādīn variṣṭhaḥ prāṇaḥ uvāca
translated: But when the principal lifebreath was about to depart, and all were in a state of confusion, the best of them, the lifebreath, said to speech and the rest:

analyzed: yūyam moham mā āpadyatha yatas ham eva etat karomi
translated: You must not be confused, for it is I who do this.

original: kiṃ tat / pañcadhā prāṇāpānādibhāvenātmānaṃ vibhajya etadvāti gacchatīti vānaṃ tadeva bāṇamasthiraṃ śarīramavaṣṭabhyāśritya dhārayāmītyarthaḥ
analyzed: kim tat pañcadhā prāṇa apāna ādi bhāvena ātmānam vibhajya etat vāti gacchati iti vānam tat eva bāṇam asthiram śarīram avaṣṭabhya āśritya dhārayāmi iti arthaḥ
translated: What is that? Dividing itself into five forms, as the lifebreath, the downward moving breath, and so on, I hold this unsteady arrow, the body, by supporting it, this is the meaning.

original: dvivacanasahavāsotkrāntiśruteśca na brahma grāhyamityāhajīvamukhyeti /🔽abhedanirdeśamāhayo vā iti /
analyzed: dvivacana sahavāsa utkrānti śruteḥ ca na brahma grāhyam iti āha jīva mukhya iti  abheda nirdeśam āhayaḥ vai iti
translated: And because of the declaration of difference, and because of the scriptural passage about the living Self, Brahman is not to be accepted. This he says in the words: The living Self, the principal lifebreath, etc.

analyzed: bhedam āha saha iti
translated: He states the teaching of nondifference in the words: He who, etc.🔽He states the difference in the words: Together, etc.

original: yadi jīvamukhyaprāṇayorliṅgādupāstatvaṃ tarhi brahmaṇo 'pi liṅgānāmuktatvādupāsanaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi jīva mukhya prāṇayoḥ liṅgāt upāsta tvam tarhi brahmaṇaḥ pi liṅgānām ukta tvāt upāsanam syāt
translated: If the individual soul and the chief vital air are to be meditated upon on account of the indicative power, then Brahman also is to be meditated upon, since indicative powers of it have been mentioned.

analyzed: na ca iṣṭa āpattiḥ upakrama ādinā niścita ekavākyatā bhaṅga prasaṅgāt iti āha na etat evam ityādinā
translated: This is not to be evaded by saying that Brahman is not to be meditated upon, because the indicative powers of it are not such as are capable of being meditated upon; for, if that were so, the indicative powers of the individual soul and the chief vital air also would not be such as are capable of being meditated upon.

original: naca svatantrapadārthabhedādvākyabhedaḥ kiṃ na syāditi vācyaṃ /
analyzed: na ca svatantra padārtha bhedāt vākya bhedaḥ kim na syāt iti vācyam
translated: Nor is it to be said that there will be a split of the sentence on account of the difference of the independent words;

analyzed: jīva mukhya prāṇayoḥ ukta liṅgānām śakya tayā svātantrya asiddheḥ
translated: because the individual soul and the chief vital air, which have been mentioned as having the indicative powers, are not independent, since they can be interpreted as Brahman.

analyzed: aphala padārthasya phalavat vākya artha śeṣa tvena pradhāna vākya artha anusāreṇa tad liṅga nayasya ucita tvāt ca
translated: And because it is proper that the indicative power of them should be interpreted in accordance with the principal matter of the sentence, the individual soul and the chief vital air being subordinate to the matter of the sentence which has Brahman for its principal matter and is fruitful.

analyzed: nahi pradhāna vākya artha brahma liṅgam anyathā netum śakyam
translated: For, the indicative power of Brahman, which is the principal matter of the sentence, cannot be interpreted otherwise.

analyzed: na vā tat ucitam iti āha na ca brahma liṅgam iti
translated: Nor is it proper to interpret it otherwise. Hence he says Nor is the indicative power of Brahman.

analyzed: sūtra śeṣam vyācaṣṭe āśrita tvāt ca iti
translated: He explains the remainder of the Sūtra by the word ‘because’ in the commentary.

original: anyatra 'ata eva prāṇaḥ'ityādau vṛtterāśritvādihāpi tasya brahmaliṅgasya yogādbrahmapara eva prāṇaśabda ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: anyatra atas eva prāṇaḥ ityādau vṛtteḥ āśritvāt iha api tasya brahma liṅgasya yogāt brahma paraḥ eva prāṇa śabdaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the word ‘prāṇa’ refers to Brahman only, because of the connection here also with the indicative power of Brahman, since the application of the word ‘prāṇa’ to something else, such as in ‘Therefore prāṇa is Brahman’, is dependent.

analyzed: prāṇa ādi liṅgāni sarvātmake brahmaṇi anāyāsena netum āha yat tu ityādinā
translated: The author now says that the indications of the individual soul, such as the vital airs, can be easily brought under Brahman, the universal Self.

original: yasminnetau preryatvena sthitau tenetareṇa brahmaṇā sarve prāṇādivyāpāraṃ kurvantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yasmin etau prerya tvena sthitau tena itareṇa brahmaṇā sarve prāṇa ādi vyāpāram kurvanti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that all these, being impelled by that other Brahman, perform the functions of the vital airs, etc.

analyzed: viśeṣam pariccheda abhimānam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the individual soul is the limiting adjunct, the conception of separateness.

analyzed: vidyāt iti na vaktuḥ jñeya tvam ucyate
translated: The word 'vat' should be known. It does not say that the speaker is to be known.

analyzed: tasya loka siddha tvāt
translated: Because that is well-known in the world.

analyzed: kintu tasya brahmatvam bodhyate
translated: But rather, His Brahmanhood is taught.

analyzed: tad bodha ābhimukhyāya liṅga ādayaḥ iti atra śruti antaram āha yat vācā iti
translated: For the purpose of inclining towards the knowledge of that, the indications, etc. are given. In this regard, another scriptural passage is stated: 'By which speech, etc.'

original: yena caitanyena vāgabhyudyate svakāryābhimukhyena preryate tadeva vāgādiragamyaṃ brahmetyarthaḥ /🔽tattvaṃpadavācyayoḥ svarūpato bhedasthābhyāmupalakṣyātmasvarūpābhedādekatvaṃ nirdiśyata ityāhanaiṣa doṣa iti /
analyzed: yena caitanyena vāc abhyudyate sva kārya ābhimukhyena preryate tat eva vāc ādiḥ agamyam brahma iti arthaḥ  tattvam pada vācyayoḥ svarūpataḥ bheda sthābhyām upalakṣya ātma svarūpa abhedāt ekatvam nirdiśyate iti āha na eṣa doṣaḥ iti
translated: The meaning is that the Brahman, which is not to be reached by speech, etc., by that sentience, speech is impelled, i.e., urged towards its own function.

analyzed: sva matena sūtram vyākhyāya vṛtti kṛt matena vyācaṣṭe athavā iti
translated: Having explained the aphorism according to his own view, he explains it according to the view of the commentator, with the words 'or rather'.

analyzed: upāsanā tri tva prasaṅgāt iti pūrvam uktam
translated: It was said earlier that the number of meditations would be three.

analyzed: atra tri prakārakasya eka brahma viśeṣa ikasya ekasya upāsanasya vivakṣita tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that here the meditation on one Brahman alone, which is of three kinds, is intended.

analyzed: atas na vākyaḥ bhedaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that therefore there is no split of the sentence.

analyzed: deha ceṣṭā ātmaka jīvana hetu tvam prāṇasya āyuḥ tvam deha apekṣayā tasya āmukteḥ avasthānāt amṛta tvam
translated: The fact that Prāṇa is the cause of life consisting of bodily activity is its being life; its being immortal is because it remains after the body has been abandoned.

analyzed: utthāpayati iti uktha tvam iti prāṇa dharmaḥ
translated: The fact that it causes to rise is its being Uktha; this is a property of Prāṇa.

analyzed: jīva dharmān āha atha iti
translated: He mentions the properties of the individual soul: Now, etc.

analyzed: buddhi prāṇayoḥ saha sthiti utkrānti ukti anantaram iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: after the statement of the simultaneous presence and departure of the intellect and Prāṇa.

analyzed: atra prajñā padena sa ābhāsā jīva ākhyā buddhiḥ ucyate
translated: Here, by the word 'prajñā', the intellect called the individual soul along with its reflection is meant.

original: tasyāḥ saṃbhandhīni dṛśyāni sarvāṇi bhūtāni yathaikaṃ bhavantyadhiṣṭhānacidātmanā tathā vyākhyāsyāma ityupakramyoktam'vāgeva'ityādi /
analyzed: tasyāḥ saṃbhandhīni dṛśyāni sarvāṇi bhūtāni yathā ekam bhavanti adhiṣṭhāna cit ātmanā tathā vyākhyāsyāmaḥ iti upakramya uktam vāc eva etyādi
translated: We shall explain how all the visible elements, which are related to it, become one through the supporting conscious Self. Having begun thus, it is said: 'Speech itself' and so on.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ eva asyāḥ ekam aṅgam adūduhat ityādi paryāyāṇām saṃkṣipta artham ucyate
translated: The condensed meaning of the chapters beginning with 'The eye itself is one limb of it, it milked' is being stated.

analyzed: utpannāyāḥ asat kalpanāyāḥ sa ābhāsa buddheḥ nāma prapañca viṣayi tvam ardham śarīram
translated: The half of the body of the intellect along with its reflection, which is the false imagination that has arisen, is the subject of the manifold names and objects.

original: arthātmakarūpaprapañcaviṣayitvamardhaṃ śarīramiti militvā viṣayitvākhyaṃ pūrṇaṃ śarīramindriyasādhyam /
analyzed: artha ātmaka rūpa prapañca viṣayi tvam ardham śarīram iti militvā viṣayi tva ākhyam pūrṇam śarīram indriya sādhyam
translated: The state of being the subject of the manifold of the forms of the nature of objects is half the body. Thus, the complete body, called the state of being the subject, is accomplished by the senses.

original: tatra karmendriyeṣu vāgevāsyāḥ prajñāyā ekamaṅgaṃ dehārdhamadūduhat pūrayāmāsa /
analyzed: tatra karmendriyeṣu vāc eva asyāḥ prajñāyāḥ ekam aṅgam deha ardham adūduhat pūrayāmāsa
translated: Among the organs of action, speech alone is one limb of this wisdom, it has filled, completed, half the body.

analyzed: vāc indriya dvārā nāma prapañca viṣayi tvam buddhiḥ labhate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the intellect obtains the state of being the subject of the manifold of the class of names through the organ of speech.

analyzed: caturthī ṣaṣṭhī arthā
translated: The fourth case has the sense of the genitive.

original: tasyāḥ punarnāma kila cakṣurādinā prativihitā jñāpitābhūtamātrā rūpādyartharūpā parastādaparārdhe kāraṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasyāḥ punar nāma kila cakṣuḥ ādinā prativihitā jñāpitā abhūtamātrā rūpa ādi artha rūpā parastāt apara ardhe kāraṇam bhavati
translated: Moreover, that [intellect] is indeed indicated, made known, by the eye etc., and the mere elements in the form of objects such as form etc. become the cause of the other half [of the body].
