analyzed: nanu akṣara śabda nirdiṣṭāt bhūtayoneḥ parasya eva tat sarvajñatvam ca na bhūtayoni viṣayam iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the omniscience and all-knowingness belong to something other than the source of the elements, which is indicated by the word imperishable.

analyzed: atra ucyate na evam saṃbhavati
translated: To this it is said: This is not possible.

original: yatkāraṇaṃ 'akṣarātsaṃbhavatīha viśvam' iti prakṛtaṃ bhūtayonimiha jāyamānaprakṛtitvena
analyzed: yatkāraṇam akṣarāt saṃbhavati iha viśvam iti prakṛtam bhūta yonim iha jāyamāna prakṛti tvena
translated: Because what is referred to here as the source of the elements, from which the universe is produced, is the Primordial Nature, which is the material cause of the origination of the universe,

original: nirdiśyānantaramapi jāyamānaprakṛtitvenaiva sarvajñaṃ nirdiśati 'yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarvavidyasya jñānamayaṃ tapaḥ /🔽tasmādetadbrahma nāma rūpamannaṃ ca jāyate' iti /
analyzed: nirdiśya anantaram api jāyamāna prakṛti tvena eva sarvajñam nirdiśati yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarva vid yasya jñāna mayam tapaḥ  tasmāt etat brahma nāma rūpam annam ca jāyate iti
translated: And immediately after the description of the source of the elements, he describes the omniscient one as the source of the created world: He who is omniscient, whose austerity consists of knowledge, from him is born this Brahman, consisting of name, form and food.

original: tasmānnirdeśasāmyena pratyabhijñāyamānatvātprakṛtasyaivākṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ sarvajñatvaṃ sarvavittvaṃ ca dharma ucyata iti gamyate /
analyzed: tasmāt nirdeśa sāmyena pratyabhijñāyamāna tvāt prakṛtasya eva akṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ sarvajña tvam sarva vid tvam ca dharmaḥ ucyate iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that omniscience and omnipresence are declared to be the attributes of the same primordial syllable, the source of the elements, which is recognized by the similarity of description.

analyzed: akṣarāt paratas paraḥ iti atra api na prakṛtāt bhūtayoneḥ akṣarāt paraḥ kaścid abhidhūyate
translated: Even in the passage, Higher than the high Imperishable, no one higher than the primordial Imperishable, the source of the elements, is mentioned.

analyzed: katham etat avagamyate
translated: How is this understood?

original: 'yenākṣaraṃ puruṣaṃ veda satyaṃ provāca tāṃ tattvato brahmavidyām' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: yena akṣaram puruṣam veda satyam provāca tām tattvataḥ brahma vidyām muṇḍa
translated: Having begun with, He who knows the Imperishable Person, the Truth, has declared the true knowledge of Brahman,

original: iti prakṛtya tasyaivākṣarasya bhūtayoneradṛśyatvādiguṇakasya vaktavyatvena pratijñātatvāt /
analyzed: iti prakṛtya tasya eva akṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ adṛśya tva ādi guṇakasya vaktavya tvena pratijñāta tvāt
translated: it is promised that the same Imperishable, the source of the elements, having the attributes of being invisible, etc., is to be described.

original: kathaṃ tarhi 'akṣarātparataḥ paraḥ' iti vyapadiśyata iti /
analyzed: katham tarhi akṣarāt paratas paraḥ iti vyapadiśyate iti
translated: Then how is it designated as Higher than the high Imperishable?

analyzed: uttara sūtre tat vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will explain that in the next aphorism.

original: apicātra dve vidye veditavye ukte 'parā caivāparā ca' iti /
analyzed: apica atra dve vidye veditavye ukte parā ca eva aparā ca iti
translated: Moreover, here two kinds of knowledge are declared to be known, the lower and the higher.

original: tatrāparāmṛgvedādilakṣaṇāṃ vidyāmuktvā bravīti 'atha parā yayā tadakṣaramadhigamyate ityādi /
analyzed: tatra aparām ṛgveda ādi lakṣaṇām vidyām uktvā bravīti atha parā yayā tat akṣaram adhigamyate ityādi
translated: There, having mentioned the lower knowledge, characterized by the Rg Veda etc., it says: 'Now the higher, by which that syllable is attained,' etc.

analyzed: tatra parasyāḥ vidyāyāḥ viṣaya tvena akṣaram śrutam
translated: There, the syllable is heard as the object of the higher knowledge.

original: yadi punaḥ parameśvarādanyadadṛśyatvādiguṇakamakṣaraṃ parikalpyeta neyaṃ parā vidyā syāt /
analyzed: yadi punar parameśvarāt anyat adṛśya tva ādi guṇakam akṣaram parikalpyeta na iyam parā vidyā syāt
translated: If, again, the syllable with the qualities of being invisible etc. were imagined to be different from the highest Lord, this would not be the higher knowledge.

analyzed: para apara vibhāgaḥ hi ayam vidyayoḥ abhyudaya niḥśreyasa phala tayā parikalpyate
translated: For this distinction between the higher and the lower knowledge is imagined to be based on the fruits of prosperity and final beatitude.

analyzed: na ca pradhāna vidyā niḥśreyasa phalā kenacid abhyupagamyate
translated: And no one accepts the knowledge of the pradhāna as having the fruit of final beatitude.

analyzed: tisraḥ ca vidyāḥ pratijñāyeran
translated: And three kinds of knowledge would have to be admitted.

analyzed: tvad pakṣe kṣarāt bhūtayoneḥ parasya paramātmanaḥ pratipādyamāna tvāt
translated: Because in your view, the highest Self, which is higher than the syllable, the source of beings, is taught.

original: dve eva tu vidye veditavye iha nirdiṣṭe /
analyzed: dve eva tu vidye veditavye iha nirdiṣṭe
translated: But only two kinds of knowledge are indicated here as to be known.

original: 'kasminnu bhagavo vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavati' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: kasmin nu bhagavaḥ vijñāte sarvam idam vijñātam bhavati muṇḍa
translated: 'In what, O Lord, when known, is all this known?' (Muṇḍ. 1.1.3)

original: iti caikavijñānena sarvavijñānāpekṣaṇaṃ sarvātmake brahmaṇi vivakṣyamāṇe 'vakalpyate /
analyzed: iti ca eka vijñānena sarva vijñāna apekṣaṇam sarva ātmake brahmaṇi vivakṣyamāṇe
translated: Thus the fact of all cognitions being implied in one cognition is possible only if Brahman, which is all, is meant to be spoken of.

analyzed: na acetana mātra eka āyatane pradhāne
translated: Not if the chief matter is the pradhāna, which is the abode of mere nonintelligent matter,

original: bhogyavyatirikte vā bhoktari /🔽apica 'sa brahmavidyāṃ sarvavidyāpratiṣṭhāmatharvāya jyeṣṭhaputrāya prāha' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: bhogya vyatirikte vā bhoktari  api ca sa brahma vidyām sarva vidyā pratiṣṭhām atharvāya jyeṣṭha putrāya prāha muṇḍa
translated: or if the enjoyer is meant, who is different from the objects of enjoyment.

original: iti brahmavidyāṃ prādhānyenopakramya parāparavibhāgena parāṃ vidyāmakṣarādhigamanīṃ darśayaṃstayā brahmavidyātvaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: iti brahma vidyām prādhānyena upakramya para apara vibhāgena parām vidyām akṣara adhigamanīm darśayan tayā brahma vidyā tvam darśayati
translated: Moreover, in the passage, He taught the highest Brahman, the foundation of all knowledge, to Atharvan, his eldest son, the highest Brahman is mentioned as the subject of the instruction, and then, by the distinction of the higher and the lower, the highest knowledge, which is the knowledge of the Imperishable, is shown to be the same as the knowledge of Brahman.

original: sā ca brahmavidyāsamākhyā tadadhigamyasyākṣarasyābrahmatve bādhitā syāt /
analyzed: sā ca brahma vidyā samākhyā tad adhigamyasya akṣarasya abrahmatve bādhitā syāt
translated: And this designation of the knowledge of Brahman would be contradicted if the Imperishable, which is to be known through that knowledge, were not Brahman.

analyzed: aparā ṛgveda ādi lakṣaṇā karma vidyā brahma vidyā upakrame upanyasyate brahma vidyā praśaṃsāyai
translated: The knowledge of works, which is represented by the other Vedas, is mentioned at the beginning of the knowledge of Brahman, in order to praise the knowledge of Brahman.

original: 'plavā hyete adṛḍhā yajñarūpā aṣṭādaśoktamavaraṃ yeṣu karma /
analyzed: plavāḥ hi ete adṛḍhāḥ yajña rūpāḥ aṣṭādaśa uktam avaram yeṣu karma
translated: For the text says, They are indeed unstable rafts, the forms of sacrifice, the inferior works which are declared in the eighteen .

original: etacchreyo yo 'bhinandanti mūḍhā jarāmṛtyuṃ te punarevāpiyanti' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: etat śreyaḥ yaḥ bhinandanti mūḍhāḥ jarā mṛtyum te punar eva apiyanti muṇḍa
translated: The foolish who delight in this good go again to old age and death.

analyzed: iti evamādi nindā vacanāt
translated: This passage and others of the same kind deprecate the knowledge of works.

original: ninditvā cāparāṃ vidyāṃ tato viraktasya paravidyādhikāraṃ darśayati 'parīkṣya lokānkarmacitānbrāhmaṇo nirvedamāyānnāstyakṛtaḥ kṛtena /
analyzed: ninditvā ca aparām vidyām tatas viraktasya para vidyā adhikāram darśayati parīkṣya lokān karma citān brāhmaṇaḥ nirvedam āyāt na asti akṛtaḥ kṛtena
translated: And after having thus censured the other knowledge, he shows that one who is indifferent to it is entitled to the higher knowledge: 'Having examined the worlds created by action, the Brāhmaṇa becomes indifferent. There is no creation for the uncreated by the created.

original: tadvijñānārthaṃ sa gurumevābhigacchetsamitpāṇiḥ śretriyaṃ brahmaniṣṭham' muṇḍa / / / iti /
analyzed: tad vijñāna artham sa gurum eva abhigacchet samidh pāṇiḥ śretriyam brahma niṣṭham muṇḍaḥ iti
translated: For the sake of knowing that, he should approach the teacher himself, with fuel in hand, a Kṣatriya devoted to Brahman.' (Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 1.2.12)

analyzed: yat tu uktam acetanānām pṛthivī ādīnām dṛṣṭānta tvena upādānāt dārṣṭāntikena api acetanena bhūtayoninā bhavitavyam iti
translated: But what was said, that because the insentient earth etc. are taken as examples, the inferred object, the source of beings, must also be insentient -

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

analyzed: nahi dṛṣṭānta dārṣṭāntikayoḥ atyanta sāmyena bhavitavyam iti
translated: For there is no rule that the example and the inferred object must be absolutely identical.

original: apica sthūlāḥ pṛthivyādayo dṛṣṭāntatvenopāttā iti na sthūla eva dārṣṭāntiko bhūtayonirabhyupagamyate /
analyzed: apica sthūlāḥ pṛthivī ādayaḥ dṛṣṭānta tvena upāttāḥ iti na sthūlaḥ eva dārṣṭāntikaḥ bhūtayoniḥ abhyupagamyate
translated: Moreover, since gross earth etc. are taken as examples, the inferred object, the source of beings, is not accepted as only gross.

analyzed: tasmāt adṛśya tva ādi guṇakaḥ bhūtayoniḥ parameśvaraḥ eva
translated: Therefore, the source of beings, having the qualities of being invisible etc., is the Supreme Lord alone.

analyzed: a dreśyam a dṛś jñāna indriyaiḥ  a grāhyam karmendriyaiḥ
translated: The unseen, invisible to the sense of knowledge.🔽The ungraspable, not graspable by the organs of action.

analyzed: ūrṇanābhiḥ lūtā kīṭaḥ
translated: The spider is the silkworm.

analyzed: pūrvatra pūrvasmin adhikaraṇe
translated: In the previous section, in the previous topic.

analyzed: nahi iti
translated: For it is not so.

original: 'aktāḥ śarkarā upadadhātī' tyatra 'tejo vai ghṛtaṃ' iti śeṣānnirṇayavadatrāpi adṛśyavādeḥ śeṣānnirṇayaḥ /
analyzed: aktāḥ śarkarāḥ upadadhāti tyatra tejaḥ vai ghṛtam iti śeṣāt nirṇaya vat atra api adṛśya vādeḥ śeṣāt nirṇayaḥ
translated: In the sentence He lays down the anointed gravels, the determination is made from the remainder, as in Ghee is indeed brilliance. Similarly here, the determination is made from the remainder of the statement about the unmanifest.

original: yena jñānenākṣaraṃ prakṛtaṃ bhūtayoniṃ puruṣaṃ satyaṃ veda /
analyzed: yena jñānena akṣaram prakṛtam bhūta yonim puruṣam satyam veda
translated: By that knowledge one knows the imperishable, the source of beings, the true Purusha.

analyzed: sarva vidyānām pratiṣṭhā samāptiḥ yasyām
translated: In which the culmination, the completion, of all the branches of knowledge is found.

analyzed: plavante gacchanti asthāyinaḥ iti plavāḥ
translated: They float, go, are impermanent, hence they are floaters.

analyzed: aṣṭādaśa iti ṣoḍaśa ārtvijaḥ yajamānaḥ patnī ca iti aṣṭādaśa
translated: Eighteen, namely the sixteen priests, the sacrificer, and the wife, make eighteen.

analyzed: yeṣu uktam avaram anityam karma yajñaḥ
translated: In which it is said that the lower, impermanent rites are sacrifices.

analyzed: apiyanti prāpnuvanti
translated: They reach, attain.

original: pratyakṣādinā karmasādhyāṃllokānanityatayā jñātvā nirvedaṃ vairāgyaṃ gacchet /
analyzed: pratyakṣa ādinā karma sādhyān lokān anitya tayā jñātvā nirvedam vairāgyam gacchet
translated: Having known by perception etc. that the worlds attainable by rites are impermanent, one should go to renunciation, non-attachment.

original: kutaḥ / kṛtena karmaṇā akṛto mokṣo nāsti /
analyzed: kutas kṛtena karmaṇā akṛtaḥ mokṣaḥ na asti
translated: Why? Liberation is not attained without the performance of rites.

analyzed: adṛśya tva ādi guṇakaḥ dharma ukteḥ
translated: Because Dharma is said to have the qualities of being unmanifest etc.

analyzed: muṇḍaka vākyam udāharati atha iti
translated: He quotes the Mundaka text, beginning with atha (now).

original: karma vidyārūpāparavidyoktyanantaraṃ yayā nirguṇaṃ jñāyate parā socyate /
analyzed: karma vidyā rūpa apara vidyā ukti anantaram yayā nirguṇam jñāyate parā sā ucyate
translated: After the teaching of the lower knowledge in the form of rites, the higher knowledge by which the attributeless is known is taught.

analyzed: tām ā eva viṣaya uktyā nirdiśati yat tat iti
translated: He indicates that very knowledge by stating its object, with the words yat tad (that which).

analyzed: adreśyam adṛśyam jñāna indriyaiḥ
translated: It is invisible, not seen by the sense of knowledge.

analyzed: a grāhyam karmendriyaiḥ
translated: Not graspable by the organs of action.

analyzed: gotram vaṃśaḥ
translated: Gotra means family.

analyzed: varṇaḥ brāhmaṇa tva ādi jātiḥ  cakṣuḥ śrotra śūnyam acakṣuḥ śrotram
translated: Varna means the caste of a Brahmin etc.🔽Devoid of eyes and ears is eyeless and earless.

analyzed: pāṇi pāda śūnyam a pāṇi pādam
translated: Devoid of hands and feet is handless and footless.

analyzed: jñāna karmendriya vikalam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is deficient in organs of knowledge and action.

analyzed: vibhum prabhum
translated: Vibhu means all-pervading.

analyzed: su sūkṣmam durjñeya tvāt
translated: Sookshma means subtle, difficult to know.

analyzed: nitya avyaya padābhyām nāśa apakṣayayoḥ nirāsaḥ
translated: The words nitya and avyayah negate destruction and diminution.

original: bhūtānāṃ yoniṃ prakṛtiṃ yatpaśyanti dhīrāḥ paṇḍitāstadakṣaraṃ tadvidyā paretyanvayaḥ /
analyzed: bhūtānām yonim prakṛtim yat paśyanti dhīrāḥ paṇḍitāḥ tat akṣaram tad vidyā parā iti anvayaḥ
translated: The wise ones, the learned ones, see the source of beings, the primordial nature, that is the imperishable, that is the supreme knowledge - this is the sequence.

analyzed: adreśya tva ādi guṇānām brahma pradhāna sādhāraṇa tvāt saṃśayaḥ
translated: Since the qualities of being imperceptible etc. are common to Brahman and Pradhana, there is doubt.

analyzed: pūrvavat draṣṭṛ tva ādīnām cetana dharmāṇām atra aśruteḥ astu pradhānam iti pratyudāharaṇena pūrvapakṣayati tatra iti
translated: As before, since the qualities of being a seer etc. are not mentioned here, let it be Pradhana - thus, taking the opposite view, he presents the prima facie view with the word tatra (in that case).

analyzed: pūrvapakṣe pradhāna ādi upāstiḥ
translated: In the prima facie view, there is the worship of Pradhana etc.

analyzed: sidvānte nirguṇa dhīḥ iti phalam
translated: In the conclusion, the result is the knowledge of Brahman devoid of qualities.

analyzed: ūrṇanābhiḥ lūtā kīṭaḥ tantūn sva dehāt sṛjati
translated: Urna-nabi is the silkworm. It emits threads from its body.

analyzed: upasaṃharati ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is it draws them back.

analyzed: sataḥ jīvataḥ
translated: While alive, while existing.

analyzed: nanu pūrvam nirastam pradhānam katham utthāpyate
translated: But how can Pradhana, which was refuted earlier, be raised again?

analyzed: tatra āha apica iti
translated: In that regard, he says api ca (Moreover).

original: atra pradhāne virudhyamāno 'saṃbhāvito vākyaśeṣaḥ śruta iti śaṅkatenanu ya iti /
analyzed: atra pradhāne virudhyamānaḥ saṃbhāvitaḥ vākyaśeṣaḥ śrutaḥ iti śaṅkate nanu yaḥ iti
translated: Here, the remainder of the sentence, which is contradicted or not possible in the principal matter, is heard. Therefore, he doubts: But is it not so that the one who is....

original: pañcamyantākṣaraśrutyā bhūtaprakṛteḥ pratyabhijñānātprathamāntaparaśabdoktasya jagannimitteśvarasya sarvajñatvādikamityāhaatrocyata iti /
analyzed: pañcamī anta akṣara śrutyā bhūta prakṛteḥ pratyabhijñānāt prathama anta para śabda uktasya jagat nimitta īśvarasya sarvajñatva ādikam iti āha atra ucyate iti
translated: Since the material cause of the elements is recognized by the hearing of the syllable ending in the fifth case, the cause of the world spoken of by the word para ending in the first case is omniscience etc. He says: To this it is said....

original: 'saṃdigdhe tu vākyaśeṣāt'iti nyāyena siddhāntayatievaṃ prāpta iti /
analyzed: saṃdigdhe tu vākyaśeṣāt iti nyāyena siddhāntayati evam prāptaḥ iti
translated: By the principle But in a doubt, from the remainder of the sentence, he concludes: Thus it is obtained....

original: cetanācetanatvena saṃdigdhe bhūtayonau 'yaḥ sarvajñaḥ'iti vākyaśeṣādīśvaratvanirṇaya ityayuktaṃ /🔽vākyaśeṣe bhūtayoneḥ pratyabhijñāpakābhāvāditi śaṅkatenanviti /
analyzed: cetana acetana tvena saṃdigdhe bhūtayonau yaḥ sarvajñaḥ iti vākya śeṣāt īśvara tva nirṇayaḥ iti ayuktam  vākya śeṣe bhūtayoneḥ pratyabhijñāpaka abhāvāt iti śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: When the source of the elements is in doubt due to being conscious and non-conscious, it is not proper to determine it as the Lord by the remainder of the sentence He who is omniscient.🔽He doubts: But is it not so that....

analyzed: jani kartṛḥ prakṛtiḥ iti sūtreṇa prakṛteḥ apādāna saṃjñāyām pañcamī smaraṇāt akṣarāt saṃbhavati iti
translated: By the sutra Prakriti is the source of the generator, since the fifth case is remembered in the designation of the source, it is said arises from the syllable.

analyzed: prakṛti tvena uktā akṣarasya bhūtayoniḥ vākyaśeṣe tasmāt iti prakṛti tva liṅgena pratyabhijñānam asti iti
translated: Since the source mentioned as the source in the remainder of the sentence by the mark of being the source with the word tasmat, there is recognition of the syllable as the source of the elements.

analyzed: samādhatte atra ucyate iti
translated: He answers: To this it is said....

analyzed: etat kāryam brahma sūkṣma ātmakam nāma rūpam
translated: This effect, Brahman, is of the nature of the subtle name-and-form.

analyzed: sthūlam tatas nnam vrīhi ādi iti arthaḥ
translated: The gross one is food, such as rice, etc.

analyzed: yat uktam pañcamī anta akṣara śrutyā bhūtayoneḥ pratyabhijñāna da cetana tvam iti
translated: It has been argued that the non-sentience of the source of elements is to be inferred from the recognition of it by the pronoun 'tat' occurring in the sentence ending with the fifth case.

analyzed: tatra āha akṣarāt paratas iti
translated: In reply to this, it is said: 'Beyond the Imperishable'.

analyzed: na ayam akṣara śabdaḥ bhūtayonim parāmṛśati
translated: This word 'akṣara' does not refer to the source of elements.

original: paravidyādhigamyatvenoktasyākṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ 'akṣaraṃ puruṣaṃ vedā'ityakṣaraśrutyā vedyatvaliṅgavatyā pūrvameva brahmatvena parāmarśādityāhayeneti
analyzed: para vidyā adhigamya tvena uktasya akṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ akṣaram puruṣam veda iti akṣara śrutyā vedya tva liṅgavatyā pūrvam eva brahmatvena parāmarśāt iti āha yena iti
translated: Because the Imperishable, which is said to be attainable by the highest knowledge, is referred to as Brahman even before by the pronoun 'akṣara' in the sentence 'One should know the Person, the Imperishable', which contains the inferential mark of being the object of knowledge. This is what is said by the words 'yena' etc.

original: yena jñānenākṣaraṃ bhūtayoniṃ sarvajñaṃ puruṣaṃ veda tāṃ brahmavidyāṃ yogyāya śiṣyāya
analyzed: yena jñānena akṣaram bhūta yonim sarvajñam puruṣam veda tām brahma vidyām yogyāya śiṣyāya
translated: By that knowledge by which one knows the Imperishable, the source of elements, the all-knowing Person, one should teach that knowledge of Brahman to a fit disciple.

analyzed: prabrūyāt iti upakramya aprāṇaḥ hi amanāḥ śubhraḥ akṣarāt paratas paraḥ iti ucyamānaḥ
translated: Having begun thus, when it is said 'It is without breath, without mind, pure', 'Beyond the Imperishable, beyond that',

analyzed: paras bhūtayoniḥ iti gamyate iti arthaḥ
translated: it is understood that the highest source of elements is meant. This is the meaning.

original: tarhi pañcamyantākṣaraśabdārthaḥ ka ityāśaṅkyājñānamiti vakṣyata ityāhakathamiti /

original: bṛhadāraṇyake ca svapnajāgaritasthānābhyāṃ saha pāṭhāt tasyāṃ ca saṃprasādāvasthāyāṃ prāṇo jāgartīti prāṇo 'tra saṃprasādo 'bhipreyate /

analyzed: chāndogyam udāharati idam iti

analyzed: na alpe sukham asti bhūmā eva sukham
translated: There is no happiness in a small thing, only the highest state is happiness.

original: tasmānniratiśayasukhārthinā bhūmaiva vicārya iti nāradaṃ prati sanatkumāreṇokte sati nārado brūtebhūmānamiti /🔽bhūmno lakṣaṇamadvitīyatvamāhayatreti /
analyzed: tasmāt niratiśaya sukha arthinā bhūmā eva vicāryaḥ iti nāradam prati sanatkumāreṇa ukte sati nāradaḥ brūte bhūmānam iti  bhūmnaḥ lakṣaṇam advitīya tvam āha yatra iti
translated: Therefore, for one who desires unsurpassed happiness, only the highest state should be pondered. When this was said by Sanatkumara to Narada, Narada said: The highest state...🔽He states the definition of the highest state, which is being without a second: Where...

analyzed: bhūma lakṣaṇam paricchinna lakṣaṇa uktyā sphuṭayati atha iti
translated: He clarifies the definition of the highest state by stating the definition of a limited thing: Now...

analyzed: atra saṃśaya bījam praśna pūrvakam āha kutas ityādinā
translated: Here, he states the seed of doubt, preceded by a question, with From where... and so on.

original: bahorbhāva iti vigrahe 'pṛthvādibhyā imanic'itīmanpratyaye kṛte 'bahorlopo bhū ca bahoḥ'iti sūtreṇa bahoḥ parasyemanicpratyayasyāderikārasya
analyzed: bahoḥ bhāvaḥ iti vigrahe pṛthu ādibhyāḥ imanic iti iman pratyaye kṛte bahoḥ lopaḥ bhū ca bahoḥ iti sūtreṇa bahoḥ parasya imanic pratyayasya ādeḥ ikārasya
translated: In the analysis of bahor bhava, after the suffix iman is added according to aprithvadhibhyam iman, by the sutra bahor lopa bhu ca bahoh, the suffix iman after bahu would be elided, and

original: lepaḥ syāt /🔽bahoḥ sthāne bhūrityādeśaśca syādityukterbhūmanniti śabdo niṣpannaḥ /
analyzed: lepaḥ syāt  bahoḥ sthāne bhūḥ iti ādeśaḥ ca syāt iti ukteḥ bhūman iti śabdaḥ niṣpannaḥ
translated: the letter a would be changed to bhu.🔽Thus, the word bhu is formed.

analyzed: tasya bhāva artha keman pratyaya anta tvāt bahu tvam vācyam
translated: Since it has the meaning of existence and ends with the suffix man, plurality is to be expressed.

analyzed: tat kindharmikam iti ākāṅkṣāyām saṃnihita prakaraṇa sthaḥ prāṇaḥ dharmaḥ bhāti
translated: When there is a desire to know what is the substratum of that, the prāṇa which is present in the context shines as the property.

original: vākyopakramastha ātmāpi svapratipādanāpekṣo dharmitvena bhātīti saṃnihitavyavahitaprakaraṇābhyāṃ saṃśaya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vākya upakrama sthaḥ ātmā api sva pratipādana apekṣaḥ dharmi tvena bhāti iti saṃnihita vyavahita prakaraṇābhyām saṃśayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The self which is present at the beginning of the sentence also shines as the substratum with reference to its own presentation. Thus, there is doubt due to the proximity and remoteness of the context. This is the meaning.

analyzed: pūrvam ātma śabdāt dyu bhū ādi āyatanam brahma iti uktam
translated: Previously, it was said that Brahman is the abode of light and other things from the word 'ātman'.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: tarati śokam ātma vit iti a brahmaṇi api ātma śabda prayogāt iti ākṣepa saṃgatyā pūrvapakṣyati prāṇaḥ bhūmā iti
translated: Because the word 'ātman' is used even in relation to what is not Brahman, as in 'One who knows the self crosses over sorrow', this is the prima facie view that the prāṇa is the highest.

analyzed: dharma dharmiṇoḥ abhedāt sāmānādhikaraṇyam dṛṣṭavyam
translated: The non-difference of the property and the possessor of the property should be seen as the basis for the co-reference.

original: pūrvottarapakṣayoḥ prāṇopāstiḥ brahmajñānaṃ ca phalaṃ krameṇa mantavyam /
analyzed: pūrva uttarapakṣayoḥ prāṇa upāstiḥ brahma jñānam ca phalam krameṇa mantavyam
translated: In the prima facie and final views, the worship of prāṇa and the knowledge of Brahman should be understood as the results respectively.

analyzed: atra adhyāye bhūyas praśna uttara bhedāt artha bhedaḥ dṛśyate
translated: In this chapter, the difference in meaning is seen due to the difference in the question and answer.

original: bhūmā tu prāṇātparaṃ bhūyaḥprakṣaṃ vinaivoktaliṅgena prāṇādabhinna ityāhakasmādityādinā /
analyzed: bhūmā tu prāṇāt param bhūyaḥ prakṣam vinā eva ukta liṅgena prāṇāt abhinnaḥ iti āha kasmāt ityādinā
translated: But the highest is different from prāṇa, without even the question of 'what is higher than prāṇa', by the mentioned reason. It is said that it is not different from prāṇa with the words 'why is it so?' etc.

original: prāṇādbhūya iti na dṛśyata iti pūrveṇa saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: prāṇāt bhūyaḥ iti na dṛśyate iti pūrveṇa saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The connection is that it is not seen that it is higher than prāṇa.

original: nanu 'eṣa tu vā ativadati'iti tuśabdena prāṇaprakaraṇavicchedānna prāṇo bhūmetyata āhaprāṇameveti /
analyzed: nanu eṣa tu vai ativadati iti tuśabdena prāṇa prakaraṇa vicchedāt na prāṇaḥ bhūmā iti atas āha prāṇam eva iti
translated: But, since the word 'but' in the passage, 'But he indeed speaks more' (Br. 3.9.26), indicates the end of the topic of the vital air, the vital air is not the highest state. To this he says 'the vital air alone'.

original: nāmādyaśāntānupāsyānatītya prāṇaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ vadatītyativādi prāṇavid taṃ prati ativādyasīti kenacitpraśne kṛte asmīti brūyāt /
analyzed: nāma ādya śāntān upāsyān atītya prāṇam śreṣṭham vadati iti ativādi prāṇa vid tam prati ativādī asi iti kenacid praśne kṛte asmi iti brūyāt
translated: The knower of the vital air, who speaks more, having gone beyond the vital air, the best, speaks more. To him, when asked by someone, 'You are a speaker', he should say, 'I am'.

analyzed: na aham ativādī iti apahnavam na kuryāt iti uktam
translated: It has been said that he should not deny, saying, 'I am not a speaker'.

original: prāṇavidameṣa iti parāmṛśya satyavacanadhyānamananaśraddhādidharmaparamparāṃ vidhāya bhūmopadeśānna prakaraṇavicchedaḥ /
analyzed: prāṇa vidam eṣaḥ iti parāmṛśya satya vacana dhyāna manana śraddhā ādi dharma paramparām vidhāya bhūma upadeśāt na prakaraṇa vicchedaḥ
translated: Since the teaching of the highest state is given after enjoining the series of virtues such as truthfulness, meditation, reflection, faith, etc., referring to him as 'this one' who knows the vital air, there is no break in the topic.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ nāma ādi upāsakasya ativādi tva nirāsa arthaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the word 'but' is for the purpose of denying that the worshipper of name etc. is a speaker.

original: bhūmno lakṣaṇavacanaṃ sukhatvamamṛtatvaṃ ca prāṇe praśnapūrvakaṃ yojayatikathaṃ punarityādinā /
analyzed: bhūmnaḥ lakṣaṇa vacanam sukha tvam amṛta tvam ca prāṇe praśna pūrvakam yojayati katham punar ityādinā
translated: He connects the statement of the definition of the highest state, namely, blissfulness and immortality, with the vital air, along with a question, beginning with 'How again?'.

original: prāṇagrasteṣu prāṇe līneṣu na śṛṇoti suṣuptapuruṣa iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: prāṇa grasteṣu prāṇe līneṣu na śṛṇoti suṣupta puruṣaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in deep sleep, a person does not hear when the vital airs are seized, i.e. merged in the vital air.

original: 'gārhapatyo ha vā eṣo 'pāno vyāno 'nvāhāryapacana āhavanīyaḥ prāṇaḥ'iti śruteḥ prāṇā agnaya iha pure śarīre jāgrati savyāpārā eva tiṣṭhantītyarthaḥ
analyzed: gārhapatyaḥ ha vai eṣa u pānaḥ vyānaḥ nvāhāryapacanaḥ āhavanīyaḥ prāṇaḥ iti śruteḥ prāṇāḥ agnayaḥ iha pure śarīre jāgrati sa vyāpārāḥ eva tiṣṭhanti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the vital breaths, which are the fires, are awake, i.e., active, in this city of the body.

analyzed: devaḥ jīvaḥ
translated: The individual soul is the god.

analyzed: atha tadā svapna adarśana kāle sukha śravaṇāt prāṇasya sukha tvam aviruddham iti anvayaḥ
translated: Now, at the time of seeing dreams, since pleasure is heard, the pleasantness of the vital breath is not contradictory. This is the sequence.

analyzed: ātma padena upakrama virodham pariharati prāṇaḥ eva iti
translated: He avoids the contradiction of the introductory statement by the word soul with the vital breath alone.

analyzed: prāṇasya ātma tvam katham iti āśaṅkya śruta tvāt iti āha tathā hi iti
translated: How is the vital breath the soul? Suspecting this, he says it is because it is heard. Thus, indeed, it is said.

original: sarvaṃ samarpitamiti ca sarvādhiṣṭhānaṃ prāṇaṃ svīkaroti śrutirityanvayaḥ ata ātmatvaṃ mukhyārthaṃ darśayatisaṃprasāda iti /
analyzed: sarvam samarpitam iti ca sarva adhiṣṭhānam prāṇam svīkaroti śrutiḥ iti anvayaḥ atas ātma tvam mukhya artham darśayati saṃprasādaḥ iti
translated: And by the statement everything is entrusted to it, the scripture accepts the vital breath as the basis of all. This is the sequence. He shows that the primary meaning is the state of being the soul with the state of deep sleep.

original: sa vā eṣa etasminsaṃprasāde sthitvā punarādravatīti prayogācca /🔽tatpadaṃ suṣuptivācakamityāhabṛhaditi /
analyzed: sa vai eṣaḥ etasmin saṃprasāde sthitvā punar ādravati iti prayogāt ca  tat padam suṣupti vācakam iti āha bṛhat iti
translated: And because of the usage He, having dwelt in this state of deep sleep, runs again.🔽He says that the word tat (that) denotes deep sleep with the Brhadāraṇyaka.

analyzed: vācyārtha saṃbandhāt prāṇaḥ lakṣyaḥ iti āha tasyām ca iti
translated: He says that the vital breath is the denoted object by the relation with the denoted meaning with and in that.

analyzed: atra sūtre iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this is the aphorism here.

analyzed: bhūmā prāṇāt bhinnaḥ tra adhyāye
translated: The supreme is different from the vital breath in this chapter.

analyzed: tasmāt ūrdhvam upadiṣṭa tvāt
translated: Therefore, because it is taught above.

analyzed: nāma ādeḥ ūrdhvam upadiṣṭa vāc ādi vat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is taught above like speech etc. from name etc.

analyzed: vipakṣa hetu ucchedam bādhakam āha prāṇaḥ eva ced iti
translated: He states the refutation in the form of the destruction of the reason in the opposite case, saying If it were only the vital breath.

analyzed: svasya eva svasmāt ūrdhvam upadiṣṭa tvam ayuktam  nāma ādiṣu adṛṣṭam ca iti arthaḥ
translated: It is not proper for something to be taught above itself.🔽The meaning is that it is not seen in name etc.

analyzed: hetu asiddhim śaṅkate nanu iha iti
translated: He doubts the non-establishment of the reason, saying But is it not so here?

analyzed: prakṛta prāṇa vid parāmarśakaḥ eṣa śabdaḥ na bhavati
translated: This word this does not refer to the one who knows the vital breath in the context.

analyzed: tasya yad śabda paratantra tvena satyavāda ji vāci tvāt
translated: Because it denotes the true living being as dependent on the word that.

analyzed: atas prāṇa prakaraṇam vicchinnam iti hetu sidviḥ iti āha atra ucyate iti
translated: Therefore, the reason is established that the section on the vital breath is interrupted. He says This is said here.

analyzed: satyena ativādi tvam viśeṣaḥ
translated: The distinction is that he speaks too much with truth.

original: tadvato ya eṣa ityukterna pūrvānukarṣa ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tadvataḥ yaḥ eṣaḥ iti ukteḥ na pūrva anukarṣaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that since it is said he who has that, it does not carry over from before.

original: ya eṣa prāṇavidativadatītyanūdya sa satyaṃ vadediti vidhānānna prāṇaprakaraṇaviccheda iti dṛṣṭāntena śaṅkatenanviti /
analyzed: yaḥ eṣa prāṇa vid ativadati iti anūdya sa satyam vadet iti vidhānāt na prāṇa prakaraṇa vicchedaḥ iti dṛṣṭāntena śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: He doubts by example that there is no interruption of the section on the vital breath, saying But is it not so here?

analyzed: satya śabdaḥ hi abādhite rūḍhaḥ brahma vācakaḥ
translated: For the word truth is established in the undeceiving and denotes Brahman.

analyzed: tad anyasya mithyātvāt
translated: Because everything else is false.

original: satyavacane tvabādhitārthasaṃbandhāllākṣaṇika iti nātra lakṣyavacanavidhirityāhaneti brūma iti /
analyzed: satya vacane tu abādhita artha saṃbandhāt lākṣaṇikaḥ iti na atra lakṣya vacana vidhiḥ iti āhana iti brūmaḥ iti
translated: But in the case of the statement about truth, the word is figurative because of the connection with an unobstructed meaning. Therefore, this is not an injunction to state the object to be defined. He says we say no.

original: kiñca satyena brahmaṇātivadatīti tṛtīyāśrutyā brahmakaraṇakamativāditvaṃ śrutaṃ /
analyzed: kiñca satyena brahmaṇā ativadati iti tṛtīyā śrutyā brahma karaṇaka mativādi tvam śrutam
translated: Moreover, by the accusative case in he speaks with truth the statement is heard to be with truth as its instrument.

original: tasya prakaraṇādbādho na yukta ityāhaśrutyā hītyādinā /
analyzed: tasya prakaraṇāt bādhaḥ na yuktaḥ iti āha śrutyā hi ityādinā
translated: Its contradiction by context is not proper. He says by the Vedic text and so on.

analyzed: atra iti
translated: Here means

analyzed: satya vākye iti arthaḥ
translated: in the statement about truth.

original: evaṃ satyeneti śrutyā prakaraṇaṃ bādhyamityuktvā tuśabdenāpi bādhyamāhaprakṛteti /
analyzed: evam satyena iti śrutyā prakaraṇam bādhyam iti uktvā tuśabdena api bādhyam āha prakṛta iti
translated: Having said that the context is to be contradicted by the Vedic text stating with truth, he says that the word but also contradicts the context.

analyzed: vijijñāsya tva liṅgāt ca pūrva uktāt bhinnam iti āha satyam tu eva iti
translated: And by the indicative mark stated earlier, namely, being the object of desire to know, it is different. He says but truth alone.

analyzed: prakaraṇa vicchede dṛṣṭāntam āha tasmāt iti
translated: For the division of the context, he gives an example, therefore.

analyzed: śruti liṅga balāt etat satyam prakṛtāt prāṇāt prādhānyena bhinnam dṛṣṭavyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that by the strength of the Vedic text and the indicative mark, this truth should be seen as primarily different from the previously mentioned prana.

analyzed: evam ativādi tvasya brahma saṃbandha uktyā prāṇa liṅga tvam nirastam
translated: Thus, the indicative mark of prana is refuted by stating the connection of speaking with truth with Brahman.

analyzed: yat tu praśnam vinā ukta tva liṅgāt bhūmā prāṇaḥ iti
translated: But it is said that the highest is prana because of the indicative mark of being stated without a question.

analyzed: tat na
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: tasya aprayojaka tvāt iti āha na ca iti
translated: Because that is not a proper reason, he says but if.

analyzed: praśna bhedāt artha bhedaḥ iti na niyamaḥ
translated: The difference in meaning is due to the difference in questions, not by rule.

analyzed: ekasya ātmanaḥ maitreyyāḥ bahuśas pṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because the one Self has been asked about many times by Maitreyi.

analyzed: praśnam vinā ukta cāturvedasya prakṛta eka vedāt bhinna tva darśanāt ca iti arthaḥ
translated: And because the four-fold knowledge, even though mentioned without a question, is seen to be different from the single knowledge mentioned in the context. This is the meaning.

analyzed: tatra yathā catur veda tvasya prakṛta asaṃbandhāt artha bhedaḥ
translated: There, just as the four-fold knowledge has a different meaning due to its lack of connection with the context,

analyzed: evam iha api iti sphuṭayati tatra ityadinā
translated: so it is here also. This is clarified by the words tatra (there) etc.

analyzed: satya padena prāṇa uktiḥ iti atas āha tatra satyam iti
translated: Since the word satya (truth) refers to the statement about the vital air, he says: There, the truth...

analyzed: vijñānam nididhyāsanam
translated: Knowledge is meditation.

analyzed: ādi padāt manana śraddhā śravaṇa manaḥ śuddhi niṣṭā tad hetu karmāṇi gṛhyante
translated: By the word etc. are included reflection, faith, hearing, purification of the mind, and the actions that are the cause of that.

original: imānyati śravaṇādīni jñeyasya satyasya brahmatve liṅgāni /
analyzed: imāni ati śravaṇa ādīni jñeyasya satyasya brahmatve liṅgāni
translated: These, beginning with hearing, are the indications of the knowable truth being Brahman.

original: evaṃ śrutiliṅgaiḥ prāṇasyāvāntaraprakaraṇaṃ bādhitvā prastutaṃ satyaṃ brahma bhūmapadoktabahutvadharmītyāhatatra yaditi /
analyzed: evam śruti liṅgaiḥ prāṇasya avāntara prakaraṇam bādhitvā prastutam satyam brahma bhūma pada ukta bahutva dharmī iti āha tatra yat iti
translated: Thus, having set aside the subordinate context of the vital air by the scriptural indications and the indications of the text, he says that the truth mentioned is the subject with the plurality denoted by the word bhūman.

original: kiñca 'saṃnihitādapi vyavahitaṃ sākāṅkṣaṃ balīyaḥ'iti nyāyena saṃnihitaṃ nirākāṅkṣaṃ
analyzed: kiñca saṃnihitāt api vyavahitam sākāṅkṣam balīyaḥ iti nyāyena saṃnihitam nirākāṅkṣam
translated: Moreover, by the rule that what is more remote is stronger if it is related and has expectancy, the proximate, which is without expectancy,

original: prāṇaṃ dṛṣṭvā vākyopakramastha ātmā svapratipādanāya bhūmavākyāpekṣa iha bhūmā grāhya ityāhaevaṃ ceti /
analyzed: prāṇam dṛṣṭvā vākya upakrama sthaḥ ātmā sva pratipādanāya bhūma vākya apekṣaḥ iha bhūmā grāhyaḥ iti āha evam ca iti
translated: Seeing the word 'prāṇa', the Self, which is mentioned in the beginning of the sentence, in order to establish itself, is to be accepted here as the 'bhūman' in relation to the statement about the earth. Therefore it is said 'thus'.

analyzed: kiñca śokasya pāram iti upakramya tamasaḥ pāram iti upasaṃhārāt
translated: Moreover, having begun with 'the other shore of sorrow', it concludes with 'the other shore of darkness'.

analyzed: śokasya mūla ucchedam vinā taraṇa ayogāt ca
translated: And because it is not possible to cross sorrow without uprooting its root.

analyzed: śoka padena mūla tamaḥ gṛhyate
translated: By the word 'sorrow', the root darkness is meant.

analyzed: tad nivartaka jñāna gamya tva liṅgāt ātmā brahma iti āha na ca anyatra iti
translated: From the indication that it is to be known by the knowledge that removes that, the Self is Brahman. Therefore it is said 'not elsewhere'.

analyzed: brāhmaṇam ātma āyattatvam prāṇasya vadati iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The connection is that the Brāhmaṇa speaks of the dependence of prāṇa on the Self.

original: nanvidaṃ caramaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ brahmaparamastu /🔽tataḥ prāgukto bhūmā prāṇa iti śaṅkateprakaraṇānta iti /
analyzed: nanu idam caramam brāhmaṇam brahma param astu  tatas prāc uktaḥ bhūmā prāṇaḥ iti śaṅkate prakaraṇa ante iti
translated: Now, let this last Brāhmaṇa be about Brahman.🔽Then, the previously mentioned bhūman is prāṇa. This is suspected in 'at the end of the section'.

analyzed: tad śabdena bhūma anukarṣāt mā evam iti āha na iti
translated: Since the word 'tat' (that) refers to bhūman, it is said 'no' (neti).

analyzed: e ns  start
translated: End.

analyzed: dharma upapatteḥ ca
translated: And because of the possibility of dharma.

original: apica ye bhūmni śrūyante dharmāste paramātmanyupapadyante /
analyzed: api ca ye bhūmni śrūyante dharmāḥ te paramātmani upapadyante
translated: Moreover, those qualities that are heard about the bhūman are possible in the supreme Self.

original: 'yatra nānyatpaśyati nānyacchṛṇoti nānyadvajānāti sa bhūmā' iti darśanādivyavahārābhāvaṃ bhūmānyavagamayati /
analyzed: yatra na anyat paśyati na anyat śṛṇoti na anyat vajānāti sa bhūmā iti darśana ādi vyavahāra abhāvam bhūmāni avagamayati
translated: 15.7.1) declares the absence of the activities of seeing, etc. to be the nature of the Absolute.

original: paramātmani cāyaṃ darśanādivyavahārābhāvo 'vagataḥ /🔽'yatra tvasya sarvamātmaivābhūttatkena kaṃ paśyet' bṛ / / /
analyzed: paramātmani ca ayam darśana ādi vyavahāra abhāvaḥ vagataḥ  yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśyet bṛ
translated: And this absence of the activities of seeing, etc. is known to belong to the Supreme Self.

analyzed: ityādi śruti antarāt

original: śrutibhyāṃ pratyabhijñānātsa evāyamiti sautraḥ saśabdo vyākhyātaḥ atraivaṃ sūtrayojanāoṅkāre yo dhyeyaḥ sa para evātmā /
analyzed: śrutibhyām pratyabhijñānāt saḥ eva ayam iti sautraḥ sa śabdaḥ vyākhyātaḥ atra evam sūtra yojanā oṅkāre yaḥ dhyeyaḥ sa paraḥ eva ātmā
translated: The word sa in the Sutra is explained as this is the same, because of recognition by the two scriptures. The construction of the Sutra here is thus: He who is to be meditated upon in the syllable Om is the supreme Self alone.

analyzed: vākyaśeṣe īkṣaṇīya tva ukteḥ
translated: Because of the statement in the remainder of the sentence that he is to be seen.

original: atra ca śrutipratyabhijñānātsa evāyamiti /🔽nanu śabdabhedānna pratyabhijñeti śaṅkatenanviti /
analyzed: atra ca śruti pratyabhijñānāt saḥ eva ayam iti  nanu śabda bhedāt na pratyabhijñā iti śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: And here, because of the recognition of the Vedic text, it is the same.🔽But it is objected that, because of the difference of words, there is no recognition. This is suspected in the words 'but is it not so?'

analyzed: parātparaḥ iti śabda bhedam aṅgīkṛtya śrutibhyām ukta pratyabhijñāyāḥ avirodham āha atra iti
translated: Accepting the difference of words, 'higher than the high,' he says that the recognition stated by the two Vedic texts is not contradictory, in the words 'here' (in the Upakrama).

analyzed: nanu etasmāt jīva dhanāt parāt iti etad padena upakrānta dhyātavya parāmarśāt īkṣaṇīyaḥ
translated: But it is objected that the object of meditation, referred to by the word 'from this high life,' is different from the object of contemplation.

analyzed: parātmā dhyeyāt anyaḥ iti atas āha na ca atra iti
translated: To this he says 'nor is it so here.'

original: dhyānasya tatphalekṣaṇasya ca loke samānaviṣayatvāddhyeya evekṣaṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: dhyānasya tad phala īkṣaṇasya ca loke samāna viṣaya tvāt dhyeyaḥ eva īkṣaṇīyaḥ
translated: Because in the world the object of meditation and the object of contemplation have the same object, the object of contemplation is the same as the object of meditation.

analyzed: evam ca upakrama upasaṃhārayoḥ eka vākya tā bhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus there is unity of meaning in the Upakrama and the Upasamhara. This is the idea.

original: 'sa sāmabhirūnnīyate brahmalokam''sa etasmājjīvaghanāt'ityetatpadena saṃnihitataro brahmalokasvāmī parāmṛśyata iti praśnapūrvakaṃ vyācaṣṭekastarhītyādinā
analyzed: sa sāmabhiḥ ūnnīyate brahma lokam saḥ etasmāt jīva ghanāt iti etad padena saṃnihitataraḥ brahma loka svāmī parāmṛśyate iti praśna pūrvakam vyācaṣṭe kaḥ tarhi ityādinā
translated: 'He is led by the Samans to the world of Brahman,' 'he from this high life' - by the word 'he,' the ruler of the world of Brahman, who is more proximate, is referred to. This is explained with a question in the words 'then who is he?'

analyzed: mūrtau ghanaḥ iti sūtrāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it is according to the sutra 'ghanas in the body.'

analyzed: saindhava khilyaḥ lavaṇa piṇḍaḥ
translated: A lump of salt is a piece of salt.

original: khilyavadalpo bhāvaḥ paricchedo yasya sa khilyabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: khilya vat alpaḥ bhāvaḥ paricchedaḥ yasya sa khilya bhāvaḥ
translated: He who has a limited existence like a splinter is one who has a limited existence.

original: etatpadena brahmaloko vā parāmṛśyata ityāhaapara iti /
analyzed: etad padena brahma lokaḥ vā parāmṛśyate iti āha apare iti
translated: By this word, the world of Brahman is referred to, he says: 'the other'.

analyzed: jīva ghana śabdasya brahma loke lakṣaṇām darśayati jīvānām hi iti
translated: He shows the definition of the word 'mass of souls' in the world of Brahman: 'For in that world, etc.'.

original: vyaṣṭikaraṇābhimānināṃ jīvānāṃ ghanaḥ saṃghāto yasminsarvakaraṇābhimānini sa jīvaghanaḥ tatsvāmikatvātparaṃparāsaṃbandhena loko lakṣya ityarthaḥ
analyzed: vyaṣṭi karaṇa abhimāninām jīvānām ghanaḥ saṃghātaḥ yasmin sarva karaṇa abhimānini sa jīva ghanaḥ tad svāmika tvāt paraṃparā saṃbandhena lokaḥ lakṣyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: That in which there is a mass, a collection, of souls who are the conceivers of individual organs, is the mass of souls. The world is indicated as the object of ownership through a series of relations.

analyzed: tasmāt paraḥ sarva loka atītaḥ śuddhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is beyond that, beyond all worlds. The meaning is: pure.

original: parapuruṣaśabdasya paramātmani mukhyatvācca sa eva dhyeya ityāhaparamiti /
analyzed: parapuruṣa śabdasya paramātmani mukhya tvāt ca saḥ eva dhyeyaḥ iti āha param iti
translated: And because the word 'supreme person' is primary in the supreme self, he says: 'Supreme', etc.

original: yasmātparaṃ nāparamasti kiñcit sa evaṃ mukhyaḥ paraḥ na tu piṇḍātparaḥ sūtrātmetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt param na aparam asti kiñcid saḥ evam mukhyaḥ paraḥ na tu piṇḍāt paraḥ sūtra ātmā iti arthaḥ
translated: Because there is nothing higher than that, that is the primary supreme, not the individual soul beyond the body. The meaning is: the thread-self.

original: kiñca paraśabdenopakrame niścitaṃ paraṃ brahmaivātra vākyaśeṣe dhyātavyamityāhaparaṃ cāparaṃ ceti /
analyzed: kiñca para śabdena upakrame niścitam param brahma eva atra vākyaśeṣe dhyātavyam iti āha param ca aparam ca iti
translated: Moreover, in the introduction, the supreme Brahman is ascertained by the word 'supreme'. Therefore, in the remainder of the sentence here, only that should be meditated upon, he says: 'The supreme and the other'.

analyzed: pāpa nivṛtti liṅgāḥ ca iti āha yathā iti
translated: And because of the indication of the cessation of sin, he says: 'As', etc.

analyzed: pāda udaraḥ sarpaḥ
translated: A legless serpent.

original: oṅkāre parabrahmopāsanayā sūryadvārā brahmalokaṃ gatvā parabrahmekṣitvā tadeva śāntamabhayaṃ paraṃ prāpnotītyavirodhamāhaatrocyata iti /🔽evamekavākyatāsamarthanaprakaraṇānugṛhītaparapuruṣaśrutibhyāṃ parabrahmapratyabhijñayā brahmalokaprāptiliṅgaṃ bādhitvā vākyaṃ praṇavadhyeye
analyzed: oṅkāre para brahma upāsanayā sūrya dvārā brahma lokam gatvā para brahma īkṣitvā tat eva śāntam abhayam param prāpnoti iti avirodham āha atra ucyate iti  evam eka vākya tā samarthana prakaraṇa anugṛhīta para puruṣa śrutibhyām para brahma pratyabhijñayā brahma loka prāpti liṅgam bādhitvā vākyam praṇava dhyeye  /
translated: By meditating on the supreme Brahman in the syllable Om, one goes to the world of Brahman through the sun, sees the supreme Brahman, and attains that very peace, that supreme fearlessness. Thus, there is no contradiction. He says Here it is said.

analyzed: brahmaṇi samanvitam iti siddham  e ns
translated: Thus, by recognizing the supreme Brahman through the scriptural statements about the supreme person, which are supported by the context of establishing a single sentence, the indication of attaining the world of Brahman is contradicted, and the sentence is established as referring to Brahman, which is to be meditated upon in the syllable Om.🔽Thus, it is established.

analyzed: start
translated: End.

analyzed: dahara adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the subtle. Sutra.

analyzed: daharaḥ uttarebhyaḥ
translated: The subtle one is from the subsequent ones.

original: 'atha yadidamasminbrahmapure daharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma daharo 'sminnantarākāśastasminyadantastadanveṣṭavyaṃ tadbhāva vijijñāsitavyam' /
analyzed: atha yat idam asmin brahma pure daharam puṇḍarīkam veśma daharaḥ smin antarākāśaḥ tasmin yat antar tat anveṣṭavyam tad bhāva vijijñāsitavyam
translated: Now, this is the subtle lotus house in this city of Brahman. The subtle inner space within it, what is within that should be sought, that state should be desired to be known.

analyzed: chā ityādi vākyam samāmnāyate
translated: This and other such statements are recited.

original: tatra yo 'yaṃ dahare hṛdayapuṇrīke dahara ākāśaḥ śrutaḥ sa kiṃ bhūtākāśo 'thavā vijñānātmā'thavā paramātmeti saṃśayyate /
analyzed: tatra yaḥ yam dahare hṛdayapuṇrīke daharaḥ ākāśaḥ śrutaḥ sa kim vijñāna ātmā athavā paramātmā iti saṃśayyate
translated: There, the subtle space within the subtle lotus of the heart, which is heard, is doubted whether it is the elemental space, or the individual self, or the supreme self.

analyzed: kutas saṃśayaḥ
translated: From where does the doubt arise?

analyzed: ākāśa brahma pura śabdābhyām
translated: By the words 'space' and 'Brahma-city'.

original: ākāśaśabdo hyayaṃ bhūtākāśe parasmiṃśca prayujyamāno dṛśyate /
analyzed: ākāśa śabdaḥ hi ayam bhūtākāśe parasmin ca prayujyamānaḥ dṛśyate
translated: For this word 'space' is seen to be used for the elemental space and the supreme.

original: tatra kiṃ bhūtākāśa eva daharaḥ syātkiṃvā para iti saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: tatra kim bhūtākāśaḥ eva daharaḥ syāt kiṃvā paraḥ iti saṃśayaḥ
translated: There, is the small one only the elemental space, or is it the supreme? This is the doubt.

original: tathā brahmapuramiti kiṃ jīvo 'tra brahmanāmā tasyedaṃ puraṃ śarīraṃ brahmapuramathavā parasyaiva brahmaṇaḥ puraṃ brahmapuramiti /
analyzed: tathā brahmapuram iti kim tasya idam puram śarīram brahmapuram athavā parasya eva brahmaṇaḥ puram brahmapuram iti
translated: Similarly, 'Brahma-city' - is the individual soul named Brahma here, and this body is its city, a Brahma-city, or is it the city of the supreme Brahman itself, a Brahma-city?

original: tatra jīvasya parasya vānyatarasya purasvāmino daharākāśatve saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: tatra jīvasya parasya vā anyatarasya pura svāminaḥ daharākāśa tve saṃśayaḥ
translated: There, if the small space belongs to either the individual soul or the supreme one, who is the lord of the city, there is doubt.

original: tatrākāśaśabdasya bhūtākāśe rūḍhatvādbhūtākāśa eva daharaśabda iti prāptam /
analyzed: tatra ākāśa śabdasya bhūtākāśe rūḍha tvāt bhūtākāśaḥ eva dahara śabdaḥ iti prāptam
translated: There, since the word 'space' is well-established in the elemental space, the word 'small' refers to the elemental space itself.

analyzed: tasya ca dahara āyatana apekṣayā dahara tvam
translated: And that is small in relation to the small abode.

original: 'yāvānvā ayamākāśastāvāneṣo 'ntarhadaya ākāśaḥ' iti ca bāhyāyantarabhāvakṛtabhedasyopamānopameyabhāvaḥ dyāvāpṛthivyādi ca tasminnantaḥ samāhitaṃ /
analyzed: yāvān vai ayam ākāśaḥ tāvān eṣaḥ ntarhadayaḥ ākāśaḥ iti ca bāhya āyantara bhāva kṛta bhedasya upamāna upameya bhāvaḥ dyāvāpṛthivya ādi ca tasmin antar samāhitam
translated: And the relation of the compared and the standard is of the external and internal space, as in 'As great as this space is, so great is that space within the heart', and the earth, sky, etc. are contained within it.

analyzed: avakāśa ātmanā ākāśasya eka tvāt
translated: Because space is one in the nature of space.

analyzed: athavā jīvaḥ daharaḥ iti prāptam
translated: Or else, it is attained that the individual soul is the small one.

analyzed: brahma pura śabdāt
translated: From the word 'Brahma-city'.

analyzed: jīvasya hi idam puram sat śarīram brahma puram iti ucyate
translated: For this city of the individual soul, the body, is called the city of Brahman,

analyzed: tasya sva karmaṇā upārjita tvāt
translated: because it is acquired by his own actions.

analyzed: bhaktyā ca tasya brahma śabda vācya tvam
translated: And it is called Brahman by metonymy.

original: nahi parasya brahmaṇaḥ śarīreṇa svasvāmibhāvaḥ saṃbandho 'sti /
analyzed: nahi parasya brahmaṇaḥ śarīreṇa sva svāmi bhāvaḥ saṃbandhaḥ sti
translated: For the highest Brahman has no relation of master and servant with a body.

original: tatra purasvāminaḥ puraikadeśe 'vasthānaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā rājñaḥ /🔽manaupādhikaśca jīvaḥ /
analyzed: tatra pura svāminaḥ pura eka deśe dṛṣṭam yathā rājñaḥ  manaupādhikaḥ ca jīvaḥ
translated: For the staying of the lord of a city in a part of the city is seen, as of a king.🔽And the individual soul is conditioned by the mind.

original: manaśca prāyeṇa hṛdaye pratiṣṭhitamityato jīvasyaivedaṃ hṛdaye 'ntaravasthānaṃ syāt /
analyzed: manaḥ ca prāyeṇa hṛdaye pratiṣṭhitam iti atas jīvasya eva idam hṛdaye ntar avasthānam syāt
translated: And the mind is mostly situated in the heart. Therefore the staying of the individual soul in the heart would be.

analyzed: dahara tvam api tasya eva ārā agra upamita tvāt avakalpate
translated: And the smallness also is possible for it, because it is compared to the point of a needle.

analyzed: ākāśa upamita tva ādi ca brahma abheda vivakṣayā bhaviṣyati
translated: And the comparison with space, etc., will be because of the desire to show non-difference from Brahman.

analyzed: na ca atra daharasya ākāśasya anveṣya tvam vijijñāsitavya tvam ca śrūyate
translated: And here the small space is not heard to be sought or to be known by the desire to know.

analyzed: tasmin yat antar iti para viśeṣaṇa tvena upādānāt iti
translated: Because it is taken as a qualification of the highest Self in the words 'what is within it'.

original: ata uttaraṃ brūmaḥ parameśvara evātra daharākāśo bhavitumarhati na bhūtākāśo jīvo vā /
analyzed: atas uttaram brūmaḥ parameśvaraḥ eva atra daharākāśaḥ bhavitum arhati na bhūtākāśaḥ jīvaḥ vā
translated: To this we reply: The small space here must be the highest Lord, not the elemental space or the individual soul.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

original: uttarebhyo vākyaśeṣagatebhyo hetubhyaḥ /🔽tathāhi anveṣṭavyatayā vihitasya daharasyākāśasya 'taṃ cedbrūyuḥ' ityupakramya 'kiṃ
analyzed: uttarebhyaḥ vākyaśeṣa gatebhyaḥ hetubhyaḥ  tathā hi anveṣṭavya tayā vihitasya daharasya ākāśasya tam ced brūyuḥ iti upakramya kim
translated: Or from the reasons stated in the subsequent passages.

original: tadatra vidyate yadanveṣṭavyaṃ yadbhāva vijijñāsitavyam' ityevamākṣepapūrvakaṃ pratisamādhānavacanaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tat atra vidyate yat anveṣṭavyam yat bhāva vijijñāsitavyam iti evam ākṣepa pūrvakam pratisamādhāna vacanam bhavati
translated: For thus, with reference to the small ether which is enjoined to be sought after, there is a statement of reply preceded by a question, beginning with 'If they should say to him' (Ch. U. 8. 1. 1), 'what is it that is to be sought after here, what is that which is to be desired to be known?'

original: 'sa brūyādyavānvā ayamākāśastāvāneṣo 'ntarhṛdaya ākāśa ubhe asmindyāvāpṛthivī antareva samāhite' chā / / / ityādi /
analyzed: sa brūyāt yavān vai ayam ākāśaḥ tāvān eṣaḥ ntar hṛdaye ākāśaḥ ubhe asmin dyāvāpṛthivī antar eva samāhite chā ityādi
translated: 'He should say: As great as is this ether, so great is that ether within the heart; in it both heaven and earth are contained' (Ch. U. 8. 1. 2).

original: tatra puṇḍarīkadaharatvena prāptadaharatvasyākāśasya prasiddhākāśaupamyena daharatvaṃ nivartayanbhūtākāśatvaṃ daharasyākāśasya nivartayatīti 🔽gamyate /
analyzed: tatra puṇḍarīka dahara tvena prāpta dahara tvasya ākāśasya prasiddha ākāśa aupamyena dahara tvam nivartayan bhūtākāśa tvam daharasya ākāśasya nivartayati iti  gamyate
translated: There, by the smallness obtained through being in the small lotus, the smallness of the small ether is removed by the comparison with the well-known ether. Thus it is understood that the small ether is removed from being the elemental ether.

original: yadyapyākāśaśabdo bhūtākāśe rūḍhastathāpi tenaiva tasyopamā nopapadyata iti bhūtākāśaśaṅkā nivartitā bhavati /
analyzed: yadi api ākāśa śabdaḥ bhūtākāśe rūḍhaḥ tathā api tena eva tasya upamā na upapadyate iti bhūtākāśa śaṅkā nivartitā bhavati
translated: Although the word 'ether' is well-established in the elemental ether, still the comparison with it is not possible. Thus the doubt of its being the elemental ether is removed.

analyzed: nanu ekasya api ākāśasya bāhya abhyantara tva kalpitena bhedena upamāna upameya bhāvaḥ saṃbhavati iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that even one thing, the ether, can be the object compared to and the standard of comparison, by a difference imagined as external and internal.

analyzed: na evam saṃbhavati  agatikā hi iyam gatiḥ
translated: This is not possible.

analyzed: yat kālpanika bheda āśrayaṇam
translated: This is not a way of going, this way of going, which is based on a difference imagined.

original: apica kalpayitvāpi bhedamupamānopameyabhāvaṃ varṇayataḥ paricchinnatvādabhyantarākāśasya na bāhyākāśaparimāṇatvamupapadyeta /🔽nanu parameśvarasyāpi 'jyāyānākāśāt' śata / brā / / / /
analyzed: api ca kalpayitvā api bhedam upamāna upameya bhāvam varṇayataḥ paricchinna tvāt abhyantara ākāśasya na bāhya ākāśa parimāṇa tvam upapadyeta  nanu parameśvarasya api jyāyān ākāśāt
translated: Moreover, even if you imagine a difference, if you explain the relation of the object compared to and the standard of comparison, then because the internal ether is limited, it cannot be the size of the external ether.

analyzed: iti śruti antarāt na eva ākāśa parimāṇa tvam upapadyate
translated: But even for the Supreme Lord, because of another scriptural passage, 'greater than the ether', Shatapatha Brahmana 1.1.1.1, the size of the ether is not possible.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: puṇḍarīka veṣṭana prāpta dahara tva nivṛtti paratvāt vākyasya na tāvat tva pratipādana paratvam
translated: The sentence is not intended to convey the size of the ether, but rather to remove the smallness obtained by being enclosed in the lotus.

analyzed: ubhaya pratipādane hi vākyam bhidyeta
translated: For if it conveyed both, the sentence would be split.

analyzed: na ca kalpita bhede piṇḍarīka veṣṭite ākāśa eka deśe dyāvāpṛthivya ādīnām antar samādhānam upapadyate
translated: And even if a difference is imagined, it is not possible for heaven, earth, etc. to be contained within a part of the ether enclosed in the lotus.

original: 'eṣa ātmāpahatapāpmā vijaro vimṛtyurvīśoko vijighatso 'pipāsaḥ satyakāmaḥ satyasaṃkalpaḥ' iti cātmatvāpahatapāpmatvādayaśca guṇā na bhūtākāśe 🔽saṃbhavanti /
analyzed: eṣaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā vijaraḥ vimṛtyuḥ viśokaḥ vijighatsaḥ pipāsaḥ satya kāmaḥ satya saṃkalpaḥ iti ca ātma tva apahata pāpma tva ādayaḥ ca guṇāḥ na bhūta ākāśe  saṃbhavanti
translated: And the qualities of being the Self, being free from sin, being free from old age, being free from death, being free from sorrow, being free from hunger, being free from thirst, having true desires, having true resolves, are not possible in the elemental ether.

original: yadyapyātmaśabdo jīve saṃbhavati tathāpītarebhyaḥ kāraṇebhyo jīvāśaṅkāpi nivartitā bhavati /
analyzed: yadi api ātma śabdaḥ jīve saṃbhavati tathā api itarebhyaḥ kāraṇebhyaḥ jīva āśaṅkā api nivartitā bhavati
translated: Even though the word Self is possible in the individual soul, still the suspicion of the individual soul is also removed by the other reasons.

original: nahyupādhiparicchinnasyārāgropamitasya jīvasya puṇḍarīkaveṣṭhanakṛtaṃ daharatvaṃ śakyaṃ nivartayitum /🔽brahmābhedavivakṣayā jīvasya sarvagatatvādi vivakṣyeteti cet /
analyzed: nahi upādhi paricchinnasya arā agra upamitasya jīvasya puṇḍarīka veṣṭhana kṛtam dahara tvam śakyam nivartayitum  brahma abheda vivakṣayā jīvasya sarvagata tva ādi vivakṣyeta iti ced
translated: For it is not possible to remove the smallness of the individual soul, which is limited by the limiting adjuncts and is compared to the tip of a hair, and is due to being enclosed in the lotus of the heart.🔽If it is argued that the all-pervasiveness etc. of the individual soul are intended to be stated by the desire for non-difference from Brahman,

original: yadātmatayā jīvasya sarvagatatvādi vivakṣyeta tasyaiva brahmaṇaḥ sākṣātsarvagatatvādivivakṣyatāmiti yuktam /
analyzed: yad ātma tayā jīvasya sarvagata tva ādi vivakṣyeta tasya eva brahmaṇaḥ sākṣāt sarvagata tva ādi vivakṣyatām iti yuktam

original: kiñca hārdākāśasyāntaratvātyāge alpatvena vyāpakabāhyākāśasādṛśyaṃ na yuktamityāhaapiceti /

translated: Moreover, if the internal nature of the heart-space is abandoned, its similarity to the all-pervading external space cannot be proper due to its smallness. Thus he says 'Moreover'.

analyzed: āntara tva tyāge tu atyanta abhedāt na sādṛśyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: If the internal nature is abandoned, there cannot be similarity due to absolute non-difference, this is the idea.

original: nanu hārdākāśasyālpatvanivṛttau tāvattve ca tātparyaṃ kiṃ na syādityata āhaubhayeti /
analyzed: nanu hārda ākāśasya alpatva nivṛttau tāvattve ca tātparyam kim na syāt iti atas āha aubhaya iti
translated: But might there not be the purport of the removal of smallness and the establishment of largeness in the case of the heart-space? To this he says 'both'.

analyzed: atas lpau anivṛttau eva tātparyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the purport is only in the removal of smallness, this is the idea.

analyzed: evam ākāśa upamita tvāt dahara ākāśaḥ na bhūtam iti uktam
translated: Thus it has been said that the subtle space is not an element because it is compared to space.

analyzed: sarva āśraya tva ādi liṅgebhyaḥ ca tathā iti āha na ca ityādinā
translated: And because of the reasons such as being the support of all, he says 'And that' etc.

original: vigatā jighatsā jagdhumicchā yasya so 'yaṃ vijighatsaḥ /
analyzed: vigatā jighatsā jagdhum icchā yasya saḥ yam vijighatsaḥ
translated: He who is free from hunger, the desire to eat, is called 'vigatadhṛṣṇu'.

analyzed: bubhukṣā śūnyaḥ iti arthaḥ  prathama śruta brahma śabdena tad sāpekṣa carama śruta ṣaṣṭhī vibhakti arthaḥ saṃbandhaḥ neyaḥ
translated: The meaning is 'devoid of hunger'.🔽The meaning of the sixth case ending, which depends on that, should be taken as the relation, by the word Brahman heard first.

original: na tu brahmaṇaḥ puramiti ṣaṣṭhyarthaḥ svasvāmibhāvo grāhyaḥ 'nirapekṣeṇa tatsāpekṣaṃ bādhyam'iti nyāyādityāhaatra brūma iti /
analyzed: na tu brahmaṇaḥ puram iti ṣaṣṭhī arthaḥ sva svāmi bhāvaḥ grāhyaḥ nirapekṣeṇa tat sāpekṣam bādhyam iti nyāyāt iti āha atra brūmaḥ iti
translated: But the relation of master and owned, which is the meaning of the sixth case ending 'of Brahman's city', should not be accepted, because 'that which depends on this is contradicted by that which does not depend on it', according to the rule. Thus he says 'Here we say' etc.

original: śarīrasya brahmaṇa tadupalabdhisthānatvarūpe saṃbandhe mānamāhasa iti /
analyzed: śarīrasya brahmaṇaḥ tad upalabdhi sthāna tva rūpe saṃbandhe mānam āha saḥ iti
translated: As to the relation of the body to Brahman, which consists in the latter being the place of the former's perception, he states the proof thus: 'He' etc.

analyzed: pūrṣu śarīreṣu
translated: In the former bodies.

original: puri hṛdaye śaya iti puruṣa ityanvayaḥ /
analyzed: puri hṛdaye śaye iti puruṣaḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that He lies in the city, i.e., the heart.

original: nanu brahmaśabdasya jīve 'pyannādinā śarīravṛddhihetau mukhyatvānna ṣaṣṭhyarthaḥ kathañcinneya ityata āhaathaveti /
analyzed: nanu brahma śabdasya jīve pi anna ādinā śarīra vṛddhi hetau mukhya tvāt na ṣaṣṭhī arthaḥ kathañcid neyaḥ iti atas āha athavā iti
translated: But since the word Brahman primarily denotes the individual soul, which is the cause of the growth of the body by food etc., the sixth case ending cannot be explained in any way. To this he says 'Or else' etc.

original: bṛṃhayati dehamiti brahma jīvaḥ tatsvāmike pure hṛdayaṃ brahmaveśma bhavatu /
analyzed: bṛṃhayati deham iti brahma jīvaḥ tad svāmike pure hṛdayam brahmaveśma bhavatu
translated: The individual soul, which nourishes the body, is Brahman. Let the house of Brahman be the heart in the city belonging to it.

analyzed: rāja pure maitra sadbhavat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is like the house of a friend in a royal city.

analyzed: ananta phala liṅgāt api daharaḥ paramātmā iti āha tat yathā iti
translated: From the indication of infinite fruit also, the small one is the supreme Self. Thus he says 'That as' etc.

original: atha karmaphalādvaurāgyānantaramiha jīvadaśāyāmātmānaṃ daharaṃ tadāśritāṃśca satyakāmādiguṇān
analyzed: atha karma phalāt vaurāgya anantaram iha jīva daśāyām ātmānam daharam tad āśritān ca satya kāma ādi guṇān
translated: Then, after detachment from the fruits of action, in this life as an individual soul, having realized by meditation the small Self and the qualities like having true desires dependent on it,

original: ācāryopadeśamanuvidya dhyānenānubhūya ye paralokaṃ gacchanti teṣāṃ sarvalokeṣvanantamaiśvaryaṃ
analyzed: ācārya upadeśam anuvidya dhyānena anubhūya ye para lokam gacchanti teṣām sarva lokeṣu anantam aiśvaryam
translated: and having understood the teaching of the teacher, those who go to the next world, for them there is infinite lordship in all the worlds.

analyzed: sva icchayā saṃcalana ādikam bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they have the power to move about etc. as they wish.

original: dahare uktaliṅgānyanyathāsiddhāni teṣāṃ tadantaḥsthaguṇatvādiyuktaṃ smārayitvā dūṣayatiyadapītyādinā /
analyzed: dahare ukta liṅgāni anyathā siddhāni teṣām tad antar stha guṇa tva ādi yuktam smārayitvā dūṣayati yat api ityādinā
translated: The marks mentioned in the Dhara chapter are refuted by showing that they are otherwise established, and by showing that they are connected with the qualities of what is within it, with the words And that also... etc.

analyzed: uttaratra ākāśa svarūpa pratipādana anyathā anupapattyā pūrvam tasya anveṣya tva ādikam iti atra anyathā upapattim śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: He doubts the other possibility here, with the non-applicability of the teaching of the nature of space later on, that its being sought after etc. is earlier, with the words But... etc.

analyzed: etat ākāśa svarūpam
translated: This is the nature of space.

analyzed: ākṣepa bījam ākāśasya alpatvam upamayā nirasya antar stha vastu ukteḥ tad antar stham eva dhyeyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The seed of the objection is that the smallness of space is to be refuted by a simile, and that what is said to be within it is to be meditated upon as within it.

analyzed: tarhi jagat eva dhyeyam syāt iti āha na etat evam iti
translated: Then the world itself would be the object of meditation. He says This is not so etc.

analyzed: astu kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: Let it be so. What is the fault?

analyzed: tatra āha tatra iti
translated: There he says There... etc.

original: sarvanāmabhyāṃ daharākāśamākṛṣyātmatvādiguṇānuktvā guṇaiḥ saha tasyaiva dhyeyatvaṃ vākyaśeṣo brūte tadvirodha ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: sarvanāmabhyām daharākāśam ākṛṣya ātma tva ādi guṇān uktvā guṇaiḥ saha tasya eva dhyeya tvam vākyaśeṣaḥ brūte tad virodhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Having drawn in the subtle space by the two pronouns, and having mentioned the qualities of self etc., the remainder of the sentence says that it alone is to be meditated upon along with the qualities. The meaning is that there is a contradiction with that.

original: 'tasmin yadantaḥ'iti tatpadena vyavahitamapi hṛdayaṃ yogyatayā grāhyamityāhatasmāditi /
analyzed: tasmin yat antar iti tad padena vyavahitam api hṛdayam yogyatayā grāhyam iti āha tasmāt iti
translated: By the word tat (that), even though separated, the heart is to be taken by suitability. He says Therefore... etc.

analyzed: yat vai ākāśaḥ tasmin yat antar tat ubhayam anveṣṭavyam iti yojanām sūcayati saha antar sthaiḥ iti
translated: Or else, the meaning is that the ether is that in which the small ether is contained, and that which is contained in it, both of these should be sought for. This is indicated by the word 'along with' (in the text).🔽End.

analyzed: e ns  start
translated: Start.

original: gatiśabdābhyāṃ tathā hi dṛṣṭaṃ liṅgaṃ ca / / / /
analyzed: gati śabdābhyām tathā hi dṛṣṭam liṅgam ca
translated: By the words 'going' and 'sound', and also because such is the indication.

analyzed: daharaḥ parameśvaraḥ uttarebhyaḥ hetubhyaḥ iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the small one is the supreme Lord, on the basis of the subsequent reasons.

analyzed: te eva uttare hetavaḥ idānīm prapañcyante
translated: Those very subsequent reasons are now being elaborated.

analyzed: itas ca parameśvaraḥ eva daharaḥ
translated: And for this reason also, the small one is the supreme Lord.

original: yasmāddaharavākyaśeṣe parameśvarasyaiva pratipādakau gatiśabdau bhavataḥ 'imāḥ sarvāḥ prajā aharahargacchantya etaṃ brahmalokaṃ na vindanti'
analyzed: yasmāt dahara vākya śeṣe parameśvarasya eva pratipādakau gati śabdau bhavataḥ imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ ahar ahar gacchantyaḥ etam brahma lokam na vindanti
translated: Because in the remainder of the passage about the small one, the words 'going' and 'sound' indicate the supreme Lord himself, as it is said: 'All these creatures go day after day to that world of Brahman, but do not find it.'

analyzed: chā iti
translated: Chandogya Upanishad 8.1.2.

original: tatra prakṛtaṃ daharaṃ brahmalokaśabdenābhidhāya tadviṣayā gatiḥ prajāśabdavācyānāṃ jīvānāmabhidhīyamānā daharasya brahmatāṃ gamayati /
analyzed: tatra prakṛtam daharam brahma loka śabdena abhidhāya tad viṣayā gatiḥ prajā śabda vācyānām jīvānām abhidhīyamānā daharasya brahma tām gamayati
translated: There, having referred to the small one as the subject, by the word 'world of Brahman', the going to it, which is spoken of as the going of the souls denoted by the word 'creatures', indicates that the small one is Brahman.

original: tathā hyaharaharjīvānāṃ suṣuptavasthāyāṃ brahmaviṣayaṃ gamanaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ śrutyantare 'satā somya tadā saṃpanno bhavati' chā / / /
analyzed: tathā hi aharahar jīvānām suṣupta vasthāyām brahma viṣayam gamanam dṛṣṭam śruti antare satā somya tadā saṃpannaḥ bhavati chā
translated: For in another Upanishad, the going of the souls to Brahman is seen in the state of deep sleep of the souls day after day, as in the following passage: 'Then, my dear, he becomes united with the non-existent.' Chandogya Upanishad 6.8.1.

analyzed: iti evamādau
translated: And so on.

original: loke 'pi kila gāḍhaṃ suṣuptamācakṣate brahmībhūto brahmatāṃ gata iti /
analyzed: loke kila gāḍham suṣuptam ācakṣate brahmībhūtaḥ brahma tām gataḥ iti
translated: In the world also they say that one who is deeply asleep is absorbed in Brahman, has become Brahman.

original: tathā brahmalokaśabdo 'pi prakṛte dahare prayujyamāno jīvabhūtākāśaśaṅkāṃ nivartayanbrahmatāmasya gamayati /
analyzed: tathā brahma loka śabdaḥ pi prakṛte dahare prayujyamānaḥ jīva bhūta ākāśa śaṅkām nivartayan brahma tām asya gamayati
translated: So also the word Brahman-world, when used with reference to the small ether, removes the suspicion of the small ether being the individual soul, and points to its being Brahman.

original: nanu kamalāsanalokamapi brahmalokaśabdo gamayet /🔽gamayedyadi brahmaṇo loka iti ṣaṣṭhīsamāsavṛttyā vyutpādyeta /
analyzed: nanu kamalāsana lokam api brahma loka śabdaḥ gamayet  gamayet yadi brahmaṇaḥ loke iti ṣaṣṭhī samāsa vṛttyā vyutpādyeta
translated: But the word Brahman-world may also denote the world of the lotus-navelled one (Visnu).🔽It would do so if it were explained by the genitive compound Brahman's world.

original: sāmānādhikaraṇavṛttyā tu vyutpādyamāno brahmaiva loko brahmaloka iti parameva brahma gamayiṣyati /
analyzed: sāmānādhikaraṇa vṛttyā tu vyutpādyamānaḥ brahma eva lokaḥ brahma lokaḥ iti param eva brahma gamayiṣyati
translated: But when explained by the co-ordinate compound, Brahman itself is the world, Brahman-world, it will point to the highest Brahman only.

original: etadeva cāhararbrahmalokagamanaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ brahmaśabdasya sāmānādhikaraṇyavṛttiparigrahe liṅgam /
analyzed: etat eva ca aharaḥ brahma loka gamanam dṛṣṭam brahma śabdasya sāmānādhikaraṇya vṛtti parigrahe liṅgam
translated: This very going to the Brahman-world every day is the reason for taking the word Brahman in the co-ordinate compound.

original: nahyaharaharimāḥ prajāḥ kāryabrahmalokaṃ satyalokākhyaṃ gacchantīti śakyaṃ kalpayitum // //
analyzed: na hi ahar ahar imāḥ prajāḥ kārya brahma lokam satya loka ākhyam gacchanti iti śakyam kalpayitum
translated: For it is not possible to imagine that the people go every day to the world called Satyaloka, which is the world of the effect Brahman.

analyzed: daharākāśasya brahmatve hetu āntaram āha gati iti
translated: As a reason for the small ether being Brahman, he says: because of the going, etc.

original: prajā jīvā etaṃ hṛdayasthaṃ daharaṃ brahmasvarūpaṃ lokamaharahaḥ pratyahaṃ svāpe gacchantyastadātmanā sthitā apyanṛtājñānenāvṛtāstaṃ na jānanti
analyzed: prajāḥ jīvāḥ etam hṛdaya stham daharam brahma svarūpam lokam aharahar pratyaham svāpe gacchantyaḥ tad ātmanā sthitāḥ api anṛta ajñānena āvṛtāḥ tam na jānanti  /
translated: The creatures, the living beings, go to that world, that small Brahman-form situated in the heart, every day, in sleep; though remaining in that form, they do not know it, being covered by untruth and ignorance.

analyzed: atas punar uttiṣṭhanti iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is, they rise up again.

original: nanvetatpadaparāmṛṣṭadaharasya svāpe jīvagamyatve 'pi brahmatve kimāyātamityaśaṅkya 'tathā hi dṛṣṭam'iti vyācaṣṭetathā hīti /
analyzed: nanu etad pada parāmṛṣṭa daharasya svāpe jīva gamya tve pi brahmatve kim āyātam iti aśaṅkya tathā hi dṛṣṭam iti vyācaṣṭe tathā hi iti
translated: If the small one referred to by the word is accessible to the individual soul in sleep, what is the implication of its being Brahman? Anticipating this doubt, he explains thus: 'For thus it is seen'.

analyzed: loke dṛṣṭam iti artha antaram āha loke pi iti
translated: He states another meaning: 'For thus it is seen in the world also'.

analyzed: gati liṅgam vyākhyāya śabdam vyācaṣṭe tathā iti
translated: Having explained the indication of motion, he explains the word thus: 'Thus'.

analyzed: jīva bhūta ākāśayoḥ brahma loka śabdasya aprasiddheḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the word 'Brahmaloka' is not well-known for the individual soul and the ether of the individual soul.

analyzed: brahmaṇi api tasya aprasiddhim śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: He doubts that it is not well-known even for Brahman: 'But how is it known for Brahman?'

analyzed: niṣāda sthapati nyāyena samādhatte gamayet iti
translated: He resolves it by the principle of the chief of the Nishadas: 'It may be known'.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭhe cintitam sva patiḥ niṣādaḥ
translated: It has been considered in the sixth: The chief of the Nishadas.

analyzed: śabda sāmarthyāt
translated: By the force of the word.

analyzed: raudrīm iṣṭim vidhāya etayā niṣāda sthapatim yājaya iti iti āmnāyate
translated: Having enjoined the Raudri sacrifice, it is stated: 'By this, one should sacrifice for the chief of the Nishadas'.

original: tatra niṣādānāṃ sthapatiḥ svāmīti ṣaṣṭhīsamāsena traivarṇiko grāhyaḥ /
analyzed: tatra niṣādānām sthapatiḥ svāmī iti ṣaṣṭhī samāsena traivarṇikaḥ grāhyaḥ
translated: There, the word 'sthapaka' in the compound 'niṣādasthapatiḥ' should be taken to mean a member of the three higher castes, not a Niṣāda, because of the impossibility of a Niṣāda performing the duties of a priest.

analyzed: agni vidyā ādi sāmarthyāt
translated: Because of his ability in the knowledge of fire and other matters.

original: na tu niṣādaścāsau sthapatiriti karmadhārayeṇa niṣādo grāhyaḥ /
analyzed: na tu niṣādaḥ ca asau sthapatiḥ iti karmadhārayeṇa niṣādaḥ grāhyaḥ
translated: But the word 'niṣāda' should not be taken to mean a Niṣāda in the karmadhāraya compound 'niṣādaḥ sthapakaḥ'.

analyzed: asāmarthyāt iti prāpte siddhāntaḥ
translated: When this is argued, the final conclusion is:

analyzed: niṣādaḥ eva sthapatiḥ syāt
translated: The Niṣāda alone should be the sthapaka.

analyzed: niṣāda śabdasya niṣāde śakta tvāt
translated: Because the word 'niṣāda' is capable of denoting a Niṣāda.

analyzed: tasya aśruta ṣaṣṭhī artha saṃbandha lakṣaka tu alpanā yogāt śruta dvitīyā vibhakteḥ pūrva pada saṃbandha kalpanāyām lāghavāt
translated: Because it is not proper to assume that the unmentioned genitive case relation is denoted by it, it is simpler to assume the relation of the mentioned instrumental case with the preceding word.

analyzed: atas niṣādasya iṣṭi sāmarthya mātram kalpyam iti
translated: Therefore, only the ability of the Niṣāda to perform the sacrifice is to be assumed.

analyzed: tad brahma loka śabde karmadhārayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the word 'brahmaloka' is a karmadhāraya compound.

analyzed: karmadhāraye liṅgam ca asti iti vyācaṣṭe etat eva iti
translated: And there is a grammatical gender in the karmadhāraya compound. This is what is explained by the words 'this alone'.

analyzed: sūtre cakāraḥ ukta nyāya samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: And in the sutra, the word 'ca' is for the purpose of combining the stated reasons.🔽End.

analyzed: e ns  start  dhṛteḥ ca mahimnaḥ sya asmin upalabdheḥ
translated: Start.🔽And because of the mention of His sustaining power in this (Upanisad).

analyzed: dhṛteḥ ca hetoḥ parameśvaraḥ eva ayam daharaḥ
translated: For the following reason also the small ether can be the highest Lord only.

analyzed: katham
translated: How so?

original: 'daharo 'sminnantarākāśaḥ' iti hi prakṛtyākāśaupamyapūrvakaṃ tasminsarvasamādhānamuktvā🔽tāṃ sminneva cātmaśabdaṃ prayujyāpahatapāpmatvādiguṇayogaṃ copaduśya tamevānativṛttaprakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: daharaḥ smin antarākāśaḥ iti hi prakṛti ākāśa aupamya pūrvakam tasmin sarva samādhānam uktvā  tām smin eva ca ātma śabdam prayujya apahata pāpma tva ādi guṇa yogam ca upaduśya tam eva an ativṛtta prakaraṇam
translated: For the text, after having declared that the small ether is the place of the final resolution of all things, by a comparison with the ether, and

translated: after having applied to it the term Self and the attributes of being free from sin and so on, again refers to it in the passage, That Self is a dam, a support, for the nondisintegration of these worlds, which passage belongs to the same context as the preceding ones🔽In the passage quoted the word dam is used in the sense of a supporter, because the word Self is used in apposition to it

analyzed: kticaḥ kartari smaraṇāt
translated: For the causative form dhārayati is known to denote the agent of an action

analyzed: yathā udaka saṃtānasya vidhārayitā loke setuḥ kṣetra saṃpadām a saṃbhedāya
translated: Just as a dam in the world is a support for the stream of water, in order that the fields may not be overflowed,

analyzed: evam ayam ātmā ātmā eṣām adhyātma ādi bheda bhinnānām lokānām varṇa āśrama ādīnām ca vidhāritā setuḥ a saṃbhedāya a saṃkarāya iti
translated: so this Self is a dam for the worlds, which are divided into the internal Self and so on, and for the castes, the āśramas and so on, in order that they may not be confounded, may not be mixed

original: evamiha prakṛte dahare vidhāraṇalakṣaṇaṃ mahimānaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: evam iha prakṛte dahare vidhāraṇa lakṣaṇam mahimānam darśayati
translated: In this way the text declares that the greatness of the small ether under discussion consists in its being a dam

original: ayaṃ ca mahimā parameśvara eva śrutyantarādupalabhyate 'etasya vā akṣarasya praśāsane gārgi sūryācandramasau vidhṛtau tiṣṭhataḥ' ityādeḥ /
