analyzed: sthirāṇi gati ādi sāmānyāni krama viśeṣavanti gṛhīta saṃgatikāni artha bodhakāni iti kḷpteṣu sāmānyeṣu prakriyā saṃcārayitavyā na tu akḷptaḥ sphoṭaḥ  /
translated: The sequence of the universal of going, etc., which are permanent, is grasped with a particular sequence and conveys meaning. The procedure should be transferred to the established universals, but not to the unestablished sphoṭa.

analyzed: kalpanīyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is to be imagined.

analyzed: varṇānām sthāyi tva vācaka tvayoḥ siddhau phalitam āha tatas ca iti
translated: Having established the permanence and denotativeness of the letters, he states the conclusion: And from that, etc.🔽End.

analyzed: śarvarī ante prasūtānām tāni eva ebhyaḥ dadāti ajaḥ  yathā ṛtuṣu ṛtu liṅgāni nānā rūpāṇi paryaye
translated: At the end of the night, the unborn one gives them to those born.🔽Just as the signs of the seasons are seen to be of various forms in succession,

original: dṛśyante tāni tānyeva tathā bhāvā yugādiṣu //🔽yathābhimānino 'tītāstulyaste sāṃpratairiha /
analyzed: dṛśyante tāni tāni eva tathā bhāvāḥ yuga ādiṣu  yathā abhimāninaḥ tītāḥ tulyaḥ te sāṃprataiḥ iha
translated: so are the states in the beginning of the yugas.🔽Just as the past gods were conceited, they are the same as the present ones here.

analyzed: devāḥ devaiḥ atātaiḥ hi rūpaiḥ nāmabhiḥ eva ca
translated: For the gods are the same in form and name as the past gods.

analyzed: iti eva jātīyakā draṣṭavyā  /

analyzed: abhidhātṛ śabdena adhyāpaka adhyetārau uktau
translated: The word abhidhātr refers to both the teacher and the student.

analyzed: tadā api mahāpralaya mahā sarga aṅgīkāre pi iti yāvat
translated: Even then, even if one accepts the great dissolution and the great creation, that is what is meant by tadayāpi.

analyzed: yadā ipi upakramāt athaśabdaḥ tadā iti arthaḥ
translated: When the word atha is used in the beginning, that is the meaning.

original: prāṇaḥ paramātmā tatra jīva ekībhavati enaṃ prāṇaṃ sa jīvaḥ tadaitīti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: prāṇaḥ paramātmā tatra jīvaḥ ekībhavati enam prāṇam sa jīvaḥ tadā eti iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The individual soul becomes one with the supreme self, the vital breath. The individual soul goes to that vital breath, this is the remainder.

analyzed: tasmāt prāṇa ātmanaḥ
translated: Therefore, from the vital breath-self.

analyzed: āyatanam golakam
translated: The abode is the body.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ yadi api iti anena saṃbadhyate
translated: The word iti is connected with although.

analyzed: hiraṇya garbhaḥ samavartata ityādayaḥ śruti vādāḥ
translated: The Vedic statements beginning with Hiranyagarbha was born first are the Vedic statements.

analyzed: jñānam apratimam yasya ityādayaḥ smṛti vādāḥ
translated: The Smriti statements beginning with He whose knowledge is incomparable are the Smriti statements.

analyzed: prahiṇoti gamayati tasya buddhau vedanā āvirbhāvayati
translated: He sends, he causes to go, he makes the feeling manifest in the intellect of that person.

original: ṛgvedo daśamaṇḍalātmakaḥ maṇḍalānāṃ daśatayamātrāstīti tatra bhavā ṛco dāśatayyaḥ /
analyzed: ṛgvedaḥ daśa maṇḍala ātmakaḥ maṇḍalānām daśataya mātrā asti iti tatra bhavāḥ ṛcaḥ dāśatayyaḥ
translated: The Ṛg Veda consists of ten books. The Ṛc verses occurring in those ten books are called Ṛc verses of ten books.

analyzed: arṣeyaḥ ṛṣi yogaḥ
translated: Arṣeya means connection with Ṛṣis.

analyzed: chandaḥ gāyatrī ādi
translated: Chandas means Gāyatrī and other meters.

analyzed: daivata agni ādi
translated: Daivata means Agni and other deities.

analyzed: brāhmaṇam viniyogaḥ etāni a viditāni yasmin mantre
translated: Brāhmaṇa means application. That mantra in which these are unknown.

analyzed: sthāṇum sthāvaram
translated: Sthāṇu means immobile.

analyzed: gartam narakam
translated: Garta means hell.

analyzed: teṣām prāṇinām madhye
translated: Among those beings.

analyzed: tāni eva tad jātīyāni eva
translated: Those very same of that same kind.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭha indriyam manaḥ manaḥ ṣaṣṭhāni indriyāṇi iti smṛteḥ
translated: The sixth sense is the mind, as stated in the Smṛti: The senses are six, with the mind as the sixth.

analyzed: nakṣatra bahutvāt bahuvacanam kṛttikā devāya agnaye
translated: The plural is used because there are many constellations. To Agni, the lord of the Kṛttikās, etc.

analyzed: aṣṭasu kapāleṣu pacanīyam haviḥ niruptavān
translated: He has offered the oblation to be cooked on eight potsherds.

analyzed: deveṣu iti viṣaya saptamī  śarvarī ante pralaya ante  ṛtuḥ liṅgāni nava pallava ādīni
translated: Among the gods. The locative case refers to the object.🔽At the end of the night, at the end of the dissolution.🔽The signs are the new sprouts, etc.

analyzed: paryaye ghaṭīyantra vat āvṛttau
translated: In the return, in the revolution like a waterwheel.

analyzed: bhāvāḥ padārthāḥ
translated: The things are the objects.

analyzed: nanu mahāpralaye jāteḥ api asattvāt śabda artha saṃbandha anitya tvam iti āśaṅkya āha samāna iti
translated: Now, if it is argued that the relation between word and meaning is impermanent because the universal also does not exist at the time of the great dissolution, he says the same and so on.

analyzed: sūtra nirasyām śaṅkām āha atha api iti
translated: He states the doubt to be removed by the aphorism: Even if and so on.

analyzed: vyakti saṃtatyā jātīnām avāntara pralaye sattvāt saṃbandhaḥ tiṣṭhati
translated: The connection [between the eternal word and its meaning] remains, because the universals of the words exist in the intermediate dissolution by means of the continuity of the individualities.

original: vyavahārāvicchedājjñāyate ceti vedasyānapekṣatvena prāmāṇye na kaścidvirodhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: vyavahāra avicchedāt jñāyate ca iti vedasya anapekṣa tvena prāmāṇye na kaścid virodhaḥ syāt
translated: And it is known from the uninterruptedness of usage. Thus, if the Veda were authoritative without dependence [on anything else], there would be no contradiction at all.

original: nirlepalaye tu saṃbandhanāśāt punaḥ sṛṣṭau kenacitpuṃsā saṃketaḥ kartavya iti puruṣabuddhisāpekṣatvena vedasyāprāmāṇyaṃ /
analyzed: nirlepa laye tu saṃbandha nāśāt punar sṛṣṭau kenacid puṃsā saṃketaḥ kartavyaḥ iti puruṣa buddhi sāpekṣa tvena vedasya aprāmāṇyam
translated: But in the case of a dissolution without residue, due to the destruction of the connection, the convention would have to be made by some person again at the time of creation. Thus, the Veda would be non-authoritative due to its dependence on the human intellect.

analyzed: adhyāpakasya āśrayasya nāśāt āśritasya tasya anitya tvam ca prāptam iti arthaḥ
translated: And it would follow that it is impermanent, because its substratum, the teacher, is destroyed. This is the meaning.

analyzed: mahāpralaye pi nirlepa layaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: Even in the great dissolution, a dissolution without residue is not established.

analyzed: satkārya vādāt
translated: Because of the doctrine of the pre-existence of the effect in the cause.

original: tathāca saṃskārātmanā śabdārthatatsaṃbandhānāṃ satāmeva punaḥ sṛṣṭāvabhivyakternānityatvam /
analyzed: tathā ca saṃskāra ātmanā śabda artha tad saṃbandhānām satām eva punar sṛṣṭau abhivyakteḥ na anitya tvam
translated: And thus, the word, its meaning, and their relation, which exist in the form of impressions, are manifested again at the time of creation, and therefore are not impermanent.

analyzed: abhivyaktānām pūrva kalpīya nāma rūpa samāna tvāt na saṃketaḥ kenacid kāryaḥ
translated: And because the names and forms of this creation are the same as those of the previous creation, no convention needs to be made by anyone.

original: viṣamasṛṣṭau hi saṃketāpekṣā na tulyasṛṣṭāviti pariharatitatredamityādinā /
analyzed: viṣama sṛṣṭau hi saṃketa apekṣā na tulya sṛṣṭau iti pariharati tatra idam ityādinā
translated: For in an unequal creation, there would be a need for convention, but not in an equal creation. This is the reply. Therein, this, etc.

analyzed: nanu ādya sṛṣṭau saṃketaḥ kenacid kāryaḥ iti atas āha tadā api iti
translated: But if it is asked who made the convention in the first creation, he says even then, etc.

analyzed: mahā sarga pralaya pravṛttau api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even at the time of the great creation and dissolution.

original: nanvastvanādisaṃsāre saṃbandhasyānāditvaṃ tathāpi mahāpralayavyavadhānādasmaraṇe kathaṃ vedārthavyavahāraḥ /
analyzed: nanu astu anādi saṃsāre saṃbandhasya anādi tvam tathā api mahāpralaya vyavadhānāt asmaraṇe katham veda artha vyavahāraḥ
translated: But even if the connection is beginningless in the beginningless worldly existence, how can there be usage of the meaning of the Veda when it is not remembered due to the obstruction of the great dissolution?

analyzed: tatra āha anādau ca iti
translated: To that, he says in the beginningless etc.

analyzed: na kaścid virodhaḥ
translated: There is no contradiction at all.

analyzed: śabda artha saṃbandha smaraṇa ādeḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: due to the remembrance of the connection between word and meaning.

analyzed: svāpa prabodhayoḥ laya sarga asiddhim āśaṅkya śrutim āha svāpa iti
translated: Fearing that the arising and dissolution are not established in sleep and waking, he quotes the scripture in sleep etc.

original: atha tadā suṣuptau prāṇe paramātmani jīva ekībhavati enaṃ prāṇaṃ sa jīvaḥ tadaitīti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: atha tadā suṣuptau prāṇe paramātmani jīvaḥ ekībhavati enam prāṇam sa jīvaḥ tadā eti iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Then, in that sleep, the individual self becomes one with the supreme self in the vital breath. The individual self goes to that vital breath - this is the remainder.

analyzed: etasmāt prātmanaḥ
translated: From this self.

analyzed: āyatanam golakam
translated: The abode is the body.

analyzed: ānantarye pañcamī ityādyā draṣṭavyā
translated: The fifth case is to be seen in the sense of immediacy.

original: svapnavatkalpitasyājñātasattvābhāvāt darśanaṃ sṛṣṭiḥ adarśanaṃ laya iti dṛṣṭisṛṣṭipakṣaḥ śrutyabhipreta iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svapna vat kalpitasya ajñāta sattva abhāvāt darśanam sṛṣṭiḥ adarśanam layaḥ iti dṛṣṭi sṛṣṭi pakṣaḥ śruti abhipretaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the view that creation is seeing and dissolution is non-seeing is the view intended by the scripture, because the imagined is not known to exist like in a dream.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta vaiṣamyam āśaṅkya pariharati syāt ityādinā
translated: Fearing the inequality of the example, he answers with it may be etc.

analyzed: aviruddham anusandhāna ādikam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: the remembrance etc. is not contradictory.

analyzed: hiraṇyagarbha ādayaḥ pūrva kalpa anusaṃdhāna śūnyaḥ
translated: Hiraṇyagarbha and others are devoid of the remembrance of the previous kalpa.

analyzed: saṃsāri tvāt  asmāt āt iva iti āśaṅkya āha yadi api iti
translated: Because of being in the cycle of birth and death.🔽Fearing the objection that If this is so, then how can there be remembrance of the past birth?, he says Even though this is so, etc.

original: iti yadyapi tathāpi na prākṛtavaditi yojanā /
analyzed: iti yadi api tathā api na prākṛta vat iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: Even though this is so, still it is not like the ordinary person.

analyzed: jñāna ādeḥ nikarṣa vat utkarṣaḥ pi aṅgīkāryaḥ
translated: The superiority of knowledge, etc. must also be accepted, like the inferiority.

original: bādhābhāvāditi nyāyānugṛhītaśrutyādibhiḥ sāmānyato dṛṣṭānumānaṃ bādhyamityāhayathā hītyādinā /
analyzed: bādhā abhāvāt iti nyāya anugṛhīta śruti ādibhiḥ sāmānyatas dṛṣṭa anumānam bādhyam iti āha yathā hi ityādinā
translated: The inference based on general observation is to be refuted by the scriptures, etc. supported by the reasoning of the absence of contradiction. He says Just as, etc.

original: nanu tathāpi pūrvakalpeśvarāṇāṃ muktatvādasminkalpe ko 'nusaṃdhātetyata āhatataśceti /
analyzed: nanu tathā api pūrva kalpa īśvarāṇām mukta tvāt asmin kalpe kaḥ nusaṃdhātā iti atas āha tatas ca iti
translated: But even then, since the Lords of the previous Kalpa are liberated, who remembers in this Kalpa? To this he says And from that, etc.

analyzed: jñāna ādi utkarṣāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: from the superiority of knowledge, etc.

analyzed: muktebhyaḥ nye nusaṃdhātāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that others than the liberated ones are the rememberers.

analyzed: parameśvara anugṛhītānām jñāna atiśaye pūrva ukta śruti smṛti vādān āha tathā ca iti
translated: He states the scriptures and statements spoken earlier that the knowledge of those favored by the Supreme Lord is superior. He says And thus, etc.

original: pūrvaṃ kalpādau sṛjati tasmai brahmaṇe prahiṇoti gamayati tasya buddhau vedānāvirbhāvayati🔽yastaṃ devaṃ svātmākāraṃ mahāvākyotthabuddhau prakāśamānaṃ śaraṇaṃ paramamabhayasthānaṃ
analyzed: pūrvam kalpa ādau sṛjati tasmai brahmaṇe prahiṇoti gamayati tasya buddhau vedān āvirbhāvayati  yaḥ tam devam sva ātma ākāram mahā vākya uttha buddhau prakāśamānam śaraṇam paramam abhaya sthānam
translated: In the beginning of the Kalpa, he creates and sends to that Brahman, he conveys, he manifests the Vedas in the intellect of that one.🔽I take refuge in that God, who is manifest in the intellect arisen from the great statements in the form of one's own self, who is the highest refuge, the place of supreme fearlessness,

analyzed: niḥśreyasa rūpam aham prapadye iti arthaḥ
translated: who is of the nature of the highest good. This is the meaning.

original: na kevalamekasyaiva jñānātiśayaḥ kintu bahūnāṃ śākhādraṣṭṛṇāmiti viśvāsārthamāhasmarantīti /
analyzed: na kevalam ekasya eva jñāna atiśayaḥ kintu bahūnām śākhā draṣṭṛṇām iti viśvāsa artham āha smaranti iti
translated: Not only is there an excess of knowledge of one person, but also of many seers of the branches. To inspire confidence, he says they remember.

analyzed: ṛgvedaḥ daśa maṇḍala avayavāḥ tatra bhavāḥ ṛcaḥ dāśatamyaḥ
translated: The Rig Veda has ten sections, and the verses contained therein are the ten-fold.

original: vedāntare 'pi kāṇḍasūktamantrāṇāṃ draṣṭāro baudhāyanādibhiḥ smṛtā ityāhapratīti /
analyzed: veda antare pi kāṇḍa sūkta mantrāṇām draṣṭāraḥ baudhāyana ādibhiḥ smṛtāḥ iti āha prati iti
translated: In other Vedas also, the seers of the sections, hymns, and mantras are remembered by Baudhayana and others. Thus he says it is known.

analyzed: kiñca mantrāṇām ṛṣi ādi jñāna āvaśyaka tva jñāpikā śrutiḥ mantra dṛś ṛṣīṇām jñāna atiśayam darśayati iti āha śrutiḥ api iti
translated: Moreover, the Shruti, which indicates the necessity of knowing the Rishis etc. of the mantras, shows the excess of knowledge of the Rishis who saw the mantras. Thus he says the Shruti also.

analyzed: ārṣeyaḥ ṛṣi yogaḥ
translated: Arshaya means connection with the Rishis.

analyzed: chandaḥ gāyatrī ādi
translated: Chanda means the Gayatri meter etc.

analyzed: daivatam agni ādi
translated: Daiva means Agni and other deities.

analyzed: brāhmaṇam viniyogaḥ
translated: Brahmana means application.

analyzed: etāni aviditāni yasmin mantre tena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in which mantra these are unknown.

analyzed: sthāṇum sthāvaram
translated: Sthanu means immobile.

analyzed: gartam narakam
translated: Garta means hell.

original: tathāca jñānādhikaiḥ kalpāntaritaṃ vedaṃ smṛtvā vyavahārasya pravartitatvādvedasyānāditvamanapekṣatvaṃ cāvirūddhamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca jñāna adhikaiḥ kalpa antaritam vedam smṛtvā vyavahārasya pravartita tvāt vedasya anādi tvam anapekṣa tvam ca avirūddham iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, the idea is that the Veda is beginningless and independent, since the usage has been started by remembering the Veda separated by kalpas by those with superior knowledge.

analyzed: adhunā samāna nāmarūpa tvam prapañcayati prāṇinām ca iti
translated: Now he elaborates on the similarity of names and forms, saying of living beings.

analyzed: tatas kim tatra āha dṛṣṭā iti
translated: What then? He says in the seen.

analyzed: aihika āmuṣmika viṣaya sukha rāga kṛta ṛmasya phalam paśu ādikam dṛṣṭa paśu ādi sadṛśyam iti yuktam
translated: The result of the act done out of attachment to the happiness of this world and the next, such as an animal etc., is proper to be similar to the seen animal etc.

analyzed: visadṛśe kāma abhāvena hetu abhāvāt
translated: In the dissimilar, there is no desire due to the absence of cause.

analyzed: tathā dṛṣṭa duḥkha dveṣa kṛta adharma phalam dṛṣṭa sadṛśa duḥkham eva na sukham
translated: Similarly, the result of the adharma done out of seen hatred and sorrow is only sorrow similar to the seen, not happiness.

analyzed: kṛta hāni ādi doṣa āpatteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the fault of the omission of what is done etc. would arise.

analyzed: tarkita arthe mānam āha smṛtiḥ ca iti
translated: In the matter inferred, he states the means of valid knowledge: and also memory.

analyzed: uttara sṛṣṭiḥ pūrva sṛṣṭi sajātīyā
translated: The subsequent creation is of the same kind as the previous creation.

analyzed: karma phala tvāt
translated: Because it is the result of action.

analyzed: pūrva sṛṣṭi vat iti anumānam caśabda arthaḥ
translated: The inference is: like the previous creation. This is the meaning of the word and.

analyzed: teṣām prāṇinām madhye tāni eva tad jātīyāni eva
translated: Among those beings, those of the same kind, those very ones.

analyzed: tāni darśayan tad prāptau hetum āha hiṃsra iti  karmaṇi vihita niṣiddha tva ākāreṇa apūrvam
translated: Showing them, he states the cause for attaining them: by the non-injury etc.🔽In the action, the unseen is produced in the form of what is enjoined and prohibited.

analyzed: kriyā tvena saṃskāram ca janayanti
translated: And the impression is produced in the form of action.

analyzed: tatra apūrvāt phalam bhuṅkte
translated: There, one experiences the result from the unseen.

analyzed: saṃskāra bhāvita tvāt punar tad jātīyāni karoti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that due to being imbued with the impression, one again does those of the same kind.

analyzed: saṃskāre liṅgam āha tasmāt iti
translated: He states the mark of the impression: therefore.

analyzed: saṃskāra vaśāt eva puṇyam pāpam vā rocate
translated: Due to the impression itself, either merit or demerit is pleasing.

analyzed: atas bhiruci liṅgāt puṇya apuṇya saṃskāraḥ nu meyaḥ
translated: Therefore, from the indication of inclination, the impressions of merit and demerit are to be inferred.

original: sa eva svabhāvaḥ prakṛtirvāsaneti ca gīyate /
analyzed: saḥ eva svabhāvaḥ prakṛtiḥ vāsanā iti ca gīyate
translated: That itself is called nature, inherent nature, and vāsanā (impression).

original: evaṃ karmaṇāṃ sṛṣṭisādṛśyamuktvā svopādāne līnakāryasaṃskārarūpaśaktibalādapi sādṛśyamāhapralīyamānamiti /
analyzed: evam karmaṇām sṛṣṭi sādṛśyam uktvā sva upādāne līna kārya saṃskāra rūpa śakti balāt api sādṛśyam āha pralīyamānam iti
translated: Thus, having stated the similarity of the creation to the action, he says that the similarity is also due to the power in the form of the impression of the dissolved effect in its own material cause, with the words 'dissolving'.

analyzed: itarathā niḥsaṃskāra pralaye jagat vaicitryasya ākasmika tvam syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that otherwise, in the dissolution without impressions, the diversity of the world would be accidental.

analyzed: nanu jagat vaicitrya kāriṇyaḥ nyāḥ śaktayaḥ kalpyantām
translated: But let other powers be postulated to bring about the diversity of the world.

analyzed: tatra aha na ca iti
translated: To that he says 'not so'.

original: avidyāyāṃ līnakāryātmakasaṃskārādanyāḥ śaktayo na kalpyāḥ manābhāvādrauravācca /
analyzed: avidyāyām līna kārya ātmaka saṃskārāt anyāḥ śaktayaḥ na kalpyāḥ manābhāvāt rauravāt ca
translated: Other powers than the impressions in the form of the dissolved effect in ignorance are not to be postulated, because of the absence of mind and the heaviness.

original: svopādāne līnakāryarūpā śaktistu 'mahān nyagrodhastiṣṭhati' 'śraddhatsva somya'itiśrutisiddhā /🔽ato 'vidyātatkāryādanyāḥ śaktayo na santi ātmāvidyaiva tacchaktiriti siddhānta ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: sva upādāne līna kārya rūpā śaktiḥ tu mahān nyagrodhaḥ tiṣṭhati śraddhatsva somya eti śruti siddhā  atas vidyā tatkāryāt anyāḥ śaktayaḥ na santi ātma avidyā eva tad śaktiḥ iti siddhāntaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But the power in the form of the dissolved effect in its own material cause is established by the Vedic texts 'The great banyan tree stands' and 'Have faith, O dear one'.🔽Therefore, the conclusion is that other powers than ignorance and its effects do not exist, and the Self itself is the power of ignorance. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nimitteṣu api upādana stham kāryam eva avidyā ghaṭanayā śaktiḥ anyā vā iti anāgrahaḥ

original: likhantīti vigrahādipañcakasadbhāvādanadhikāradoṣo nāstītyarthaḥ /🔽'vigraho haviṣāṃ bhoga aiśvaryaṃ ca prasannatā /
analyzed: likhanti iti vigraha ādi pañcaka sadbhāvāt anadhikāra doṣaḥ na asti iti arthaḥ  vigrahaḥ haviṣām bhogaḥ aiśvaryam ca prasanna tā
translated: Thus, since the five, beginning with form, exist, there is no fault of non-qualification, is the meaning.

original: phalapradānamityetatpañcakam vigrahādikam' iti /🔽kiñca vigrahābhāvāddevādīnāṃ na kvāpyadhikāra ityāhajyotiṣi bhāvācceti /

translated: The five are: form, enjoyment of oblations, lordship, satisfaction, and bestowal of fruits. This is the fivefold beginning with form.🔽 Moreover, since there is no form for the gods, etc., there is no qualification anywhere, he says: and because of the existence in the luminaries.

original: ādityaḥ sūryaścandraḥ śukro 'ṅgāraka ityādiśabdānāṃ jyotiḥpiṇḍeṣu prayogasya bhāvātsattvānna vigrahavāndevaḥ kaścidastītyarthaḥ /

analyzed: ādityaḥ purastāt udetā paścāt astam etai iti madhu vidyā vākya śeṣe jyotiṣi eva āditya śabdaḥ prasiddhaḥ

translated: The Mīmāṃsakas declare that the Mantras, like rice etc., are taken up by the injunction of performance, and are expressive of things connected with the performance, and are not meant to convey unknown meanings like the names of deities.

translated: Even though in the knowledge of Soma etc. which are mixed with deities etc. there is impossibility of eligibility, still there is possibility in the pure knowledge of Brahman.

analyzed: arthi tva sāmarthya pratiṣedha ādi apekṣa tvāt adhikārasya

analyzed: na ca kvacid asaṃbhavaḥ iti etāvatā yatra saṃbhavaḥ tatra api adhikāraḥ upodyeta

original: atra brūmaḥ jyotirādiviṣayā api ādityādayo devatāvacanāḥ śabdāścetanāvantamaiśvaryādyupetaṃ taṃ taṃ devatātmānaṃ samarpayanti /

translated: As to what has been said above about the existence of the gods in the light, &c, we remark that the words denoting the gods, such as Āditya, &c, denote not only light, &c, but also the individual gods endowed with intelligence and possessing the attributes of lordship, &c

analyzed: mantra arthavāda ādiṣu tathā vyavahārāt
translated: For in the Mantras, Arthavādas, &c, they are used in that sense

original: asti hyaiśvaryayogāddevatānāṃ jyotirādyātmabhiścāvasthātuṃ yatheṣṭaṃ ca taṃ taṃ vigrahaṃ grahītuṃ sāmarthyam /
analyzed: asti hi aiśvarya yogāt devatānām jyotiḥ ādi ātmabhiḥ ca avasthātum yathā iṣṭam ca tam tam vigraham grahītum sāmarthyam
translated: The gods, on account of their lordship, are able to abide in light, &c, and to assume such and such a body as they like

analyzed: tathā hi śrūyate subrahmaṇya arthavāde medhātitheḥ meṣa iti
translated: For instance, it is heard in the Arthavada of the Subrahmanya, 'Medhatithi's ram' (Tai. Br. 2. 7. 10. 1).

original: 'medhātithiṃ ha kāṇvāyanamindro meṣo bhūtvā jahāra' ṣaḍviṃśa / brā / / iti /
analyzed: medhātithim ha kāṇvāyanam indraḥ meṣaḥ bhūtvā jahāra ṣaḍviṃśa iti
translated: 'Indra, becoming a ram, carried off Medhatithi, the son of Kanva' (Satapatha Br. 6. 2. 1. 1).

original: smaryate ca 'ādityaḥ puruṣo bhūtvā kuntīmupajagāma ha' iti /🔽mṛdādiṣvapi cetanā adhiṣṭhitāro 'bhyupagamyante mṛdabravīdāpobruvannityādidarśanāt /
analyzed: smaryate ca ādityaḥ puruṣaḥ bhūtvā kuntīm upajagāma ha iti  mṛd ādiṣu api cetanāḥ adhiṣṭhitāraḥ bhyupagamyante mṛd abravīt apaḥ bruvan ityādi darśanāt
translated: And it is remembered: 'The sun, becoming a man, approached Kunti' (Mahabharata, Sabha, 1. 1).🔽And in the case of clay and so on, it is accepted that conscious beings preside over them, because of such statements as 'Clay spoke, water spoke' (Ch. Up. 6. 1. 3).

analyzed: jyotiḥ ādeḥ tu bhūtadhātoḥ āditya ādiṣu acetana tvam abhyupagamyate
translated: But in the case of the luminous elements like the sun, it is accepted that they are unconscious.

analyzed: cetanāḥ tu adhiṣṭhitāraḥ devatā ātmanaḥ mantra arthavāda ādi vyavahārāt iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that conscious beings preside over them, because of the usage of the Upahavya mantras and the Arthavada passages.

analyzed: yat api uktam mantra arthavādayoḥ anyāya artha tvāt na devatā vigraha ādi prakāśana sāmarthyam iti
translated: As for what was said, that because the mantras and Arthavada passages have a different meaning, they are not capable of revealing the form and so on of the deities,

original: atra brūmaḥ pratyayāpratyayau hi sadbhāvāsadbhāvayoḥ kāraṇaṃ /
analyzed: atra brūmaḥ pratyaya apratyayau hi sadbhāva asadbhāvayoḥ kāraṇam
translated: we say: The cause of existence and non-existence is the presence and absence of cognition,

analyzed: na anya artha tvam ananya artha tvam vā
translated: not having a different meaning or not having a different meaning.

original: tathāhyanyārthamapi prasthitaḥ pathi patitaṃ tṛṇaparṇādyastītyeva pratipadyate /
analyzed: tathā hi anya artham api prasthitaḥ pathi patitam tṛṇa parṇa ādi asti iti eva pratipadyate
translated: For thus, one who has set out with a different purpose, on the path, understands that there is grass, leaves, etc. that have fallen.

analyzed: atra āha viṣamaḥ upanyāsaḥ
translated: Here he says: The example is inappropriate.

original: tatra hi tṛṇaparṇādiviṣayaṃ pratyakṣaṃ pravṛttamasti yena tadastitvaṃ pratipadyate /🔽atra punarvidhyuddeśaikavākyabhāvena stutyarther'thavādena pārthagarthyena vṛttāntaviṣayā pravṛttiḥ śakyādhyavasātum /
analyzed: tatra hi tṛṇa parṇa ādi viṣayam pratyakṣam pravṛttam asti yena tad astitvam pratipadyate  atra punar vidhi uddeśa eka vākya bhāvena stuti artha irthavādena pārthagarthyena vṛttānta viṣayā pravṛttiḥ śakyā adhyavasātum
translated: For there is a perception of grass, leaves, etc., which is operative, by which one understands the existence of those [objects].🔽But here, by syntactical connection with the injunction statement, the engagement with the subject matter of the narrative is capable of being ascertained as having a separate meaning for the purpose of praise by the Arthavada.

original: nahi 'na surāṃ pibet' iti nañvati vākye padatrayasaṃbandhātsurāpānapratiṣedha evaikor'tho 'vagamyate /
analyzed: nahi na surām pibet iti nañvati vākye pada traya saṃbandhāt surā pāna pratiṣedhaḥ eva ekaḥ ūrthaḥ vagamyate
translated: For in the sentence with the negative particle, 'One should not drink wine', only the prohibition of drinking wine is understood as the single meaning, due to the connection of the three words.

analyzed: na punar surām pibet iti pada dvaya saṃbandhāt surā pāna vidhiḥ api iti
translated: And it is not that due to the connection of the two words 'one should drink wine', the injunction of drinking wine is also [understood].

analyzed: atra ucyate viṣamaḥ upanyāsaḥ  yuktam yat surā pāna pratiṣedhe pada anvayasya eka tvāt avāntaravākya arthasya agrahaṇam
translated: To this it is said: The example is not appropriate.🔽It is proper that in the prohibition of drinking wine, the subordinate meaning of the sentence is not grasped, because the connection of the words is single.

original: vidhyuddeśārthavādayostvarthavādasthāni padāni pṛthaganvayavṛttāntaviṣayaṃ pratipadyānantaraṃ kaimarthyavaśena kāmaṃ vidheḥ stāvakatvaṃ pratipadyante
analyzed: vidhi uddeśa arthavādayoḥ tu arthavāda sthāni padāni pṛthak anvaya vṛttānta viṣayam pratipadya anantaram kaimarthya vaśena kāmam vidheḥ stāvaka tvam pratipadyante
translated: But in the case of the injunction statement and the Arthavada, the words in the Arthavada, having first been understood to have a separate connection with the subject matter of the narrative, subsequently, due to the requirement of purpose, they certainly become the praise of the injunction.

original: yathāhi 'vāyavyaṃ śvetamālabheta bhūtikāmaḥ' ityatra vidhyuddeśavartināṃ vāyavyādipadānāṃ vidhinā saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: yathā hi vāyavyam śvetam ālabheta bhūti kāmaḥ iti atra vidhi uddeśa vartinām vāyavya ādi padānām vidhinā saṃbandhaḥ
translated: For, in the case of the sentence, 'One who desires prosperity should sacrifice a white (animal) dedicated to Vayu,' the words 'dedicated to Vayu' and so on, occurring in the injunction, are connected with the injunction.

original: naivaṃ 'vāyurvai kṣepiṣṭhā devatā vāyumeva svena bhāgadheyenopadhāvati sa evainaṃ bhūtiṃ gamayati' ityeṣāmarthavādagatānāṃ padānām /
analyzed: na evam vāyuḥ vai kṣepiṣṭhā devatā vāyum eva svena bhāgadheyena upadhāvati saḥ eva enam bhūtim gamayati iti eṣām arthavāda gatānām padānām
translated: But it is not so with the words occurring in the explanatory passage, 'Vayu is the swiftest deity; verily he goes to Vayu with his own share; he alone leads him to prosperity.'

original: nahi bhavati vāyurvā ālabheteti kṣepiṣṭhā devatā vā ālabhetetyādi /🔽vāyusvabhāvasaṃkīrtanena tvavāntaramanvayaṃ pratipadyaivaṃ viśiṣṭadaivatyamidaṃ karmeti vidhiṃ stuvanti /🔽tadyatra so 'vāntaravākyārthaḥ pramāṇāntaragocaro bhavati tatra tadanuvādenarthavādaḥ pravartate /
analyzed: nahi bhavati vāyuḥ vai ālabheta iti kṣepiṣṭhāḥ devatāḥ vai ālabheta ityādi  vāyu svabhāva saṃkīrtanena tu avāntaram anvayam pratipadya evam viśiṣṭa daivatyam idam karma iti vidhim stuvanti  tat yatra saḥ vāntara vākya arthaḥ pramāṇa antara gocaraḥ bhavati tatra tad anuvādena artha vādaḥ pravartate
translated: For it is not said 'one should sacrifice to Vayu' or 'one should sacrifice to the swiftest deity' and so on.🔽But by proclaiming the nature of Vayu, they praise the injunction, understanding that this rite is dedicated to such and such a deity.🔽And where the meaning of that subordinate sentence is the sphere of another means of knowledge, there the explanatory passage proceeds by referring to that.

analyzed: yatra pramāṇa antara viruddhaḥ tatra guṇa vādena
translated: Where it is contradicted by another means of knowledge, there by a commendatory statement.

original: yatra tu tadubhayaṃ nāsti tatra kiṃ pramāṇāntarābhāvādguṇavādaḥ syādāhosvitpramāṇāntarāvirodhādvidyamānavāda iti pratītiśaraṇairvidyamānavāda
analyzed: yatra tu tat ubhayam na asti tatra kim pramāṇa antara abhāvāt guṇa vādaḥ syāt āhosvit pramāṇa antara avirodhāt vidyamāna vādaḥ iti pratīti śaraṇaiḥ vidyamāna vāda
translated: But where neither of these two is found, should it be a mere eulogy because there is no other means of knowledge, or should it be a statement of what exists because there is no contradiction with other means of knowledge? Those who rely on perception should accept it as a statement of what exists,

analyzed: āśrayaṇīyaḥ na guṇa vādaḥ
translated: not as a mere eulogy.

analyzed: etena mantraḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By this, the mantra is explained.

analyzed: apica vidhibhiḥ eva indra ādi daivatyāni havīṃṣi codayadbhiḥ apekṣitam indra ādīnām svarūpam
translated: Moreover, when the injunctions enjoin the oblations dedicated to Indra and other deities, the nature of Indra and others is required.

analyzed: nahi svarūpa rahitāḥ indra ādayaḥ cetasi āropayitum śakyante
translated: For Indra and others devoid of nature cannot be imposed on the mind.

original: naca cetasyanārūḍhāyai tasyai tasyai devatāyai haviḥ pradātuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: na ca cetasi an ārūḍhāyai tasyai tasyai devatāyai haviḥ pradātum śakyate
translated: And an oblation cannot be offered to this or that deity without being imposed on the mind.

original: śrāvayati ca 'yasyai devatāyai havirgṛhītaṃ syāttāṃ dhyāyedvaṣaṭkariṣyan' ai /brā / / / iti /
analyzed: śrāvayati ca yasyai devatāyai haviḥ gṛhītam syāt tām dhyāyet vaṣaṭkariṣyan aibrā iti
translated: It is also heard: One who is about to utter 'Vashat' should meditate on the deity to whom the oblation has been taken.

analyzed: na ca śabda mātram artha svarūpam saṃbhavati
translated: And the mere word cannot be the nature of the meaning.

analyzed: śabda arthayoḥ bhedāt
translated: Because the word and the meaning are different.

original: tatra yādṛśaṃ mantrārthavādayorindrādīnāṃ svarūpamavagataṃ na tattādṛśaṃ śabdapramāṇakena pratyākhyatuṃ yuktam /
analyzed: tatra yādṛśam mantra arthavādayoḥ indra ādīnām svarūpam avagatam na tat tādṛśam śabda pramāṇakena pratyākhyatum yuktam
translated: There, it is not proper to reject by means of what is known from verbal testimony the nature of Indra and others as it is understood from mantra and arthavada.

original: itihāsapurāṇamapi vyākhyātena mārgeṇa saṃbhavanmantrārthavādamūlatvātprabhavati devatāvigrahādi sādhayitim /
analyzed: itihāsa purāṇam api vyākhyātena mārgeṇa saṃbhavat mantra arthavāda mūla tvāt prabhavati devatā vigraha ādi sādhayitim
translated: The Itihāsas and Purāṇas also, on the same principle, are able to prove the existence of the forms of the gods, &c., since they have Mantras and Arthavādas for their basis.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi mūlam api saṃbhavati
translated: They may also have Perception, &c., for their basis.

analyzed: bhavati hi asmākam apratyakṣam api cirantanānām pratyakṣam
translated: For what is not perceived by us may have been perceived by the ancients.

original: tathāca vyāsādayo devādibhiḥ pratyakṣaṃ vyavaharantīti smaryate /
analyzed: tathā ca vyāsa ādayaḥ deva ādibhiḥ pratyakṣam vyavaharanti iti smaryate
translated: And it is remembered that Vyāsa and others had a direct intercourse with the gods, &c.

original: yastu brūyādidānīntanānāmiva pūrveṣāmapi nāsti devādibhirvyavahartuṃ sāmarthyamiti sa jagadvaicitryaṃ pratiṣedhet /
analyzed: yaḥ tu brūyāt idānīntanānām iva pūrveṣām api nā asti deva ādibhiḥ vyavahartum sāmarthyam iti sa jagat vaicitryam pratiṣedhet
translated: But he who should say that the ancients had no more power of intercourse with the gods, &c., than we have at present, would deny the variety of the world.

original: idānīmiva ca nānyadapi sārvabhaumaḥ kṣatriyo 'stīti brūyāt /
analyzed: idānīm iva ca na anyat api sārvabhaumaḥ kṣatriyaḥ sti iti brūyāt
translated: And he would also say that there was no universal monarch in other ages as there is now.

analyzed: tatas ca rājasūya ādi codanā uparundhyāt
translated: And he would thus deny the possibility of the Rājasūya and other sacrifices.

analyzed: idānīm iva ca kāla antare pi avyavasthita prāyān varṇa āśrama dharmān pratijānīta
translated: And he would also maintain that the duties of the castes and the modes of life were not well defined in other ages as they are now.

analyzed: tatas ca vyavasthā vidhāyi śāstram anarthakam syāt
translated: And thus the scriptures which define the duties would be useless.

analyzed: tasmāt dharma utkarṣa vaśāt cirantanāḥ deva ādibhiḥ pratyakṣam vyavajahnuḥ iti śliṣyate
translated: Therefore it is reasonable to suppose that the ancients, by the power of their superior virtue, had a direct intercourse with the gods, &c.

analyzed: apica smaranti svādhyāyāt iṣṭa devatā saṃprayogaḥ ityādi
translated: Moreover, they remember: 'The union with the desired deity is through self-study' (Tai. Āraṇyaka 10.1.1).

original: yogo 'pyaṇimādyaiśvaryarprāptiphalaḥ smaryamāṇo na śakyate sāhasamātreṇa pratyākhyātum /
analyzed: yogaḥ pi aṇima ādi aiśvarya ṛ prāpti phalaḥ smaryamāṇaḥ na śakyate sāhasa mātreṇa pratyākhyātum
translated: And the fruit of yoga, which is remembered as the attainment of the power to become small, etc., cannot be denied merely out of audacity.

original: śrutiśca yogamāhātmyaṃ prakhyāpayati 'pṛthivyaptejo 'nilakhe samutthite pañcātmake yogaguṇe pravṛtte /
analyzed: śrutiḥ ca yoga māhātmyam prakhyāpayati pṛthivī ap tejaḥ nilakhe samutthite pañca ātmake yoga guṇe pravṛtte
translated: And the Veda proclaims the greatness of yoga: 'When the five-fold yoga quality arises from earth, water, fire, air, and space,

original: na tasya rogo na jarā na mṛtyuḥ prāptasya yogāgnimayaṃ śarīram'' śvaṃ / / iti /
analyzed: na tasya rogaḥ na jarā na mṛtyuḥ prāptasya yoga agni mayam śarīram śvaṃ iti
translated: for him who has attained it, there is no disease, no old age, no death, and the body becomes full of the fire of yoga' (Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad 3.8).

original: ṛṣīṇāmapi mantrabrāhmaṇadarśināṃ sāmarthyaṃ nāsmadīyena sāmarthyenopamātuṃ yuktam /
analyzed: ṛṣīṇām api mantra brāhmaṇa darśinām sāmarthyam na asmadīyena sāmarthyena upamātum yuktam
translated: And the power of the seers who saw the mantras and Brāhmaṇas cannot be compared with our power.

analyzed: tasmāt sa mūlam itihāsa purāṇam
translated: Therefore, the Itihāsas and Purāṇas have a basis.

original: lokaprasiddhirapi na sati saṃbhave nirālambanādhyavasātuṃ yuktā /
analyzed: loka prasiddhiḥ api na sati saṃbhave nirālambanā adhyavasātum yuktā
translated: And popular belief also cannot be accepted as baseless unless there is a possibility (of a basis).

analyzed: tasmāt upapannaḥ mantra ādibhyaḥ deva ādīnām vigrahavat tva ādi avagamaḥ
translated: Therefore, the knowledge of the gods, etc. having bodies, etc. from the mantras, etc. is reasonable.

analyzed: tatas ca arthi tva ādi saṃbhavāt upapannaḥ deva ādīnām api brahmavidyāyām adhikāraḥ
translated: And from that, the possibility of the gods, etc. being entitled to the knowledge of Brahman is reasonable, because of their being supplicants, etc.

analyzed: krama mukti darśanāni api evam eva upapadyante  /
translated: And the teachings of gradual liberation are also reasonable in this way.

original: FN / yataḥ sarveṣāṃ sarvatrādhikāro na saṃbhavati tato na cāpodyetetyanvayaḥ /
analyzed: yatas sarveṣām sarvatra adhikāraḥ na saṃbhavati tatas na ca apodyeta iti anvayaḥ
translated: Because all are not entitled everywhere, therefore it is not to be rejected - this is the connection.

analyzed: tat brahma yaḥ devānām madhye pratyak tvena abudhyata
translated: That Brahman which was known as the manifest Self among the gods,

analyzed: ādi grahaṇena itihāsa purāṇa dharma śāstrāṇi gṛhyante
translated: By the word etc. the Itihasa, Purana and Dharma Shastras are included.

analyzed: vidhi uddeśaḥ vidhi vākyam tad eka vākya tayā
translated: The injunction statement is the statement of the injunction, by the unity of that statement.
The story is the past meaning.

analyzed: śliṣyate yujyate
translated: It is connected, it is proper.

analyzed: mantra japāt devatā sāṃnidhyam tad saṃbhāṣaṇam ca iti sūtra arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the sutra is that the presence of the deity and its conversation are due to the recitation of the mantra.

analyzed: sūtrābhyām prāptam pūrvapakṣam nirasyati tuśabdaḥ ityādinā
translated: Having refuted the prima facie view obtained from the two sutras, he says the word tu and so on.

analyzed: brahma vidyā deva ādīn na adhikaroti
translated: The knowledge of Brahman does not entitle the gods and others.

analyzed: vidyā tvāt
translated: Because it is knowledge.

analyzed: madhu ādi vidyā vat iti ukta hetuḥ aprayojakaḥ iti āha yadi api iti
translated: The stated reason that it is like the knowledge of honey etc. is not conclusive, he says even though.

analyzed: darśa ādikam
translated: The Darsha etc.

analyzed: na brāhmaṇam adhikaroti
translated: It does not entitle the Brahmana.

analyzed: karma tvāt
translated: Because it is an action.

analyzed: rājasūya ādi vat iti ābhāsa sāmyam vidyā tva hetoḥ āha na ca iti
translated: Like the Rajasuya etc. - this is the similarity of appearance to the reason of being knowledge. He says no.

original: yatra yasyādhikāraḥ saṃbhavati sa tatrādhikārīti nyāyastulya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yatra yasya adhikāraḥ saṃbhavati sa tatra adhikārī iti nyāyaḥ tulyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The principle that one is entitled to that where his entitlement is possible - this is the same for all, is the meaning.

original: yataḥ sarveṣāṃ sarvatrādhikāro na saṃbhavati tato na cāpodyetatyanvayaḥ /
analyzed: yatas sarveṣām sarvatra adhikāraḥ na saṃbhavati tatas na ca apodyeta iti anvayaḥ
translated: Because all cannot be entitled everywhere, therefore it is not to be rejected - this is the connection.

original: tadbrahma yo yo devādīnāṃ madhye pratyaktvenābudhyata sa tadbrahmābhavadityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tat brahma yaḥ yaḥ deva ādīnām madhye pratyaktvena abudhyata sa tat brahma abhavat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: He who realized Brahman as the inner Self among the gods and others became that Brahman.

analyzed: te ha devāḥ ūcuḥ anyonyam
translated: The gods said to each other:

original: tata indravirocanau surāsurarājau prajāpatiṃ brahmavidyāpradaṃ jagmaturiti ca liṅgamastītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tatas indra virocanau sura asura rājau prajāpatim brahma vidyā pradam jagmatuḥ iti ca liṅgam asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is an indication that Indra and Virocana, the kings of the gods and demons, went to Prajapati, the giver of knowledge of Brahman.

original: kimatra brahmāmṛtamiti gandharvapraśne yājñavalkya uvāca tamiti mokṣadharmeṣu śrutaṃ devādīnāmadhikāraliṅgamityāhasmārtamiti /
analyzed: kim atra brahma amṛtam iti gandharva praśne yājñavalkyaḥ uvāca tam iti mokṣa dharmeṣu śrutam deva ādīnām adhikāra liṅgam iti āha smārtam iti
translated: In the question of the Gandharva, What is Brahman here, the immortal? Yajnavalkya said, That, which is heard in the Dharmas of Liberation. He says it is an indication of the eligibility of the gods and others.

original: yathā bālānāṃ golakeṣu cakṣurādipadaprayoge 'pi śāstrajñairgolakātiriktendriyāṇi svīkriyante /
analyzed: yathā bālānām golakeṣu cakṣuḥ ādi pada prayoge śāstra jñaiḥ golaka atirikta indriyāṇi svīkriyante
translated: Just as, even though the terms eye etc. are used for the balls in the case of children, those who know the scriptures accept the sense organs apart from the balls.

original: yathā jyotirādau sūryādiśabdaprayoge 'pi vigrahavaddevatā svīkāryā ityāhajyotirādīti /
analyzed: yathā jyotiḥ ādau sūrya ādi śabda prayoge vigraha vat devatā svīkāryā iti āha jyotiḥ ādi iti
translated: Just as, even though the terms sun etc. are used for the light etc., the deity with form should be accepted. He says light etc.

analyzed: tathā cetana tvena vyavahārāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because of the usage as conscious.

analyzed: ekasya jaḍa cetanā ubhaya rūpa tvam katham
translated: How can one be both insentient and sentient?

analyzed: tatra āha astihi iti
translated: There he says but there is.

original: tathāhi vigrahavattayā devavyavahāraḥśrūyate /🔽subrahmaṇya udgātṛgaṇastha ṛtvik tatsaṃbandhī yor'thavādaḥ 'indra /
analyzed: tathā hi vigrahavat tayā deva vyavahāraḥ śrūyate  subrahmaṇyaḥ udgātṛ gaṇa sthaḥ ṛtvij tad saṃbandhī yaḥ arthavādaḥ indra
translated: For thus the usage of the gods as having a body is heard.

analyzed: agaccha ityādiḥ  tatra medhātitheḥ meṣa
translated: The Subrahmanya, a priest standing in the group of Udgātṛs, the explanatory passage connected with him, beginning with O Indra, come,🔽there the invocation of Indra with O Aries

analyzed: iti indra saṃbodhanam śrutam
translated: is heard.

original: tadvyācaṣṭemeveti /🔽muniṃ meṣo bhūtvā jahāreti jñāpanārthaṃ meṣa /
analyzed: tat vyācaṣṭa īm iva iti  munim meṣaḥ bhūtvā jahāra iti jñāpana artham meṣa
translated: He explains it as O Aries.

analyzed: iti indra saṃbodhanam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the invocation of Indra with O Aries is for the purpose of indicating that the sage was carried away by becoming a ram.

analyzed: yat uktam āditya ādayaḥ mṛd ādi vat acetanāḥ eva iti
translated: It is said that the sun and others are only insentient like clay and so on.

analyzed: tat na
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: sarvatra jaḍa jaḍa aṃśa dvaya sattvāt iti āha mṛd iti
translated: Because in every case there are two parts, the inert and the sentient, I say clay and so on.

analyzed: āditya ādau kaḥ jaḍa bhāgaḥ kaḥ cetanā aṃśaḥ iti
translated: What is the inert part in the sun and so on, and what is the sentient part?

analyzed: tatra āha jyotiḥ ādeḥ tu iti
translated: Regarding that, he says but of the light and so on.

original: mantrādikaṃ padaśaktyā bhāsamānavigrahādau svārthe na pramāṇaṃ /
analyzed: mantra ādikam pada śaktyā bhāsamāna vigraha ādau svārthe na pramāṇam
translated: The mantra and so on are not a means of knowledge regarding the meaning that appears by the power of the words in something with a manifest body,

analyzed: anya para tvāt
translated: because they have another purport.

original: viṣaṃ bhuṅkṣveti vākyavadityāhayadapīti /🔽anyaparādapi vākyādbādhābhāve svārtho grāhya ityāhaatra brūma iti /
analyzed: viṣam bhuṅkṣva iti vākya vat iti āha yat api iti  anya parāt api vākyāt bādhā abhāve sva arthaḥ grāhyaḥ iti āha atra brūmaḥ iti
translated: Like the sentence Eat poison, he says that which is also.🔽Or the meaning should be accepted even from a sentence with another purport, if there is no contradiction, he says here we say.

analyzed: tātparya śūnye pi arthe pratyaya mātreṇa astitvam udāharati tathā hi iti
translated: Even in a meaning devoid of purport, existence is by mere cognition, he gives an example thus indeed.

original: tṛṇādau pratyayo 'sti vigrahādau sa nāstīti vaiṣamyaṃ śaṅkateatrāheti /
analyzed: tṛṇa ādau pratyayaḥ sti vigraha ādau sa na asti iti vaiṣamyam śaṅkate atra āha iti
translated: He suspects the inequality that there is approval in grass etc., but not in war etc., and says Here it is said.

analyzed: vidhi uddeśaḥ vidhi vākyam
translated: The injunction statement is the statement of the injunction.

analyzed: tad eka vākya tayā praśastaḥ vidhiḥ iti eva artha vādeṣu pratyayaḥ
translated: By the same sentence, the approval is in the sense that the injunction is praiseworthy.

analyzed: vigraha ādiḥ tad viṣayaḥ pratyayaḥ na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The story is the past meaning.🔽The meaning is that there is no approval in war etc., which are its subject matter.

analyzed: nanu avāntara vākyena vigraha ādi pratyayaḥ stu iti atas āha nahi iti
translated: But let there be approval of war etc. by the subordinate sentence. To this he says No.

analyzed: surā pāna pratyayaḥ pi syāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there would also be approval of drinking liquor.

analyzed: pada ekavākyatva vākya ekavākyatva vaiṣamyāt mā evam iti āha atra ucyate iti
translated: Due to the inequality of being a sentence of one word and a sentence of many words, he says Here it is said.

original: nañpadamekaṃ yadā surāṃ pibediti padābhyāmanveti tadā padaikavākyamekamevārthānubhavaṃ karoti natu padadvayaṃ pṛthaksurāpānaṃ bodhayati /
analyzed: nañ padam ekam yadā surām pibet iti padābhyām anveti tadā pada eka vākyam ekam eva artha anubhavam karoti na tu pada dvayam pṛthak surā pānam bodhayati
translated: When the word not is connected with the two words if one should drink liquor, then it forms a single sentence of one word and produces a single experience of meaning, and the two words do not separately convey the drinking of liquor.

analyzed: tasya vidhau niṣedha anupapatteḥ vākya artha anubhavam prati advāra tvāt
translated: Because in the injunction, prohibition is not possible, and because it is not a door to the experience of the meaning of the sentence.

original: arthavādastu bhūtārthasaṃsargaṃ stutidvāraṃ bodhayanvidhinā vākyaikavākyatāṃ bhajata ityasti vigrahādyanubhava ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: arthavādaḥ tu bhūta artha saṃsargam stuti dvāram bodhayan vidhinā vākya ekavākyatām bhajate iti asti vigraha ādi anubhavaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But the Arthavada, by teaching the connection with the real meaning through praise, becomes syntactically connected with the injunction. Thus, there is the experience of dismemberment etc. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nanu arthavāda stha padānām avāntara saṃsarga bodhaka tvam vinā sākṣāt eva vidhi anvayaḥ stu tatra āha yathā hi iti
translated: If it be said that without the Arthavada words teaching the secondary connection, there should be direct connection with the injunction, he says: Just as...

analyzed: sākṣāt anvaya ayogam darśayati na hi iti
translated: He shows the impossibility of direct connection: For...

analyzed: arthavādāt sarvatra svārtha grahaṇam āśaṅkya arthavādān vibhajate itat yatra iti  tat tatra arthavādeṣu yatra agniḥ himasya bheṣajam ityādau iti arthaḥ
translated: Fearing the apprehension of the meaning of the Arthavada everywhere, he divides the Arthavadas: That is, where...🔽That is, in the Arthavadas, where there is 'Fire is the remedy for cold' etc.

analyzed: ādityaḥ yūpaḥ iti abhedaḥ bādhitaḥ iti tejasvi tva ādi guṇavādaḥ
translated: In 'The sun is the sacrificial post', the non-difference is contradicted, so it is a praise of the qualities of brilliance etc.

original: yatra 'vajrahastaḥ purandaraḥ'ityādau mānāntarasaṃvādavisaṃvādau na stastatra bhūtārthavāda ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yatra vajrahastaḥ purandaraḥ ityādau māna antara saṃvāda visaṃvādau na staḥ tatra bhūtārtha vādaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Where there is 'Indra with the thunderbolt in his hand' etc., and there is neither agreement nor disagreement with other means of knowledge, there it is a statement of the real meaning. This is the meaning.

analyzed: iti vimṛśya iti adhyāhāraḥ
translated: The construction is: having thus considered.

analyzed: vigraha ārta vādaḥ svārthe satya jñāta abādhita arthaka śabda tvāt
translated: The Arthavada of dismemberment has the purport in its own meaning also, because it is a word whose meaning is not known and not contradicted, while having another purport.

analyzed: prayāja ādi vākya vat iti nyāyam mantreṣu atidiśati etena iti
translated: The author now extends the same reasoning to the case of Mantras.

analyzed: vedānta anuvāda guṇa vādānām nirāsāya hetau padāni
translated: The words in the reason are to exclude the Vedanta passages and the Arthavada passages.

analyzed: na ca ubhya para tve vākya bhedaḥ
translated: And there is no split of the sentence even if it refers to both.

analyzed: avāntarārthasya mahāvākya artha tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the subordinate meaning is the meaning of the great sentence.

analyzed: vidhi anupapattyā api svargavat devatā vigrahaḥ ṅgīkāryaḥ iti āha api ca iti
translated: Even by the non-applicability of the injunction, the form of the deity should be accepted like heaven. He says: Moreover...

original: nanu kleśātmake karmaṇi vidhiḥ phalaṃ vinānupapanna iti bhavatu 'yanna duḥkhena saṃbhinnam'ityarthavādasiddhaḥ svargo vidhipramāṇakaḥ /
analyzed: nanu kleśa ātmake karmaṇi vidhiḥ phalam vinā anupapannaḥ iti bhavatu yat na duḥkhena saṃbhinnam iti arthavāda siddhaḥ svargaḥ vidhi pramāṇakaḥ
translated: Now, if the injunction in an action which is of the nature of affliction is not possible without a result, let heaven be established by the Arthavada passage 'which is not mixed with sorrow' and known by the injunction.

analyzed: vigraham vinā vidheḥ kā anupapattiḥ
translated: What is the non-applicability of the injunction without the form?

analyzed: tām āhana hi iti
translated: He states that in 'Na hi' etc.

original: uddiśya tyāgānupapattyā cetasyāroho 'ṅgīkārya ityatra śrutimapyāhayasyā iti /
analyzed: uddiśya tyāga anupapattyā cetasya ārohaḥ ṅgīkāryaḥ iti atra śrutim api āha yasyāḥ iti
translated: And the ascent into the mind is to be accepted by the non-applicability of renunciation with reference to that. Here he quotes the Shruti also in 'Yasya' etc.

analyzed: atas ca itasya āroha artham vigrahaḥ eṣṭavyaḥ  kiñca karma prakaraṇa pāṭhāt vigraha pramitiḥ prayāja vat karma aṅga tvena aṅgīkāryā
translated: And therefore the form is to be desired for the ascent into the mind.🔽Moreover, the cognition of the form is to be accepted as a part of the action like the Prayaja, by the reading in the context of the action.

analyzed: tām vinā karma apūrva asiddheḥ
translated: Because without that, the unseen potentiality of the action is not accomplished.

original: kiñca suprasannavigrahavaddevatāṃ tyaktvā śabdamātraṃ devateti bhaktirayuktetyāhanaca śabdeti /
analyzed: kiñca su prasanna vigraha vat devatām tyaktvā śabda mātram devatā iti bhaktiḥ ayuktā iti āha na ca śabda iti
translated: Moreover, it is not proper to abandon the deity with a well-pleasing form and have devotion to mere sound as the deity. He says: Nor is the deity mere sound,

original: na cākṛtimātraṃ śabdaśakyamastu kiṃ vigraheṇeti vācyaṃ /
analyzed: na ca ākṛti mātram śabda śakyam astu kim vigraheṇa iti vācyam
translated: Moreover, it is not proper to abandon the deity with a well-pleased form and have devotion to the deity as mere sound. Therefore he says: And it cannot be said that the mere form is the object denoted by the word, what is the use of a body?

analyzed: nirvyakti ākṛti ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible without an individual form.

analyzed: atas śabdasya artha ākāṅkṣāyām mantra ādi pramita vigrahaḥ ṅgīkāryaḥ iti āha tatra iti
translated: Therefore, when there is a desire for the meaning of the word, the form known from mantras etc. should be accepted. He says: That.

analyzed: evam mantra arthavāda mūlakam itihāsa ādikam api vigrahe mānam iti āha aitihāsa iti
translated: Thus, the Puranas etc. based on mantras and Arthavadas are also a means of knowing the form of the deity. He says: In the Puranas etc.

analyzed: pramāṇa tvena saṃbhavat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are possible as a means of knowledge.

analyzed: vyāsa ādīnām yoginām devatā ādi pratyakṣam api itihāsa ādeḥ mūlam iti āha pratyakṣa iti
translated: The direct perception of deities etc. by yogis like Vyasa is also the basis of the Puranas etc. He says: By direct perception etc.

analyzed: vyāsa ādayaḥ deva ādi pratyakṣa śūnyāḥ
translated: Vyasa and others are devoid of direct perception of deities etc.

analyzed: prāṇi tvāt
translated: Because they are living beings.

analyzed: asmad vat iti anumānam atiprasaṅgena dūṣayati yaḥ tu ityādinā
translated: He refutes the inference that they are like us by the fallacy of over-extension, beginning with But he who.

analyzed: sarvam ghaṭa abhinnam
translated: Everything is non-different from the pot.

analyzed: vastu tvāt
translated: Because it is an entity.

analyzed: ghaṭa vat iti jagat vaicitryam na asti iti api sa brūyāt
translated: He may also say that there is no diversity in the world.

original: tathā kṣatriyābhāvaṃ varṇāśramābhāvaṃ varṇāśramādyavyavasthāṃ ca brūyāt /
analyzed: tathā kṣatriya abhāvam varṇa āśrama abhāvam varṇa āśrama ādi avyavasthām ca brūyāt
translated: Similarly, he may say that there is no Kshatriya, no Varna and Ashrama, and no arrangement of Varna, Ashrama etc.

analyzed: niraṅkuśa buddhi tvāt
translated: Because of the unrestrained nature of their intellect.

translated: What is that Prāṇa? What is that terrible thunderbolt? In the absence of any idea on these points, we proceed to consider the matter. The most reasonable view is that the term ‘Prāṇa’ stands for the fivefold bodily air, on the ground of this being in keeping with the context.🔽And the term ‘thunderbolt’ also would stand for the lightning, on the ground of this being in keeping with the context.🔽And what is glorified here is the greatness of the Air.🔽How so?🔽This entire world rests upon the fivefold bodily air, which is called ‘Prāṇa’, and moves about.🔽And it is on account of the Air that the terrible thunderbolt is raised.🔽When the Air manifests itself in the form of the Cloud, it is said to manifest itself in the form of lightning, thunder, rain and hail.🔽And it is by the knowledge of the Air that Immortality is attained.

original: tathāhi śrutyantaram 'vāyureva vyaṣṭirvāyuḥ samaṣṭirapa punarmṛtyuṃ jayati ya evaṃ veda' iti /🔽tasmādvāyurayamiha pratipattavya iti /🔽evaṃ prāpte brūmaḥ brahmaivedamiha pratipattavyam /🔽kutaḥ /🔽pūrvottarālocanāt /

translated: What is that prāṇa? What is that terrible thunderbolt? As we do not understand the passage, we must enter on an inquiry The pūrvapakṣin maintains that the passage refers to the wind which has five modifications, and is called prāṇa, because that is the generally received meaning of the word prāṇa, and that the thunderbolt is the flash of lightning, because that is the generally received meaning of the word vajra But, the opponent resumes, the passage glorifies the wind, and the wind only How so? The whole world rests on the wind which has five modifications, and is called prāṇa, and moves on it; and the terrible thunderbolt is hurled on account of the wind only For when the wind is transformed into rain, they say that lightning, thunder, rain, and hail are transformed also And immortality is due to the knowledge of the wind only; for another scriptural passage declares, The wind is the individual soul, the wind is the totality; he who knows this conquers death again and again Bṛ Up , , Hence the wind is to be understood as the object of meditation in the passage under discussion To this we reply that Brahman is to be understood as the object of meditation in the passage under discussion Why so? original: ' kā / / / iti / tenāpi jīvaprājñayorabheda eveha vivakṣata iti gamyate /🔽yatpraśnanimittāṃ ca praśaṃsāṃ mahatīṃ mṛtyoḥ pratyapadyata naciketā yadi taṃ vihāya praśaṃsānantaramanyameva praśnamupakṣipedasthāna eva sā 🔽sarvā praśaṃsā prasāritā syāt /🔽tasmāt 'yeyaṃ prete' ityasyaiva praśnasyaitadanukarṣaṇam 'anyatra dharmāt' iti /🔽yattu praśnacchāyāvailakṣaṇyamuktaṃ tadadūṣaṇam /🔽tadīyasyaiva viśeṣasya punaḥ pṛcchyamānatvāt /🔽pūrvatra hi dehādivyatiriktasyātmano 'stitvaṃ pṛṣṭamuttaratra tu tasyaivāsaṃsāritvaṃ
analyzed: iti tena api jīva prājñayoḥ abhedaḥ eva iha vivakṣate iti gamyate  yad praśna nimittām ca praśaṃsām mahatīm mṛtyoḥ pratyapadyata naciketāḥ yadi tam vihāya praśaṃsā anantaram anyam eva praśnam upakṣipet asthāne eva sā  / sarvā praśaṃsā prasāritā syāt  tasmāt yā iyam prete iti asya eva praśnasya etat anukarṣaṇam anyatra dharmāt iti  yat tu praśna chāyā vailakṣaṇyam uktam tat adūṣaṇam  tadīyasya eva viśeṣasya punar pṛcchyamāna tvāt  pūrvatra hi deha ādi vyatiriktasya ātmanaḥ stitvam pṛṣṭam uttaratra tu tasya eva asaṃsāri tvam
translated: and the other also, in the question, ‘Who is that?’, speaks of the non-difference of the individual soul and the Supreme Self.🔽And if, after the eulogy, he had put forward a question entirely different from the one that had led to the eulogy, then all the eulogy would have been scattered to the winds.🔽Therefore, the question, ‘Who is that?’ is the same as the question, ‘What is that?’ in the text, ‘What is that?’, and the answer to it is given in the text, ‘Other than the existent, other than the non-existent’ (Ka. 2.2.12).🔽As for the difference in the form of the question, that is not a defect;🔽because the same topic is being asked about again.🔽For in the former case, the existence of the Self different from the body, etc., was asked about; in the latter case, the question is about the non-transmigratory character of that very Self.

original: pṛcchyata iti yāvaddhyavidyā na nivartate tāvaddharmādigocaratvaṃ jīvasya jīvatvaṃ ca na nivartate /🔽tannivṛttau tu prājña eva tattvamasīti śrutyā pratyāyyate /
analyzed: pṛcchyate iti yāvat hi avidyā na nivartate tāvat dharma ādi gocara tvam jīvasya jīva tvam ca na nivartate 🔽tad nivṛttau tu prājñaḥ eva tat tvam asi iti śrutyā pratyāyyate

original: nacāvidyāvattve tadapagame ca vastunaḥ kaścidviśeṣo 'sti /🔽yathā kaścitsaṃtamase patitāṃ kāñcidrajjumahiṃ manyamāno bhīto vepamānaḥ palāyate /
analyzed: na ca avidyāvat tve tad apagame ca vastunaḥ kaścid viśeṣaḥ sti  yathā kaścid saṃtamase patitām kāñcid rajjum ahim manyamānaḥ bhītaḥ vepamānaḥ palāyate
translated: And there is no difference whatever in the thing itself, whether it be associated with Nescience or freed from it.

analyzed: tam ca aparaḥ brūyāt mā bhaṣīḥ na ayam ahī rajjuḥ eva iti
translated: For instance, a certain man, in the darkness of night, may take a rope for a snake, and, frightened, trembling, and desirous of flight, may cry out, Do not be afraid, it is not a snake, it is only a rope.

original: sa ca tadupaśrutyāhikṛtaṃ bhayamutsṛjedvepathuṃ palāyanaṃ ca /
analyzed: sa ca tat upaśrutya ahi kṛtam bhayam utsṛjet vepathum palāyanam ca
translated: And the other, on hearing this, will give up the fear caused by the snake, and the trembling and the desire of flight.

original: natvahibuddhikāle tadapagamakāle ca vastunaḥ kaścidviśeṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na tu ahi buddhi kāle tad apagama kāle ca vastunaḥ kaścid viśeṣaḥ syāt
translated: But there will be no difference whatever in the rope itself, when the idea of a snake has been present in the mind, and when that idea has disappeared.

analyzed: tathā eva etat api draṣṭavyam
translated: The case under discussion is to be viewed in the same light.

original: tataśca 'na jāyate mriyate vā' ityevamādyapi bhavatyastitvapraśnasya prativacanam /
analyzed: tatas ca na jāyate mriyate vā iti evamādi api bhavati astitva praśnasya prativacanam
translated: And on account of this the question as to the existence of the soul has been answered by the passage, It is not born, it dies not, and so on.

analyzed: sūtram tu avidyā kalpita jīva prājña bheda apekṣayā yojayitavyam
translated: The Sūtra, however, has to be interpreted with a view to the difference of the individual soul and the highest Self, a difference which is due to Nescience.

original: ekatve 'pi hyātmaviṣayasya praśnasya prāyaṇāvasthāyāṃ dehavyatiriktāstitvamātravicikitsānātkartṛtvādisaṃsārasvabhāvānapohanācca pūrvasya paryāyasya
analyzed: ekatve pi hi ātma viṣayasya praśnasya prāyaṇa avasthāyām deha vyatirikta astitva mātra vicikitsānāt kartṛ tva ādi saṃsāra svabhāva anapohanāt ca pūrvasya paryāyasya
translated: For although the Self is one only, still the question which is put in the passage under discussion refers to the individual soul, because the doubt expressed there refers to the existence of the individual soul only, and because the questioner does not deny the nature of the individual soul as connected with the saṃsāra, ie as connected with the attributes of an agent, and so on

analyzed: jīva viṣaya tvam utprekṣyate
translated: The first section of the Sūtra therefore refers to the individual soul.

analyzed: uttarasya tu dharma ādi atyaya saṃkīrtanāt prājña viṣaya tvam iti
translated: But in the case of the northern path, the mention of the transgression of Dharma etc. indicates that it pertains to the wise.

analyzed: tatas ca yukta agni jīva paramātma kalpanā
translated: And hence the assumption of Agni, Jiva and the Supreme Self is proper.

original: pradhānakalpanāyāṃ tu na varapradānaṃ na praśno na prativacanamiti vaiṣamyam // //
analyzed: pradhāna kalpanāyām tu na vara pradānam na praśnaḥ na prativacanam iti vaiṣamyam
translated: But in the assumption of Pradhana, there is no bestowal of boons, no question, no reply - this is the disparity.

original: FN / mṛtyunā naciketasaṃprati trīnvarānavṛṇīṣvetyuktestrayāṇāmeva praśno naciketasā kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: mṛtyunā naciketas prati trīn varān avṛṇīṣva iti ukteḥ trayāṇām eva praśnaḥ naciketas kṛ
translated: When Death said to Nachiketa, Choose three boons, Nachiketa asked about the three alone.

analyzed: upanyāsaḥ ca mṛtyunā kṛtaḥ
translated: And the presentation was made by Death.

original: he mṛtyo / sa mahyaṃ dattavarastvaṃ svargahetumagnimadhyeṣi smarasi /
analyzed: he mṛtyo sa mahyam datta varaḥ tvam svarga hetum agnim adhyeṣi smarasi
translated: O Death, that boon given to me by you, you remember the Agni that is the cause of heaven.

analyzed: prete mṛte
translated: When the embodied one dies.

original: dehādanyo 'sti naveti saṃśayo /'sti ata etadātmatattvamasaṃdigdhaṃ jānīyāmityarthaḥ /
analyzed: dehāt anyaḥ sti na vā iti saṃśayaḥ usti atas etat ātma tattvam asaṃdigdham jānīyām iti arthaḥ
translated: There is doubt whether there is another apart from the body or not. The meaning is: I should know this truth about the self without doubt.

analyzed: śrutam upanyāsam
translated: The presentation heard is the introduction.

analyzed: vara pradhānam upakramaḥ yasyāḥ sā
translated: That which has the bestowal of boons as its beginning is so-named.

analyzed: prahitāya yama lokam prati preṣitāya
translated: To one sent to the world of Yama.

analyzed: gocara tvāt aśraya tvāt
translated: Because it is the domain, because it is the basis.

analyzed: bhāgī yuktaḥ
translated: One who is fit is a partaker.

analyzed: antaḥ vasthā
translated: The end is the state.

original: yena sākṣiṇā pramātā paśyati tamātmānamiti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: yena sākṣiṇā pramātā paśyati tam ātmānam iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: by which witness the knower sees, that is the self.

analyzed: iha dehe yat caitanyam tat eva amutra sūrya ādau
translated: The sentience that is here in the body, that alone is there in the sun etc.

analyzed: yasmin praśnaḥ yad praśnaḥ tam vihāya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: leaving aside that question which is about that.

analyzed: viśeṣa ukti samāptau iti śabdaḥ  kiñca atra kaṭhavallyām pradhānasya praśna uttarayoḥ asattvāt na grahaṇam iti āha trayāṇām iti
translated: The word 'iti' (thus) at the end of the statement of the special case.🔽And moreover, here in the Katha-valli, since there is no question and answer about the pradhāna, it is not mentioned. Thus he says 'of the three'.

original: mṛtyunā naciketasaṃ prati trīnvarānvṛṇīṣvetyukteḥ trayāṇāmeva praśno naciketasā kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: mṛtyunā naciketasam prati trīn varān vṛṇīṣva iti ukteḥ trayāṇām eva praśnaḥ naciketasā kṛtaḥ
translated: When Death said to Naciketas, 'Choose three boons', Naciketas asked questions about only three things.

analyzed: upanyāsaḥ ca mṛtyunā kṛtaḥ
translated: And the statement was made by Death.

analyzed: na anyasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: not of anything else.

analyzed: praśna trayam krameṇa paṭhati tatra tāvat iti
translated: He reads the three questions in order, beginning with 'tatra tāvad'.

original: he mṛtyo / sa mahyaṃ dattavarastvaṃ svargahetumagni smarasi /
analyzed: he mṛtyo sa mahyam datta varaḥ tvam svarga hetum agni smarasi
translated: O Death, you have granted me the boon, you remember the fire which is the cause of heaven.

analyzed: prete mṛte
translated: After death, when dead.

analyzed: dehāt anyaḥ sti na vā iti saṃśayaḥ sti
translated: There is doubt whether there is anything other than the body or not.

analyzed: atas etat ātma tattvam asaṃdigdham jānīyām iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is: may I know this truth about the self without doubt.

analyzed: krameṇa uttara trayam āha prativacanam api iti
translated: He states the three answers in order, beginning with 'prativacanam api'.

analyzed: loka hetu virāj ātmanā upāsya tvāt loka ādiḥ cityaḥ gniḥ tam mṛtyuḥ uvāca naciketase
translated: Death said to Naciketas the fire which is the object of worship of the world-cause, Virāj, and the Self.

original: yāḥ svarūpato yāvatīḥ saṃkhyāto yathā vā krameṇāgniścīyate tatsarvamuvācetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yāḥ svarūpataḥ yāvatīḥ saṃkhyātaḥ yathā vā krameṇa agniḥ cīyate tat sarvam uvāca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: he said everything about how the fire is piled up in terms of its nature, extent, and order.

original: hantedānīṃ brahma vakṣyāmīti brahmavākyena jīvapraśnādvyavahitanamapi 'yathā ca maraṇaṃ prāpya'ityādi vākyaṃ jīvaviṣayamuttaraṃ /
analyzed: hanta idānīm brahma vakṣyāmi iti brahma vākyena yathā ca maraṇam prāpya etyādi vākyam jīva viṣayam uttaram
translated: Now, I will declare the Brahman. Thus, by the statement of Brahman, even though interrupted by the question about the individual soul, the statement beginning with 'and how one becomes after attaining death' is the answer about the individual soul.

analyzed: yogya tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is because of suitability.

original: vākyārthastu ātmā maraṇaṃ prāpya yathā bhavati tathā vakṣyāmīti /
analyzed: vākya arthaḥ tu ātmā maraṇam prāpya yathā bhavati tathā vakṣyāmi iti
translated: The meaning of the sentence is: I will declare how the self becomes after attaining death.

analyzed: pratijñātam āha yonim iti
translated: He states what was promised with 'yoni' (womb).

analyzed: carācara deha prāptau nimittam āha yathā iti
translated: He states the cause for attaining the bodies of the moving and unmoving with 'yathā' (as).

analyzed: śrutam upāsanam
translated: The meditation is heard.

analyzed: sūtre ādyaḥ cakāraḥ yatas iti arthaḥ
translated: In the sutra, the first 'ca' (and) means 'since'.

original: evaṃ ca trayāṇāmevopanyāsaḥ praśnaśca yataḥ ato na pradhānamavyaktamiti yojanā /
analyzed: evam ca trayāṇām eva upanyāsaḥ praśnaḥ ca yatas atas na pradhānam avyaktam iti yojanā
translated: And thus, only three are mentioned and asked about, since. Therefore, the primordial nature is not the unmanifest. This is the construction.

analyzed: ukta arthe sūtram ākṣipati atra āha iti
translated: He objects to the stated meaning of the sutra with 'Here it is said'.

original: ekaḥ praśnaḥ dvau praśnau veti pakṣadvaye phalitaṃ pṛcchatikiñcāta iti /
analyzed: ekaḥ praśnaḥ dvau praśnau vā iti pakṣa dvaye phalitam pṛcchati kiñca atas iti
translated: In the two cases of one question or two questions, he asks the result with 'What then?'.

analyzed: saptamī arthe tasiḥ
translated: The 'tasi' suffix is in the sense of the locative case.

analyzed: atra ca pakṣa dvaye pi kim iti arthaḥ
translated: And in both cases, the meaning is 'what then?'.

original: praśnaikye sūtrāsaṃgatiḥ bhede pradhānasya śrautatvasiddhiriti pūrvavādyāhasa evetyādinā /
analyzed: praśna aikye sūtra asaṃgatiḥ bhede pradhānasya śrauta tva siddhiḥ iti pūrvavādī āha saḥ eva ityādinā
translated: In the case of one question, the sutra is irrelevant. In the case of difference, the primordial nature is established as heard. The former speaker says with 'Sa eva' (he alone) and so on.

analyzed: praśna aikya pakṣam ādāya siddhāntī āha atra ucyate iti
translated: Taking the side of the unity of the question, the Siddhantin says Here it is said etc.

analyzed: yena pradhāna siddhiḥ syāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is by which there would be the establishment of the principal.

analyzed: caturtha praśna kalpane vara tritva upakrama virodhaḥ syāt iti vivṛṇoti vara ityādinā
translated: If the fourth question is assumed, there would be a contradiction with the beginning of the three boons. This is explained by boon etc.

analyzed: vara pradānam upakramaḥ yasyāḥ sā
translated: That which has the granting of a boon as its beginning.

analyzed: prahitāya yama lokam prati preṣitāya
translated: To one sent to the world of Yama, to the dead.

original: itaḥ punaḥ martyalokaṃ prāptasya mama pitā yathāpūrvaṃ sumanāḥ syāditi prathamaṃ vavre /
analyzed: itas punar martya lokam prāptasya mama pitā yathāpūrvam su manāḥ syāt iti prathamam vavre
translated: May my father be well-disposed as before, after I have returned from here to the world of mortals, he chose first.

original: nanu dvitīyavaro jīvavidyā tṛtīyo brahmavidyeti praśnabhedaḥ kiṃ na syādityata āhayeyamiti /
analyzed: nanu dvitīya varaḥ jīvavidyā tṛtīyaḥ brahmavidyā iti praśna bhedaḥ kim na syāt iti atas āha yeyam iti
translated: But is it not that the second boon is the knowledge of the individual soul and the third is the knowledge of Brahman? So how can there not be a difference in the questions? To this he says This etc.

original: prete ityupakramya tṛtīyatvoktiliṅgājjīvātmavidyaiva tṛtīyo vara ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: prete iti upakramya tṛtīya tva ukti liṅgāt jīvātma vidyā eva tṛtīyaḥ varaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The third boon is the knowledge of the individual soul itself, because it is indicated by the statement of being third after mentioning the dead in the beginning.

original: evaṃ vākyopakrame sati praśnāntaraṃ na yuktamityāhatatreti /
analyzed: evam vākya upakrame sati praśna antaram na yuktam iti āha tatra iti
translated: When there is such a beginning to the passage, it is not proper to have another question. This is stated by There etc.

original: maraṇadharmādyasparśaliṅgābhyāṃ praṣṭavyayorjīveśvarayorbhedāt praśnabhedasiddhervākyabādho yukta iti śaṅkatenanvityādinā /
analyzed: maraṇa dharma ādi asparśa liṅgābhyām praṣṭavyayoḥ jīva īśvarayoḥ bhedāt praśna bheda siddheḥ vākya bādhaḥ yuktaḥ iti śaṅkate nanu ityādinā
translated: Since there is a difference in the questions due to the difference between the individual soul and the Lord, who are to be asked about by the signs of being subject to death and the undesirable contact, it is proper that the passage be contradicted. This is suspected by But etc.

analyzed: gocara tvāt āśraya tvāt
translated: Because of being the object, because of being the support.

original: na kevalaṃ praṣṭavyabhedāt praśnabhedaḥ kintu praśnavākyayoḥ sādṛśyābhāvādapītyāhapraśnacchāyeti /
analyzed: na kevalam praṣṭavya bhedāt praśna bhedaḥ kintu praśna vākyayoḥ sādṛśya abhāvāt api iti āha praśna chāyā iti
translated: He says that the difference in questions is not only due to the difference in the objects asked about, but also due to the lack of similarity between the questions and their statements, by saying the shadow of the question.

analyzed: praṣṭavya bhedaḥ siddhaḥ iti pariharati na ityādinā
translated: He answers No and so on, that the difference in the objects asked about is not established.

original: kiñca brahmāpraśne janmādiniṣedhena jīvasvarūpaṃ vadan yamastayoraikyaṃ sūcayatītyāhaiha cānyatreti /
analyzed: kiñca brahma apraśne janma ādi niṣedhena jīva svarūpam vadan yamaḥ tayoḥ aikyam sūcayati iti āha aiha ca anyatra iti
translated: Moreover, in the question about Brahman, Yama, by denying birth etc., speaks of the nature of the individual soul, indicating their identity. He says Here and elsewhere.

analyzed: tad niṣedha vākye śiva uktiḥ asiddhā iti atas āha sati iti
translated: In the statement denying that, the statement of Shiva is not established. Therefore he says It is.

analyzed: bhāgī yuktaḥ
translated: Bhagī means connected.

analyzed: tasmāt avidyayā jīvasya prāpta janma ādi niṣedhena svarūpam uktam iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, by denying the birth etc. attained by the individual soul through ignorance, its nature is said to be spoken of. This is the meaning.

analyzed: kiñca jīvaḥ brahma abhinnaḥ
translated: Moreover, the individual soul is non-different from Brahman.

analyzed: mokṣa hetu jñāna viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because it is the object of knowledge which is the cause of liberation.

analyzed: brahma vat iti āha tathā svapna iti
translated: Like Brahman, he says So in the dream state.

analyzed: antaḥ vasthā
translated: Anta means state.

original: yena sākṣiṇā pramātā paśyati tāmātmānamiti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: yena sākṣiṇā pramātā paśyati tām ātmānam iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The one by whom the experiencer sees that state is the self. This is the connection.

analyzed: hetoḥ aprayojaka tvam āśaṅkaya tam eva viditvā iti śruti virodham āha prājña iti
translated: Fearing that the reason is not conclusive, he says The wise one to show the contradiction with the scripture Having known Him alone.

original: kiñcābhedamuktvā bhedasya ninditatvādabheda eva satya ityāhatatheti /
analyzed: kiñca abhedam uktvā bhedasya nindita tvāt abhedaḥ eva satyaḥ iti āha tathā iti
translated: Moreover, after speaking of non-difference, because difference is condemned, non-difference alone is true. He says So and so on.

analyzed: iha dehe yat caitanyam tat eva amutra sūrya ādau
translated: The consciousness that is here in this body is the same as that in the sun and other things.

original: evamihākhaṇḍaikarase brahmaṇi yo nāneva mithyābhedaṃ paśyati sa bhedadarśī maraṇānmaraṇaṃ prāpnoti saṃsārabhayānna mucyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: evam iha akhaṇḍa ekarase brahmaṇi yaḥ nānā iva mithyā bhedam paśyati sa bheda darśī maraṇāt maraṇam prāpnoti saṃsāra bhayāt na mucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, he who sees diversity, false distinctions, in Brahman which is undivided and of one taste here, he who sees distinctions, attains death after death from death, i.e., is not liberated from the fear of worldly existence. This is the meaning.

original: kiñca jīvapraśnānantaraṃ 'taṃ durdarśam'iti yaduttaramuvāca tenāpyuttareṇābhedo gamyata iti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca jīva praśna anantaram tam durdarśam iti yat uttaram uvāca tena api uttareṇa abhedaḥ gamyate iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Moreover, the non-difference is understood from the answer that was given after the question about the individual soul, namely, 'That is difficult to see' - this is the connection.

analyzed: praṣṭṛ praśnayoḥ praśaṃsayā api liṅgena pṛṣṭasya daurlabhya dyotanāt brahma tva siddhiḥ iti āha anyam varam ityādinā
translated: Brahmanhood is established by the indication of the rarity of the one questioned by the praise of the questioner and the question, through the inference. He says this with 'Another boon' and so on.

original: putrādikaṃ vṛṇīṣvetyukte 'pi viṣayāṃstucchīkṛtyātmajñānānna cacāla 'nānyaṃ tasmānnaciketā vṛṇīte'iti śravaṇāt /
analyzed: putra ādikam vṛṇīṣva iti ukte viṣayān tucchīkṛtya ātma jñānāt na cacāla na anyam tasmāt naciketāḥ vṛṇīte iti śravaṇāt
translated: Even when told 'Choose a son and so on', he did not waver from self-knowledge, considering worldly objects to be worthless, as stated in the text 'Naciketas does not choose anything else than that'.

original: tadā saṃtuṣṭo yamaḥ 'anyacchreyo 'nyadutaiva preyaḥ'iti bhogāpavargamārgayorvailakṣaṇyaṃ pratijñāya 'dūramete viparīte viṣūcī avidyā yā ca
analyzed: tadā saṃtuṣṭaḥ yamaḥ anyat śreyaḥ nyat uta eva preyaḥ iti bhoga apavarga mārgayoḥ vailakṣaṇyam pratijñāya dūram ete viparīte viṣūcī avidyā yā ca
