translated: are the seven transformations of prakrti.

original: ṣoḍaśakaśca vikāro na prakṛtirna vikṛtiḥ puruṣaḥ' sāṃkhyakā / iti /
analyzed: ṣoḍaśakaḥ ca vikāraḥ na prakṛtiḥ na vikṛtiḥ puruṣaḥ sāṃkhyakāḥ iti
translated: The group of sixteen is a transformation. The puruṣa is neither a prakrti nor a vikṛti.' Sāṃkhyakārikā.

original: tayā śrutiprasiddhayā pañcaviṃśatisaṃkhyayā teṣāṃ smṛtiprasiddhānāṃ pañcaviṃśatitattvānāmupasaṃgrahātprāptaṃ punaḥ śrutimattvameva pradhānādīnām
analyzed: tayā śruti prasiddhayā pañcaviṃśati saṃkhyayā teṣām smṛti prasiddhānām pañcaviṃśati tattvānām upasaṃgrahāt prāptam punar śrutimat tvam eva pradhāna ādīnām
translated: By the number twenty-five, which is well known from the Veda, the twenty-five principles, which are well known from Smṛti, are included, and thus the pradhāna, etc., again obtain the quality of being mentioned in the Veda

original: tato brūmaḥ na saṃkhyopasaṃgrahādapi pradhānādīnāṃ śrutimattvaṃ pratyāśā kartavyā /
analyzed: tatas brūmaḥ na saṃkhyā upasaṃgrahāt api pradhāna ādīnām śrutimat tvam pratyāśā kartavyā
translated: Therefore we say: On account of the inclusion of the number twenty-five, no hope can be entertained that the pradhāna, etc., are mentioned in the Veda

original: kasmāt /🔽nānābhāvāt /🔽nānā hyetāni pañcaviṃśatistattvāni /🔽naiṣāṃ pañcaśaḥ pañcaśaḥ sādhāraṇo dharmo 'sti /
analyzed: kasmāt  nānābhāvāt  nānā hi etāni pañcaviṃśatiḥ tattvāni  na eṣām pañcaśas pañcaśas sādhāraṇaḥ dharmaḥ sti
translated: Why not?🔽On account of the difference of the principles🔽The twenty-five principles are different from one another

original: yena pañcaviṃśaterantarāle parāḥ pañca pañcasaṃkhyā niveśeran /
analyzed: yena pañcaviṃśateḥ antarāle parāḥ pañca pañca saṃkhyāḥ niveśeran
translated: They have no common property in groups of five, by virtue of which other sets of five could be inserted in the series of five

original: nahyekanibandhanamantareṇa nānābhūteṣu dvitvādikāḥ saṃkhyā niviśante /🔽athocyeta pañcaviṃśatisaṃkhyaiveyamavayavadvāreṇa lakṣyate /
analyzed: nahi eka nibandhanam antareṇa nānā bhūteṣu dvi tva ādikāḥ saṃkhyāḥ niviśante  atha ucyeta pañcaviṃśati saṃkhyā eva iyam avayava dvāreṇa lakṣyate
translated: For, without a common basis, the numbers two and so on cannot be inserted in things that are different from one another

original: yathā 'pañca sapta ca varṣāṇi na vavarṣa śatakratuḥ' iti dvādaśavārṣikīmanāvṛṣṭiṃ kathayanti tadvaditi /
analyzed: yathā pañca sapta ca varṣāṇi na vavarṣa śatakratuḥ iti dvādaśa vārṣikīm anāvṛṣṭim kathayanti tadvat iti
translated: Now it might be said that the number twenty-five is indicated by the word part, just as in the passage, Śatakratu did not rain for five and seven years, the drought lasting twelve years is spoken of

analyzed: tat api na upapadyate
translated: But that also is not possible

analyzed: ayam eva asmin pakṣe doṣaḥ yat lakṣaṇā āśrayaṇīyā syāt
translated: For in that case the fault would arise that we should have to assume a figurative sense of the word part

original: paraścātra pañcaśabdo janaśabdena samastaḥ pañcajanā iti /
analyzed: paraḥ ca atra pañca śabdaḥ jana śabdena samastaḥ pañcajanāḥ iti
translated: And here the word 'five' is compounded with the word 'people' to form 'five people'.

analyzed: pāribhāṣikeṇa svareṇa eka pada tva niścayāt
translated: Because it is ascertained to be one word by the technical accent.

analyzed: prayoga antare ca pañcānām tvā pañcajanānām taiḥ
translated: And in another application, 'Of the five, of the five people' (Taitt.

analyzed: iti aikapadya ekasvarya eka vibhaktika tva avagamāt
translated: Because it is understood to be one, with one accent, and in one case.

analyzed: samastasya na vīpsā pañca pañca iti
translated: The repetition is not of the compound, as in 'five fives'.

analyzed: na ca pacaka dvaya grahaṇam pañca pañca iti
translated: Nor is it the taking of two sets of five, as in 'five fives'.

original: naca pañcasaṃkhyāyā ekasyāḥ pañcasaṃkhyayā parayā viśeṣaṇaṃ pañca pañcakā iti /
analyzed: na ca pañca saṃkhyāyāḥ ekasyāḥ pañca saṃkhyayā parayā viśeṣaṇam pañca pañcakāḥ iti
translated: Nor is the single number 'five' qualified by the higher number 'five', as in 'five fives'.

analyzed: upasarjanasya viśeṣaṇena asaṃyogāt
translated: Because the subordinate cannot be connected with the qualifier.

original: nanvāpannapañcasaṃkhyakā janā eva punaḥ pañcasaṃkhyayā viśeṣyamāṇāḥ pañcaviṃśatiḥ pratyeṣyante /
analyzed: nanu āpanna pañca saṃkhyakāḥ janāḥ eva punar pañca saṃkhyayā viśeṣyamāṇāḥ pañcaviṃśatiḥ pratyeṣyante
translated: But the people who have already obtained the number 'five' will be understood as twenty-five when qualified again by the number 'five'.

original: yathā pañca pañcapūlya iti pañcavaṃśatipūlāḥ pratīyante tadvat /
analyzed: yathā pañca pañca pūlyaḥ iti pañcavaṃśati pūlāḥ pratīyante tadvat
translated: Just as twenty-five balls are understood when it is said 'five fives of balls'.

analyzed: na iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say no.

original: yuktaṃ yatpañcapūlīśabdasya samāhārābhiprāyatvātkatīti satyāṃ bhedākāṅkṣāyāṃ pañca pañcapūlya iti viśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: yuktam yat pañca pūlī śabdasya samāhāra abhiprāya tvāt kati iti satyām bheda ākāṅkṣāyām pañca pañca pūlyaḥ iti viśeṣaṇam
translated: It is proper that when the word 'five balls' is intended to mean a collection, and there is a desire to distinguish when it is said 'five fives of balls', it is a qualification.

original: iha tu pañca pañca janā ityādita eva bhedopādānātkatītyasatyāṃ bhedākāṅkṣāyāṃ na pañca pañcajanā iti viśeṣaṇaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: iha tu pañca pañca janāḥ iti āditas eva bheda upādānāt kati iti asatyām bheda ākāṅkṣāyām na pañca pañcajanāḥ iti viśeṣaṇam bhavet
translated: But here, in the passage, ‘Five five-fold groups of people,’ the distinction is mentioned right at the outset; and until there is a desire for a distinction, there can be no such qualifying phrase as ‘five five-fold groups of people.’

analyzed: bhavat api idam viśeṣaṇam pañca saṃkhyāyāḥ eva bhavet
translated: And even if the qualifying phrase were there, it could only qualify the number ‘five.’

original: tatra cokto doṣaḥ /🔽tasmātpañca pañcajanā iti na pañcaviṃśatitattvābhiprāyam /
analyzed: tatra ca uktaḥ doṣaḥ  tasmāt pañca pañcajanāḥ iti na pañcaviṃśati tattva abhiprāyam
translated: And in that case, the objection remains as before.🔽From all this it follows that the passage, ‘five five-fold groups of people,’ does not refer to the twenty-five principles.

analyzed: atirekāt ca na pañcaviṃśati tattva abhiprāyam  atirekāt ca na pañcaviṃśati tattva abhiprāyam
translated: And for the same reason, it does not refer to the twenty-five principles.

original: atireko hi bhavatyātmākāśābhyāṃ pañcaviṃśatisaṃkhyāyāḥ /🔽ātmā tāvadiha pratiṣṭhāṃ pratyādhāratvena nirdiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: atirekaḥ hi bhavati ātma ākāśābhyām pañcaviṃśati saṃkhyāyāḥ  ātmā tāvat iha pratiṣṭhām pratyādhāra tvena nirdiṣṭaḥ
translated: For, in that case, the number twenty-five would be exceeded by two,🔽The ‘soul’ has been indicated as the substratum of ‘resting’ in the passage, ‘on which all this rests’;

analyzed: yasmin iti saptami sūcitasya tam eva manye ātmānam iti ātma tvena anukarṣaṇāt
translated: and this same ‘soul’ is referred to in the passage, ‘that which is to be known as the Self.’

analyzed: ātmā ca cetanaḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: And the ‘soul’ is the conscious person;

original: sa ca pañcaviṃśatāvantargata eveti na tasyaivādhāratvamādheyatvaṃ ca yujyate /🔽arthāntaraparigrahe ca tattvasaṃkhyātirekaḥ siddhāntaviruddhaḥ prasajyeta /
analyzed: sa ca pañcaviṃśatau antargataḥ evā iti na tasya eva ādhāra tvam ādheya tvam ca yujyate 🔽artha antara parigrahe ca tattva saṃkhyā atirekaḥ siddhānta viruddhaḥ prasajyeta
translated: and this being included in the twenty-five, it cannot be right to make it both the substratum and the thing subsisting in the substratum.🔽And if the soul be held to be something different from the twenty-five, then it would be necessary to admit of a number of principles in excess of the twenty-five, which would be contrary to the doctrine of the Upaniṣads.

original: tathā 'ākāśaśca pratiṣṭhitaḥ' ityākāśasyāpi pañcaviṃśatavantargatasya na pṛthagupādānaṃ nyāyyam /
analyzed: tathā ākāśaḥ ca pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti ākāśasya api na pṛthak upādānam nyāyyam
translated: Similarly, the statement that space is established does not justify the separate mention of space, which is included in the twenty-five principles.

analyzed: artha antara parigrahe ca uktam dūṣaṇam
translated: And the objection stated applies to the inclusion of something else.

original: kathaṃ ca saṃkhyāmātraśravaṇe satyaśrutānāṃ pañcaviṃśatitattvānāmupasaṃgrahaḥ pratīyate /
analyzed: katham ca saṃkhyā mātra śravaṇe satya śrutānām pañcaviṃśati tattvānām upasaṃgrahaḥ pratīyate
translated: And how is the inclusion of the twenty-five principles heard in the mere mention of the number?

analyzed: jana śabdasya ta tveṣu a rūḍha tvāt
translated: Because the word people is not well-established in the principles.

analyzed: artha antara upasaṃgrahe pi saṃkhyā upapatteḥ
translated: And because the number is possible even when something else is included.

analyzed: katham tarhi pañca pañcajanāḥ iti
translated: Then how is it that there are five groups of people?

analyzed: ucyate diś saṃkhye saṃjñāyām pā sū
translated: It is said: In the case of a number and a direction, in a name.

original: iti viśeṣaṇasmaraṇātsaṃjñāyāmeva pañcaśabdasya janaśabdena samāsaḥ tataśca rūḍhatvābhiprāyeṇaiva kecitpañcajanā nāma vivakṣyante na sāṃkhyatattvābhiprāyeṇa
analyzed: iti viśeṣaṇa smaraṇāt saṃjñāyām eva pañca śabdasya jana śabdena samāsaḥ tatas ca rūḍha tva abhiprāyeṇa eva kecid pañcajanāḥ nāma vivakṣyante na sāṃkhya tattva abhiprāyeṇa
translated: Because of the recollection of this specification, the compound of the word five with the word people is only in a name. Therefore, with the intention of etymological derivation, some people named five groups are intended, not with the intention of the Sāṃkhya principles.

analyzed: te kati iti asyām ākāṅkṣāyām punar pañca iti prayujyate
translated: When there is a desire for the number of them, five is used again.

original: pañcajanā nāma ye kecitte ca pañcaivetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: pañcajanāḥ nāma ye kecid te ca pañca eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the five groups are some people, and they are only five.

analyzed: saptarṣayaḥ sapta iti yathā
translated: Like the seven sages are seven.

analyzed: mūlaprakṛtiḥ avikṛtiḥ anyasya kasyacid vikāraḥ na
translated: The root-nature is not a modification of anything else.

analyzed: mahat ahaṅkāra pañca tanmātrāṇi sapta prakṛti vikṛtayaḥ
translated: The seven, Mahat, Ahamkara, and the five Tanmatras, are both nature and modifications.

analyzed: mahān ahaṅkārasya prakṛtiḥ mūlaprakṛteḥ vikṛtiḥ
translated: Mahat is the nature of Ahamkara and the modification of the root-nature.

analyzed: ahaṅkāraḥ tāmasaḥ tanmātrāṇām prakṛtiḥ
translated: Ahamkara also, in its tamas aspect, is the nature of the Tanmatras.

analyzed: sāttvikaḥ tu ekādaśa indriyāṇām tanmātrāṇi ākāśa ādīnām sthūlānām prakṛtayaḥ
translated: But in its sattvika aspect, it is the nature of the eleven sense organs, and the Tanmatras of space etc. are the natures of the gross elements.

analyzed: pañcabhūtāni ekādaśa indriyāṇi ṣoḍaśakaḥ gaṇaḥ vikāraḥ eva
translated: The group of sixteen, the five elements and the eleven sense organs, is modification only.

analyzed: pṛthivī ādīnām ghaṭa ādi prakṛti tve pi tattva antara aprakṛti tvāt vikṛtayaḥ eva
translated: Even though earth etc. are the natures of pot etc., they are modifications only because they are not the natures of any other principles.

analyzed: puruṣaḥ tu kauṭasthyāt prakṛti vikṛti tva virahī iti arthaḥ
translated: But the Purusha, being immutable, is devoid of being both nature and modification. This is the meaning.

analyzed: bhedaḥ viśeṣaṇam  atireke ādhikyam
translated: Difference is a qualification.🔽Excess is superiority.

analyzed: ukta doṣaḥ saṃkhyā ādhikyam
translated: The stated fault is the excess of number.

original: na saṃkhyopasaṃgrahāt /🔽pañcajanaśabdaḥ sāṃkhyatattvaparo 'nyaparo veti yogarūḍhyoraniścayāt saṃśaye yathā
analyzed: na saṃkhyā upasaṃgrahāt  pañcajana śabdaḥ sāṃkhya tattva paraḥ vā iti yoga rūḍhyoḥ aniścayāt saṃśaye yathā
translated: Not so, because of the inclusion of number.🔽The word five people refers to the categories of Sankhya or to something else. Due to the uncertainty of yoga and rddhi, there is doubt.

analyzed: tattva vidyā adhikāre chāgāyām tātparya abhāvāt ajāpade rūḍhi tyāgaḥ tathā pañca manuṣyeṣu
translated: Just as in the goat, due to the absence of purpose in the section on the knowledge of reality, there is abandonment of the conventional meaning of goat, so in the five men

analyzed: tātparya abhāvāt pañcajana śabdena rūḍhim tyaktvā tattvāni grāhyāṇi iti dṛṣṭānta saṃgatim
translated: The meaning is that, because of the absence of any other purpose, the word 'five people' should be taken to refer to the principles, abandoning its conventional meaning. This is indicated by the connection with the example.

analyzed: sūcayan mantram udāhṛtya pūrvapakṣayati evam ityādinā
translated: Having quoted the mantra, he presents the prima facie view with the words 'thus' etc.

analyzed: phalam pūrvavat
translated: The result is as before.

analyzed: prāṇa cakṣuḥ śrotra anna manāṃsi vākyaśeṣa sthāḥ pañcajanāḥ pañca
translated: The five people mentioned in the supplementary passage are the vital breath, eye, ear, food, and mind.

original: tatra catvāraḥ sūtraṃ annaṃ virāṭ tayoḥ kāraṇamavyākṛtamākāśaśca yasminnadhyastāstamevātmānamamṛtaṃ brahma manye /
analyzed: tatra catvāraḥ annam virāj tayoḥ kāraṇam avyākṛtam ākāśaḥ ca yasmin adhyastāḥ tam eva ātmānam amṛtam brahma manye
translated: Among them, the four are the thread, food is Virāṭ, and the unmanifest and space, in which they are superimposed, are the very self, which I consider to be the immortal Brahman.

analyzed: tasmāt mananāt vidvān aham amṛtaḥ smi iti mantradṛśaḥ vacanam
translated: Therefore, by meditating on that, the knower says, 'I am immortal,' as stated by the seer of the mantra.

original: nanvastu pañcatvaśiṣṭeṣu pañcajaneṣu punaḥ pañcatvānvayāt pañcaviṃśatisaṃkhyāpratītiḥ /
analyzed: nanu astu pañcatva śiṣṭeṣu pañcajaneṣu punar pañcatva anvayāt pañcaviṃśati saṃkhyā pratītiḥ
translated: But let there be the understanding of the number twenty-five by the repetition of the number five in the five people who remain after the five have been taken away.

original: tāvatā kathaṃ sāṃkhyatattvagraha ityāśaṅkya saṃkhyāyā dharmyākāṅkṣāyāṃ tattvāni grāhyāṇītyāhatatheti /
analyzed: tāvatā katham sāṃkhya tattva grahaḥ iti āśaṅkya saṃkhyāyāḥ dharmya ākāṅkṣāyām tattvāni grāhyāṇi iti āha tathā iti
translated: To that extent, how can the principles of Sāṃkhya be grasped? Fearing this doubt, when there is a requirement for a subject for the number, he says 'thus' that the principles should be grasped.

analyzed: jagataḥ mūla bhūtā prakṛtiḥ triguṇa ātmakam pradhānam anādi tvāt avikṛtiḥ
translated: Prakṛti, which is the root of the world, is the primordial nature consisting of the three guṇas. It is beginningless and hence unmanifest.

analyzed: kasyacid kāryam na bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not the effect of anything.

analyzed: mahat ahaṅkāra pañca tanmatraṇī iti sapta prakṛtayaḥ vikṛtayaḥ ca
translated: The seven are the seven principles, Mahat, Ahamkara, and the five Tanmatras, and also the evolutes.

analyzed: tatra mahān pradhānasya vikṛtiḥ ahaṅkārasya prakṛtiḥ
translated: Among them, Mahat is the evolute of Pradhana and the cause of Ahamkara.

analyzed: ahaṅkāraḥ tāmasaḥ pañca tanmātrāṇām śabda ādīnām prakṛtiḥ
translated: Tamas Ahamkara is the cause of the five Tanmatras beginning with sound.

analyzed: sāttvikaḥ ekādaśa indriyāṇām
translated: Sattva Ahamkara is the cause of the eleven organs.

original: pañca tanmātrāśca pañcānāṃ sthūlabhūtānāmākāśādīnāṃ prakṛtayaḥ pañca sthūlabhūtānyekādaśendriyāṇi ceti ṣoḍaśasaṃkhyāko gaṇo vikāra eva na prakṛtiḥ /
analyzed: pañca tanmātrāḥ ca pañcānām sthūlabhūtānām ākāśa ādīnām prakṛtayaḥ pañca sthūlabhūtāni ekādaśa indriyāṇi ca iti ṣoḍaśa saṃkhyākaḥ gaṇaḥ vikāraḥ eva na prakṛtiḥ
translated: The five Tanmatras are the causes of the five gross elements beginning with space. The group of sixteen, consisting of the five gross elements and the eleven organs, is only an evolute, not a cause.
Because it is not the material cause of any other principle.

analyzed: puruṣaḥ tu udāsīnaḥ iti sāṃkhya kārikā arthaḥ
translated: The Purusha is indifferent. This is the meaning of the Sāṃkhya Kārikā.

analyzed: saṃkhyayā tattvānām upasaṃha grahāt śabdavat tvam iti prāpte siddhāntayati na iti
translated: When it is argued that the principles should be enumerated because they are mentioned by number, the conclusion is stated as follows: No.

analyzed: nānātvam iṣṭam iti atas āha na eṣām iti
translated: The diversity is accepted. Therefore, it is said: These.

original: pañcsu pañcasu sādhāraṇasyetarapañcakāddhyāvṛttasya dharmasyābhāvo 'tra nānātvaṃ vivakṣitamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: pañcsu pañcasu sādhāraṇasya itara pañcakāt hi āvṛttasya nānātvam vivakṣitam iti arthaḥ
translated: The intended diversity here is the absence of a property common to the five, which is excluded from the other five. This is the meaning.

original: yadyapi jñānakarmendriyeṣu daśasu jñānakaraṇatvaṃ karmakaraṇatvaṃ ca pañcakadvaye 'sti /
analyzed: yadi api jñāna karmendriyeṣu daśasu jñāna karaṇa tvam karma karaṇa tvam ca pañcaka dvaye sti
translated: Although in the ten organs of knowledge and action, there is the nature of being instruments of knowledge and action in the two sets of five,

analyzed: pañca tanmātrāsu pañcasu sthūla prakṛti tvam ca
translated: and the nature of being gross evolvents in the five subtle elements,

original: tathāpi yasminnityātmana ākāśasya ca pṛthagukteḥ sattvarajastamomahadahaṅkārāḥ pañca kartavyāḥ /
analyzed: tathā api yasmin iti ātmanaḥ ākāśasya ca pṛthak ukteḥ sattva rajaḥ tamaḥ mahat ahaṅkārāḥ pañca kartavyāḥ
translated: nevertheless, since the Self and Ākāśa are mentioned separately in the phrase in which, the five - Sattva, Rajas, Tamas, Mahat, and Ahaṃkāra - should be taken.

analyzed: manaḥ catvāri bhūtāni ca pañca
translated: And the five - Mind and the four gross elements -

analyzed: asmin pañcaka dvaye mithas nuvṛtta itara pañcaka vyāvṛtta dharmaḥ na asti iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The idea is that in this set of five pairs, there is no mutually recurring or other-excluding dharma in the five.

analyzed: mā astu iti atas āha yena iti
translated: To this, he says by which

analyzed: dharmeṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is by dharma.

analyzed: sphuṭayati nahi iti
translated: He clarifies this with For, indeed...

analyzed: mahāsāṃkhyāyām avāntara saṃkhyāḥ praviśanti
translated: The subsidiary numbers enter into the great number,

original: yathā dvāvaśvinau saptarṣayo 'ṣṭau vasavaśceti saptadaśetyatrāśvitvādikamādāya dvitvādayaḥ praviśantiḥ /
analyzed: yathā dvau aśvinau sapta ṛṣayaḥ ṣṭau vasavaḥ ca iti saptadaśa iti atra aśvi tva ādikam ādāya dvi tva ādayaḥ
translated: Just as in the statement the two Aśvins, the seven sages, and the eight Vasus are seventeen, the numbers two and so on enter in by taking the quality of being an Aśvin and so on.

analyzed: na anyathā iti arthaḥ

original: tataśṭodbhidetyaprasiddhasya tṛtīyāntasya yāgenetyanena prasiddhārthakena sāmānādhikaraṇyena tannāmatvaṃ niścīyate /

original: tathā chinattīti prasiddhārthacchedanayogyārthakaśabdasamabhivyāhārāddāruviśeṣo yūpaśabdārthaḥ karotīti samabhivyāhārādvediśabdārthaḥ saṃskārayogyasthaṇḍilaviśeṣa 🔽iti gamyate /

translated: Hence it is that the pūrvapakṣin maintains that on account of the passage under discussion being a complementary passage, and on account of the word prāṇa denoting the chief vital air, either the individual soul or the chief vital air is to be understood, not the highest Lord To this we make the following reply The matter has been already disposed of in the Sūtra , , , where it is said that on account of the threefoldness of the meditation, and on account of the passage being dependent on another, the passage under discussion is to be referred to what is mentioned in another passage, ie to Brahman For if the passage under discussion were to be taken as referring to the individual soul, or to the chief vital air, or to Brahman, three different kinds of meditation would result, and that is improper But the passage under discussion is to be referred to Brahman, because it is introduced and concluded by passages referring to Brahman The introduction of the passage has already been shown to refer to Brahman The conclusion also refers to Brahman, because it teaches a result of such a kind as can be produced only by Brahman, He removes all evil and becomes the highest of all beings, the selfruler, the lord, he who thus knows Bṛ Up , , 0 But if this is the case, the passage under discussion is settled by the decision arrived at with regard to the passage about Pratardana? It is not settled by that decision, because the two passages are not of the same nature

translated: The reply also is, When he is asleep and sees no dreams, then he is one with that prāṇa alone Bṛ Up , , 0, and so on; and, From that Self the prāṇas go forth to their several places; from the prāṇas the gods, from the gods the worlds Kau Up , And in the state of deep sleep the individual soul becomes one with the highest Brahman; and from that highest Brahman the world with its prāṇas and so on originates This is the doctrine of the Vedānta From this it follows that the state of deep sleep, in which the soul is free from all consciousness and is of the nature of pure intelligence, is the souls own nature, free from all the special knowledge produced by the limiting adjuncts, and that the soul comes forth from that state in the form of the parts of that whole, ie of the individual soul Thus it is understood that the highest Self is to be known as the object of the injunctions whose purport is to be known Moreover, in this very dialogue between Bālāki and Ajātaśatru, the Vājasaneyins, who belong to the same Śākhā as the Bṛhadāraṇyaka, distinctly declare, by means of the word consisting of knowledge, that the individual soul is different from the highest Self, and mention the latter as something different from the former, Where is that person consisting of knowledge?

analyzed: tasyāḥ eva pratijñāyāḥ siddhim sūcati etat liṅgam yat mahataḥ bhūtasya draṣṭavyasya bhūtebhyaḥ samutthānam vijñāna ātma bhāvena kathitam iti āśmarathya
translated: This is an indication of the establishment of that very thesis, that the origin of the great existent, which is to be seen, from the elements, is stated in the form of the conscious Self, so thinks Āśmarathya,

analyzed: ācāryaḥ manyate

original: abhede hi satyekavijñānena sarvavijñānaṃ pratijñātamavakalpayata iti /

analyzed: utkramiṣyataḥ evaṃbhāvāt iti auḍulomiḥ
translated: 'From the state of being about to depart, says Audulomi.'

analyzed: utkramiṣyataḥ vijñāna ātmanaḥ jñāna dhyāna ādi sāmarthyāt saṃprasannasya pareṇa ātmanā aikya saṃbhavāt idam abheda abhidhānam iti auḍulomiḥ ācāryaḥ manyate
translated: The teacher Audulomi thinks that this designation of non-difference is because of the possibility of the identity of the departing conscious Self with the supreme Self, when it is satisfied by the power of knowledge, meditation, etc.

analyzed: avasthiteḥ iti kāśakṛtsnaḥ

analyzed: asya eva paramātmanaḥ nena api vijñāna ātma bhāvena avasthānāt upapannam idam abheda abhidhānam iti kāśakṛtsnaḥ ācāryaḥ manyate
translated: The teacher Kashyapa thinks that this designation of non-difference is proper because of the existence of this supreme Self in the state of the conscious Self also.

original: nanūcchedābhidhānametat 'etebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tānyevānuvinaśyati na pretya saṃjñāsti' bṛ / / /
analyzed: nanu uccheda abhidhānam etat etebhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tāni eva anuvinaśyati na pretya saṃjñā asti
translated: But this is a statement of annihilation: 'Having risen from these elements, it is destroyed along with them. After death there is no consciousness.'

analyzed: iti katham eda bheda abhidhānam
translated: How is this a statement of non-difference?

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: viśeṣa vijñāna vināśa abhiprāyam etat vināśa abhidhānam na ātma uccheda abhiprāyam
translated: This statement of destruction is intended to mean the destruction of the knowledge of particulars, not the annihilation of the Self.

original: 'atraiva mā bhagavānamūmuhanna pretya saṃjñāsti' iti paryanuyujya svayameva śrutyārthāntarasya
analyzed: atra eva mā bhagavān amūmuhat na pretya saṃjñā asti iti paryanuyujya svayam eva śrutyā artha antarasya
translated: 'Do not be deluded about this, O Lord. After death there is no consciousness.' When questioned thus, the Shruti itself states the other meaning,

original: darśitatvāt 'na vā are 'haṃ mohaṃ bravīmyavināśī vā are 'yamātmānucchittidharmā
analyzed: darśita tvāt na vai are ham moham bravīmi avināśī vai are yama ātmā an ucchitti dharmā
translated: Because it has been shown in the passage, ‘Verily, I do not say that thou art deluded, O child; this Self is imperishable, O child; it is subject to no modification.

analyzed: mātrā saṃsargaḥ tu asya bhavati iti

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati kūṭasthanitya evāyaṃ vijñānaghana ātmā nāsyocchedaprasaṅgo 'sti /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati kūṭastha nityaḥ eva ayam vijñāna ghanaḥ ātmā na asya uccheda prasaṅgaḥ sti
translated: This is what is meant: This Self, which is a mass of pure knowledge, is immutable and eternal; there is no possibility of its being annihilated.

original: mātrābhistvasya bhūtendriyalakṣaṇābhiravidyākṛtābhirasaṃsargo vidyayā bhavati /🔽saṃsargābhāve ca prakṛtasya viśeṣavijñānasyābhāvānna pretya saṃjñāstītyuktamiti /
analyzed: mātrābhiḥ tu asya bhūta indriya lakṣaṇābhiḥ avidyā kṛtābhiḥ a saṃsargaḥ vidyayā bhavati  saṃsarga abhāve ca prakṛtasya viśeṣa vijñānasya abhāvāt na pretya saṃjñā asti iti uktam iti
translated: But its contact with the limiting adjuncts, which are characterized by the material elements and the organs of sense, and which are due to Nescience, is removed by knowledge.🔽And when there is absence of contact, there is absence of the knowledge of the particular Self, which is the subject of the present discussion; hence it has been said that after death there is no consciousness.’

original: yadapyuktam 'vijñātāramare kena vijānīyāt' iti kartṛvacanena śabdenopasaṃhārādvijñānātmana evedaṃ draṣṭavyamiti /

translated: It has been argued that ‘by the word “knower,” which denotes an agent, the text sums up the section; hence the knowable Self is to be seen.’

original: tadapi kāśakṛtsnīyenaiva darśanena parihapaṇīyam /🔽apica 'yatra hi dvaitamiva bhavati taditara itaraṃ paśyati' bṛ / / /

original: ityārabhyāvidyāviṣaye tasyaiva darśanādilakṣaṇaṃ viśeṣajñānaṃ prapañcya 'yatra tvasya

original: sarvāmātmaivābhūttatkena kaṃ paśyet' ityādinā vidyāviṣaye tasyaiva darśanādilakṣaṇasya🔽viśeṣavijñānasyābhāvamabhidadhāti /

original: punaśca viṣayābhāve 'pi ātmānaṃ vijānīyāt ityāśaṅkya 'vijñātāramare kena vijānīyāt' ityāha /

original: tataśca viśeṣavijñānābhāvopapādānaparatvādvākyasya vijñānadhātureva kevalaḥ saṃnbhūtapūrvagatyā kartṛvacanena tṛcā nirdiṣṭa iti gamyate /

translated: And thus, because the passage is devoted to the proof of the absence of special knowledge, it is understood that the mere ‘Consciousness-principle’ is indicated by the third person, which is used in the sense of the agent, on account of its having existed before.

analyzed: darśitam tu purastāt kāśakṛtsnīyasya pakṣasya śrutimat tvam
